en: URGENT At this time, 3:30 am, a commission from the Intelligence Forces arrives to journalist and human rights activist Luis Carlos Díaz's home, missing since 5:30 pm #WhereIsLuisCarlos
yor: NÍ KÍÁKÍÁ Ní dédé àsìkò yìí, ní dédé agogo 3:00 òwúrọ̀ kùtùkùtù, ìgbìmọ̀ láti àjọ Amúninípá dé ilé oníròyìn àti ajà-fún- ẹ̀tọ́ọ ọmọ ènìyàn Luis Carlos Díaz, tí ó ti di ẹni àwátì láti agogo 5:30 ìrọ̀lẹ́ #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa.
mt0: <pad> JUST NOW, around 3:00 a.m., a delegation from Amnesty International arrived at the press office and human rights activist Luis Carlos Díaz, who has been missing since 5:30 p.m. on Tuesday under the #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa movement.</s>

en: Other human rights and freedom of speech organizations joined the campaign through #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Where is Luis Carlos?) which is, at the moment, a trending topic in Venezuela's twittosphere.
yor: Àwọn ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti àjọ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ náà darapọ̀ mọ ìpolongo yìí pẹ̀lú #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Níbo ni Luis Carlos wà?), tí ó jẹ́ pé, ní báyìí, ni àkọlé tí ó gbajúmọ̀ ní orí ìkànnì ayélujára Twitter ti Orílẹ̀ Èdè Venezuela.
mt0: <pad> Human rights activists and media groups joined the campaign with #DondeEstaLuisCarlos (Where Is Luis Carlos), which has now become a popular hashtag on Venezuelan Twitter.</s>

en: Díaz is a journalist and a human rights and freedom of speech advocate who is well known and highly appreciated in Venezuela and abroad for his commentary and criticism of the government of Nicolas Maduro.
yor: Díaz jẹ́ ajábọ̀ ìròyìn àti a-jà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́-ọmọ ènìyàn tí ó jẹ́ ògbólógbòó ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ tí wọ́n sì mọ ìṣe rẹ̀ fún un l'órílẹ̀ èdè Venezuela àti òkè òkun fún ìdásọ́rọ̀ àti ìtakò ìjọba Nicholas Maduro.
mt0: <pad> Díaz is a journalist and human rights activist who is known for his work in Venezuela and internationally for the promotion and criticism of the government of Nicolas Maduro.</s>

en: He has long worked with Soto producing web-based video and radio programs focused on politics and human rights in Venezuela.
yor: Ó ti tó ìgbà díẹ̀ kan tí ó ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìyàwó rẹ̀ àti olùdásọ́rọ̀ òṣèlú tí ó gbajúmọ̀ n nì, Naky Soto, tí wọn sì ń ṣe ìgbéjáde àwọn fídíò àti ètò Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ lórí ayélujára èyí tí ó dá lórí ìṣèlú àti ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ ènìyàn ní Venezuela.
mt0: <pad> He has been working with his wife and well-known politician spokesperson, Naky Soto, and they have produced videos and an online radio show about politics and human rights in Venezuela.</s>

en: He has also worked as an educator and promoter of the creation of citizen media spaces and independent media projects.
yor: Ó ti ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bí akọ́ni àti olùgbé-lárúgẹ ìdásílẹ̀ àyè ọ̀tọ̀ fún àwọn ará ìlú àti àwọn àkànṣe eto ìgbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ tí kò lọ́wọ́ ìjọ̀ba nínú.
mt0: <pad> He has worked as a director and executive of the Equal Rights Foundation and the non-governmental radio and television stations in the city.</s>

en: Díaz has also been part of the Global Voices community for more than a decade.
yor: Díaz tún jẹ́ olùkópa nínú ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé fún ọdún mẹ́wàá.
mt0: <pad> Díaz has also been a co-founder of the World Voices for 10 years.</s>

en: To me, Luis Carlos is a brilliant person, well versed in information and networks in this chaotic Venezuela of ours.
yor: Lọ́dọ̀ tèmi, Luis Carlos jẹ́ onílàákàyè ẹ̀dá kan, ó gbọ́njú nínú ìròyìn gbígbà àti ìkànsì-ara-ẹni nínú Venezuela ti wa yìí tí kò fara rọ.
mt0: <pad> Luis Carlos is a wildlife photographer, he has been working in the field of ecology and environmental issues in Venezuela.</s>

en: He has been able to make links with society (from criticism to cultural spaces) #WhereIsLuisCarlos.
yor: Ó ti ṣe àwárí ìjápọ̀ nínú ìlú (láti ìtakò sí ibi ìṣẹ̀ṣe) #NiboniLuisCarlosWa.
mt0: <pad> He has found connections in the city (to get to his job) #NiboniLuisCarlosWa.</s>

en: Just a few days prior to his disappearance, the state-affiliated media program Con el Mazo Dando showed a video clip of a recent broadcast of Diaz.
yor: Láàrin ọjọ́ péréte tó ṣíwájú ìpòóráa rẹ̀, ètò ìkàn-sára- ẹni ti ìjọba Con el Mazo Dando ṣàfihàn fídíò tí Díaz sọ̀rọ̀ nínúu rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> A few days before his death, the government radio show Con el Mazo Dando aired a video of Díaz speaking in it.</s>

en: The program's host, politician Diosdado Cabello, insinuated that Diaz had helped to orchestrate the nationwide power outage that had Venezuelans living in the dark for more than 24 hours on March 7 and 8.
yor: Atọ́kùn ètò ọ̀hún, olóṣèlú Diosdado Cabello, rò kàn pé Díaz lọ́wọ́ sí ìfẹ̀hónú hàn àìsí ináa mọ̀nàmọ̀nà tí ò lọ jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè èyí tí ó mú kí àwọn ọmọ Venezuela máa gbé nínú òkùnkùn fún ó lé ní wákàtí mẹ́rin lé lógún lọ́jọ́ 7 àti 8 Oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà
mt0: <pad> The speaker of the National Assembly, Diosdado Cabello, accused Díaz of participating in the massive blackout that hit Venezuela on 7 and 8 April, forcing Venezuelans to live in darkness for over four hours.</s>

en: There is no evidence to support this.
yor: Kò sí ẹ̀rí tí ó fi ẹsẹ̀ rinlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> No evidence that he walked on his feet.</s>

en: It's been been seven hours since Luis Carlos Díaz has gone missing.
yor: Wákàtí méje ti ré kọjá lọ tí Luis Carlos Díaz ti di àwátì.
mt0: <pad> Luis Carlos Díaz has been a patient for seven hours.</s>

en: [Díaz] is a journalist for Unión Radio Noticias and he's a human rights activist.
yor: [Díaz] jẹ́ oníròyìn fún ilé iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Unión Radio Noticias , ó sì tún jẹ́ ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn.
mt0: <pad> [Díaz] is a journalist for the radio station Unión Radio Noticias and a human rights activist.</s>

en: We're at the SEBIN headquarters and they deny having him [in custody there] #WhereIsLuisCarlos
yor: Àwa ní olú ilé iṣẹ́ẹ SEBIN headquarters àti pé wọ́n ní àwọn kò ní í [ní àhámọ́ àwọn] #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa.
mt0: <pad> We own the headquarters of SEBIN and they say they don't have it [in their hands] #NiboNiLuisCarlosWa</s>

en: [Update: they later confirmed Diaz was in custody]
yor: [Ìròyìn tí ó tẹ̀ wá lọ́wọ́: they wọ́n pàpà jẹ́wọ́ wípé [Diaz wà ní akolóo wọn]
mt0: <pad> [Reports: they all admitted that Diaz was in their household.</s>

yor: Akọ̀ròyìn Vladimir Villegas sọ wípé kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ mọ́ wípé ìjọba ni ó fi ọwọ́ agbára mú u:
mt0: <pad> The journalist Vladimir Villegas said he did not believe the government had arrested him.</s>

en: We've been informed that @Unionradionet journalist Luis Carlos Díaz, has been detained by State's security forces.
yor: radionet Luis Carlos Díaz, ti wà nínú àtìmọ́lé agbófinró Ìlú.
mt0: <pad> Luis Carlos Díaz, a journalist at radionet, has been in custody at the city's mayoral office.</s>

yor: A bá a kẹ́dùn ipò tí ó wà.

en: We demand any information of his whereabouts and respect for his human rights.
yor: A béèrè fún ìtọ́sọ́nà nípa mímọ ibi tí ó wà, àti ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn-an rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> He asked for assurances about his location, and respect for his human rights.</s>

en: The Global Voices community stands in solidarity with Luis Carlos, his family, and all other independent journalists working to hold power to account in Venezuela.
yor: Ẹgbẹ́ Ohùn Àgbáyé dúró ṣinṣin pẹ̀lú Luis Carlos, ẹbíi rẹ̀, àti oníròyìn aládàáṣiṣẹ́ gbogbo àwọn tí ó ń mú ìjọba ṣe bí ó ti yẹ ní Venezuela.
mt0: <pad> World Voices stand firm with Luis Carlos, his family, and the brave journalists of all the people who are fighting for a fair government in Venezuela.</s>

en: We wish for his safe and speedy return, and will continue to update this story as it develops.

mt0: <pad> We hope you will be well soon in both body and spirit, we will post further information about this as it comes to hand.</s>

en: Nigeria's social media bill will obliterate online freedom of expression
yor: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà yóò pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà
mt0: <pad> The bill to ban internet freedom in Nigeria will block the use of mobile phone services.</s>

en: The draconian bill will legalize internet shutdowns in Nigeria
yor: Ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò fi àṣẹ fún ìṣánpa ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní Nàìjíríàj
mt0: <pad> The bill will legalize the use of internet services in Nigeria.</s>

en: Senator Mohammed Sani Musa is the sponsor of the social media bill. Screenshot from Channel Television You Tube video.
yor: Aṣojú Mohammed Sani Musa ni agbátẹrùu ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà. Àwòrán àgékù láti ibùdó Channel Television You Tube .
mt0: <pad> Dr. Mohammed Sani Musa is the author of the bill to ban the use of mobile phones. The video was taken from Channel TV You Tube.</s>

en: On November 20, the Protection from Internet Falsehoods and Manipulation of other Related Matters Bill 2019, known as the "social media bill", sponsored by Senator Mohammed Sani Musa, sailed through a second reading.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 20 oṣù Belu, Ìwé Àbádòfin tí ó fi Ààbò fún Irọ́ àti Màkàrúrù tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ ọn ti ọdún-un 2019, tí a mọ̀ sí "ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà", tí Aṣojú kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Mohammed Sani Musa ṣe agbátẹrùu rẹ̀, ti di kíkà nínú ìgbìmọ̀ fún ìgbà kejì.
mt0: <pad> On 20th of July, the Bill on Protection of Information and Privacy of 2019, known as the "mobile phone bill", which was proposed by a Member Mohammed Sani Musa, has been passed by the Committee for the second time.</s>

en: The social media bill aims to curb online falsehoods and mis- and disinformation.
yor: Èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà ni láti dẹ́kun àwọn àhesọ àti gbólóhùn tí kì í ṣe òtítọ́ lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere.
mt0: <pad> The purpose of the bill is to stop rumors and misinformation about social media as a sport.</s>

en: However, the real intent is not regulation, but rather, the annihilation of online freedom of expression, criminalization of government criticism and legalization of internet shutdowns in Nigeria.
yor: Bí-ó-ti-lẹ̀-jẹ́-wípé, kì í ṣe láti fi òfin de ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà ni ìwé àbádòfin náà dá lé lórí, àmọ́ ṣá, ó máa pa òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ lórí ayélujára, ìsọ alátakò ìjọba di ọ̀daràn àti fífi àtìpà ẹ̀rọ ayélujára fúngbà díẹ̀ sínú ìwé òfin.
mt0: <pad> Although the bill is not intended to ban cell phone use, it will restrict internet freedom, make government communications illegal and introduce some Internet service provider content into the bill.</s>

en: A similar bill was beaten dead in its track in 2016.
yor: Àtẹ̀pa bí erín bá tẹ koríko ni àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà tẹ irú ìwé àbádòfin báyìí pa ní ọdún-un 2016.
mt0: <pad> Before the constitutional referendum, Nigerians had voted for such a bill in 2016.</s>

en: Any form of government criticism is a crime
yor: Ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ni bí o bá gbó ìjọba lẹ́nu (tako ìjọba)
mt0: <pad> Crime is when you insult the government (the government).</s>

en: This bill aims to "[prevent] the transmission of false statements or declaration of facts in Nigeria", according to Section 1a.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 1A ti ṣe ṣàlàyé, èròńgbà ìwé àbádòfin yìí ni láti "[máà jẹ́] kí ìgbéjáde ọ̀rọ̀ tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan nínú tàbí èyí tí ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ kò f'ẹsẹ̀ rinlẹ̀ tó ó jáde ní Nàìjíríà".
mt0: <pad> As defined in Article 1A, the purpose of this bill is to "[prevent] the publication of false or unsubstantiated statements or reports in Nigeria."</s>

en: It will ban the dissemination statements likely to be "prejudicial" to Nigeria, including subjects like public health, public safety, "public tranquility or public finances" and Nigeria's "friendly relations with other countries".
yor: Yóò yọ ọwọ́ kílàńkó àwọn àtẹ̀jáde irọ́ tí ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà sí "ìyọnu", láwo láì gbàgbée àwọn ọ̀ràn bíi ètò ìlera gbogboògbò, ààbòo gbogboògbò, "ìbalẹ̀-ọkàn-an gbogboògbò tàbí ìṣúná owóo gbogboògbò" àti "àwọn ìbáṣepọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà pẹ̀lú àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè mìíràn".
mt0: <pad> We will reject any propaganda that could lead Nigeria to "destruction", without forgetting the recommendations such as a national energy plan, national security, "national happiness or national prosperity" and "Nigeria's relations with other nations."</s>

en: The bill will also "detect, control and safeguard against coordinated misuse of online accounts and bots", according to Section 1c.
yor: Abala 1c sọ bí ìwé àbádòfin náà yóò ṣe "mú, ṣàkóso àti fi ààbò bo ìlònílòkulò àwọn ìṣàmúlò àti ẹ̀rọ adánìkanṣiṣẹ́ orí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára".
mt0: <pad> Article 1c states that the bill will "establish, manage and protect the interests of users and online services."</s>

en: In other words, everything is permissible to monitor and control in the proposed law — under the guise of fighting false information.
yor: Ní àlàyé síwájú sí i, kò sí ohun tí ojú òfin tuntun náà kò leè tó bí ó bá ti jẹ́ lórí ayélujára — lábẹ́ àbùradà à ń gbógun ti àhesọ àti irọ́ pọ́nbẹ́lẹ́.
mt0: <pad> In a preliminary description, there is nothing that the new law cannot cover if it's on the internet — under the guise of combating falsehoods and lies.</s>

en: The social media bill is omniscient since it will be binding for every Nigerian citizen, regardless of residence or geographic location, as long as the ambiguous "false statement of fact" is transmitted within the country.
yor: Ọ̀run ń ya bọ̀ ni ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà, kò yọ ẹnìkan sílẹ̀, gbogbo ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà ni yóò bá, kò kan agbègbè tàbí ibi tí ènìyàn fi ṣe ibùgbé, máà ṣe é l'oògùn máà mọ́, ọwọ́ àwọn ológìnní ojú tólé ojú tóko ni "gbólóhùn irọ́ tí kò ní ẹ̀rí" tí ó bá gba òpópónà ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere Nàìjíríà yóò bọ́ sí.
mt0: <pad> The bill doesn't exclude anybody, it will affect every Nigerian, no matter where or where you live, make it a drug, hand the military face to face as "false statements" if you get a network like Nigeria's broadcasting network as an international trade network, they will return to the Nigerian market.</s>

en: Section 3a to b(i) of the social media bill states that:
yor: Abala 3a sí b(i) ti ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà sọ wípé:
mt0: <pad> Section 3a to b(i) of the Mobile Phone Use Act states that:</s>

en: A person must not do any act in or outside Nigeria in order to transmit in Nigeria a statement knowing or having reasons to believe that it is a false statements of fact; and the transmission of the statement in Nigeria is likely to be, prejudicial to the security of Nigeria or any part of Nigeria.
yor: Ẹnikẹ́ni kò gbọdọ̀ wu ìwà kíwà kan nínú tàbí lẹ́yìn odi Nàìjíríà láti tari gbólóhùn tí kò ní òtítọ́ kan tí a kò leè fi ẹ̀ríi rẹ̀ múlẹ̀ síta; àti àgbésórí afẹ́fẹ́ ayélujára gbólóhùn t'ó lè kó orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà síta bí ọmọ ọjọ́ mẹ́jọ nípa ti ààbò ìlú.
mt0: <pad> No one should engage in any act within or outside Nigeria to propagate unsubstantiated statements that cannot be verified; and the dissemination of online statements that can potentially denigrate Nigeria as a young child in relation to urban protection.</s>

en: The nebulous "national security" excuse is used to justify the trumping of free expression.
yor: Ọ̀ràn-an ti "ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè" ni orí Èṣù tí òfin náà dúró lé láti pa ẹ̀tọ́ sí òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ mọ́.
mt0: <pad> The doctrine of "national security" is the Satanic principle that the law was based on to ban the right to free speech.</s>

en: But it does not stop there, the Nigerian government is always right and cannot be criticized.
yor: Àmọ́ kò tán síbẹ̀, kò sí ẹní tó lè tako ìjọba Nàìjíríà tàbí gbó o lẹ́nu nítorí kì í ṣ'àṣìṣe.
mt0: <pad> But beyond that, no one can challenge the Nigerian government or prosecute it because it is not a criminal organization.</s>

en: According to Section 3b(vi), any statement that diminishes “public confidence in the performance of any duty or function of, in the exercise of any power of the government” is prohibited.
yor: Ní Abala 3b(vi), gbólóhùn tí ó bá yẹpẹrẹ “ojúṣe tàbí ìṣe, tí ó jẹ́ ti ìjọba lójú ará ìlú” kò leè la orí ayélujára kọjá.
mt0: <pad> In Article 3b(vi), statements that describe "governmental functions or activities, which are publicly available" cannot be posted online except by email.</s>

en: According to Section 3b(v), this applies to any statement that: "incites feelings of enmity, hatred, directed at persons or ill-will between different groups of persons".
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abala 3b(v) ti ṣe fi hàn, èyí ní í ṣe pẹ̀lú gbólóhùn tí ó: "fa ìmúnilọ́tàá, tí a sọ sí ẹnìkan tàbí ìtara láàárín àwọn ènìyàn".
mt0: <pad> As defined in Article 3b(v), this is done by statements that: "cause embarrassment, which are made to one or more of the people, either individually or in a group."</s>

en: This is dangerous because it leaves regulators open to contradictory interpretations that could be abused by political actors.
yor: Èyí léwu nítorí ó fi àyè gba àwọn onípò àṣẹ láti lo agbára nílòkulò.
mt0: <pad> This is dangerous because it allows the power-brokers to use excessive power.</s>

en: Who defines and approves what incites feelings of hatred?
yor: Ta ní í sọ bóyá gbólóhùn kan lè fa rògbòdìyàn?
mt0: <pad> I wonder if a statement can make radio audiences</s>

en: It means that seeking transparency or even daring to hold a politician accountable could be declared hateful.
yor: Ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wípé lílo inú kan tàbí mímú àwọn olóṣèlúu mú ìléríi wọn ṣe lè já sí ìkórìíra lójúu wọn.
mt0: <pad> That means that the use of a single word or phrase by politicians to refer to their authority can lead to a criminal prosecution.</s>

en: The punishment upon conviction for any provisions of the bill is a fine that ranges between 200,000 and 10 million naira [about $556 to $28,000 United States dollars], imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years or both.
yor: Owó ìtanràn fún ẹni tí ilé ẹjọ́ bá dá lẹ́bi tó láàárín ẹgbẹ̀rún 200 àti ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 10 owó naira [tí ó tó $556 sí $28,000 owó orílẹ̀ èdèe United States], ìtìmọ́lé fún ọdún mẹ́ta tàbí méjèèjì.
mt0: <pad> The indemnity fee for the accused is between 200 and 10,000 naira [US$556 to $28,000], a bail of three or four years, and a parole period of one to two years.</s>

en: Police licensed to shut down the internet
yor: Àṣẹ fún Àjọ Agbófinró láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélujára pa fúngbà díẹ̀
mt0: <pad> Permission for the police to access the internet was issued just days ago.</s>

en: The social media bill also grants the government unlimited power to switch off the internet, through the "Access Blocking Order" as contained in Section 12, number 3:
yor: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà fún ìjọba lágbára bí ó ṣe hù wọ́n láti ṣán ẹ̀rọ ayélukára bí ajere pa nígbàkúùgbà tí ó bá lérò wípé ó tọ́, nípasẹ̀ "Àṣẹ Ìdígàgá Ìráyè" láti lo ayélujára bí ó ti ṣe wà ní Abala 12, òǹkaye 3:
mt0: <pad> The bill gives the government power to control the Internet as a criminal weapon whenever it feels right, through the "Right to Free Use" of the Internet as it was passed on March 12, at 3 p.m.</s>

en: The Law Enforcement Department may direct the NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – the regulatory agency for the telecommunication industry] to order the internet access service provider to take reasonable steps to disable access by end-users in Nigeria.
yor: Ẹ̀ka Agbófinró leè fi àṣẹ fún Àjọ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Nàìjíríà NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – tí ó ń ṣe bòńkárí ìtàkùrọ̀sọ orí ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá] láti pa á láṣẹ fún apèsè àyè sí ìlò ẹ̀rọ ayélujára kí ó gbé ìgbésẹ̀ lójú ẹsẹ̀ tí ò ní mú àwọn òǹlò rí àyè lo ayélujára ní Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> The Ministry of Law can order the Nigerian Communications Commission NCC [Nigerian Communications Commission – the regulator of mobile communication] to ban internet access and take action to ensure that users have access to the Internet in Nigeria.</s>

en: Internet service providers must comply with this blocking order or risk upon conviction a fine within the range of 5 to 10 million naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].
yor: Àwọn apèsè ayélujára gbọdọ̀ tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá yìí tàbí kí wọ́n ó sanwó ìtanràn tí ó tó ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 5 sí 10 owó naira [$14,000-28,000 USD].
mt0: <pad> Web sites must comply with this regulation or face fines of up to N5,000-N10,000 ($14,000-$28,000 USD).</s>

en: In addition, the bill under consideration indemnifies the internet service providers from any "civil or criminal liability" incurred from a lawsuit brought against them for "complying to any access blocking order", according to section 12, number 5.
yor: Ní àfikún, ìwé àbádòfin náà fi àrídájú ààbò bo àwọn apèsè iṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ ayélujára tí kò ní mú wàhálà "ará ìlú tàbí bẹ́ẹ̀ " tí kò bá à lè jáde láti ìdájọ́ kan tí ẹnikẹ́ni kò bá pè wọ́n fúnopé "wọ́n tẹ̀lé òfin ìdígàgá ìráyé" sí ayélujára, ìyẹn bí abala 12, òǹkaye 5 ṣe fi lélẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> In addition, the bill guarantees protection for non-commercial internet services that do not engage in "commercial or otherwise" censorship and cannot be sued unless anyone has called them to "comply with the Internet Privacy Act," as provided in Section 12, paragraph 5.</s>

en: The human rights violations get murkier because the law grants the police a legal license to command an access-blocking order at whim.
yor: Ìtẹ́rí ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn náà ṣ'ókùnkùn sí i nítorí wípé òfin náà gba àwọn ọlọ́pàá láyè lábẹ́ òfin láti pa àṣẹ ìdígàgá-àyè bí ó ti ṣe hù wọ́n.
mt0: <pad> Human rights violations were linked to the law because it allowed police under the law to revoke building permits as they were threatened.</s>

en: Section 15a states that only the "initiative" of the police in face of "overwhelming sufficing evidence" is needed to cancel an internet shutdown in the country.
yor: Abala 15a sọ wípé “iṣẹ́ ọpọlọ” ọlọ́pàá ní àsìkò "ìṣèwádìí ẹ̀rí tó dájú" jẹ́ kókó láti fagilé ìṣánpá ẹ̀rọ ayélujára ní orílẹ̀ èdè náà.
mt0: <pad> Article 15a says that police "brainstorming" during "credible investigation" is necessary to prevent internet piracy in the country.</s>

en: Consequently, "no appeal may be made to the High Court" [Section 13(2)] by any party to revoke such a ban without first applying to the police to revoke an existing blocking order.
yor: Ní ìparí, “kò sí àyè fún ẹjọ́ọ kò tèmi lọ́rùn ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga” [Abala 13(2)] tí eẹnikẹ́ni lè fi yẹ ìdígàgá sílẹ̀ láì máà kọ́kọ́ tọ ọlọ́pàá lọ láti fagilé òfin ìdígàgá náà.
mt0: <pad> Finally, "there is no immediate right to sue in the High Court" [Article 13(2)] that any person can use to terminate a building without first going to the police to challenge the legality of the building.</s>

en: The implications of this are obvious — no one can resort to the courts for redress in the face of this violation while the blocking order persists.
yor: Ipa èyí hàn gbàgàdà — ẹnikẹ́ni kò ní leè gba ilé ẹjọ́ lọ fún ìgbèjà ìfẹ̀tọ́ ẹni dunni yìí tí ìdígàgá náà ṣì wà.
mt0: <pad> This is clearly a mistake — no one can sue for this violation of privacy while the restrictions are in place.</s>

en: The lawmakers behind the social media bill
yor: Àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin tí ó wà lẹ́yìn ìwé àbádòfin ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà
mt0: <pad> The lawyers who backed the bill</s>

en: Three lawmakers seem to be the arrowhead of the bill in the Senate, the upper house of Nigeria’s parliament: Mohammed Sani Musa (the sponsor of the bill), Abba Moro and Elisha Abbo.
yor: Àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin mẹ́ta kan ni ó gbé ìwé àbádòfin náà sórí nínú ìgbìmọ̀, ilé ìgbìmọ̀ àgbà: Mohammed Sani Musa (agbátẹrùu ìwé àbádòfin), Abba Moro àti Elisha Abbo.
mt0: <pad> Three senators took the bill to the House of Representatives, Senate: Mohammed Sani Musa (the author of the bill), Abba Moro and Elisha Abbo.</s>

en: Mohammed Sani Musa’s company, Activate Technologies Limited, supplied the Permanent Voter Cards (PVCs) machine used for the 2019 general elections, while he was the candidate of the ruling All Progressives Congress (APC) for Niger East Senatorial district, according to the investigate outlet, Premium Times.
yor: Ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ Mohammed Sani Musa, Activate Technologies Limited, ni ó kó ẹ̀rọ Ìwé-pélébé Ìdìbò Alálòpẹ́ (PVCs) tí a lò fún ìbò ọdún-un 2019, nígbà tí ó jẹ́ òǹdíjedupò lábẹ́ ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu tí ó ń tukọ̀ ètò ìṣèlú lọ́wọ́ All Progressives Congress (APC) fún Aṣojú Ìlà-Oòrùn Niger, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ilé iṣẹ́ aṣèwádìí, Premium Times ṣe tẹ̀ ẹ́ jáde.
mt0: <pad> The Mohammed Sani Musa's company, Activate Technologies Limited, manufactured the European Voting Certificates (PVCs) used in the 2019 general election while he was a candidate for the All Progressives Congress (APC) parliamentary candidate for the East Niger State, according to a report by the research newspaper, Premium Times.</s>

en: This is an allegation that the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) admitted.
yor: Àjọ Elétò (INEC) gba ẹ̀sùn náà mọ́ra.
mt0: <pad> The National Electricity Corporation (INEC) has accepted the charges.</s>

en: Musa’s conflict of interest raised some doubts about the true independence of Nigeria’s election umpire in the last election.
yor: Ọ̀ràn yìí fi hàn pé àwọn alákòóso ìbò tí ó kọjá kò ṣiṣẹ́ láì lọ́wọ́ àwọn alágbára ń'nú.
mt0: <pad> This shows that the previous election commissions did not work without the help of the internal powers.</s>

en: Ishaku Elisha Abbo of the opposition People’s Democratic Party (PDP) is a senator representing the Adamawa North Senatorial District in Adamawa State, in northeast Nigerian.
yor: Ishaku Elisha Abbo ti ẹgbẹ́ alátakò People’s Democratic Party (PDP) jẹ́ aṣojú tí ó ń ṣojú Ẹkùn-un Àríwá Adamawa ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Adamawa, ní ìlà-oòrùn àríwá orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> Ishaku Elisha Abbo of the opposition People's Democratic Party (PDP) is a member of the Adamawa North District in the state of Adamawa, north-eastern Nigeria.</s>

en: In July 2019, in the presence of a police officer, Abbo assaulted a female staff member in an adult sex toy store in Abuja.
yor: Nínú oṣù Agẹmọ 2019, ní ìṣojú ọlọ́pàá, Abbo ṣe àṣemáṣe pẹ̀lú òṣìṣẹ́bìnrin kan nínú ìsọ̀ ohun ìbálòpọ̀ ní olú-ìlú Nàìjíríà ní Abuja.
mt0: <pad> In August 2019, under police supervision, Abbo had an affair with a waitress in a brothel in the capital of Nigeria, Abuja.</s>

en: After a video of the assault went viral on social media, Abbo offered a public apology.
yor: Lẹ́yìn tí àwòrán càṣemáṣe náà fọ́n ká sórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà, Abbo offered mọ ìwàa rẹ̀ lẹ́bí, ó sì bẹ̀bẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> After the photo of the stunt went viral on his phone, Abbo offered to know his family and then there.</s>

en: Abba Moro, also with the PDP, is the senator representing Benue South district, northcentral Nigeria.
yor: Abba Moro, tí í ṣe ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ẹ PDP, ni aṣojú fún ẹ̀ka Gúúsù Benue, àárín gbùngbùn àríwá Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> Abba Moro, a member of the PDP, is the representative for the North Benue Zone, in the north-eastern Nigerian state of Benue.</s>

en: On March 15, 2014, Moro, as minister of interior, was responsible for the Nigerian Immigration Recruitment tragedy in which about 6 million Nigerian youths who applied for 4,000 vacant positions in Nigerian Immigration Service were forced to assemble in various recruitment locations in the country.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 15, oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, ọdún-un 2014, Moro, tí í ṣe ọ̀gá pátápátá ètò abélé, ló wà nídìí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ abanilọ́kànjẹ́ Ìgbanisíṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí àwọn ọ̀dọ́langba tí ó tó bíi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 6 tó fẹ́ àyè iṣẹ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún 4 tí ó ṣí sílẹ̀ nínú iléeṣẹ́ Ẹ̀ṣọ̀ Aṣọ́bodè Nàìjíríà tí wọ́n kóra jọ níbi orísìírísìí jákèjádò orílẹ̀ èdè náà.
mt0: <pad> On 15th January 2014, Moro, the national coordinator of the peace initiative, was at the center of the Nigerian Security Service protests by about 65,000 applicants for the 44,000 vacant jobs in the Nigerian Security Service.</s>

en: The resulting stampede due to overcrowding led to about 20 deaths and multiple injuries.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ tí ó burúkú jáì náà tí ó ṣekú pa ogún ènìyàn àti ìpalára fún ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn.
mt0: <pad> The horrific accident killed four people and injured many others.</s>

en: Moro was a recipient of part of the application fees paid by the job-seekers amounting to 675 million naira [about $1.8 million USD].
yor: Moro gbà nínú of owó ìwáṣẹ̀ tí àwọn awáṣẹ́ san tí ó ń lọ bíi ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 675 owóo naira [ $1.8 USD].
mt0: <pad> Moro received a fine of about N675, 000 (US$1.8) from the authorities.</s>

en: Moro not only enriched himself but also bypassed the extant procurement laws for the Immigration Service.
yor: Moro kó owó sápòo rẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ó fo òfin ìgbanǹkan Aṣọ́bodè dá.
mt0: <pad> Moro took his own money and violated the Constitution of the Republic of Zimbabwe.</s>

en: "No need for silence, fear or self-pity" – #SayNoToSocialMediaBill!
yor: "Kò nílò ìdákẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́, ìbẹ̀rù bojo tàbí ìkáàánú-araẹni" – #SayNoToSocialMediaBill!
mt0: <pad> "There is no need for anxiety, fear or resentment" – #SayNoToSocialMediaBill</s>

en: Using the hashtag #SayNoToSocialMediaBill, Nigerian netizens took to Twitter to express their collective indignation:
yor: Nípa lílo àmì #SayNoToSocialMediaBill, àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára orílẹ̀ èdèe Nàìjíríà bọ́ sóríi Twitter láti sọ èrò ọkàn-an wọn:
mt0: <pad> Through the hashtag #SayNoToSocialMediaBill, Nigerian internet users took to Twitter to express their discontent with the proposed bill.</s>

en: In a statement, Amnesty International condemned the use of "laws to justify human rights violations" because it will not only stop Nigerians "from speaking their minds" but will also "send them to jail for doing so".
yor: Nínú gbólóhùn kan, Amnesty International fajúro sí lílo "àwọn òfin tí ó ń fìdìí ìfojú ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn gbolẹ̀ múlẹ̀ " nítorí pé kò ní pa àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà lẹ́nu mọ́ "láti máà sọ èrò ọkàn-an wọn" tí yóò sì tún "rán wọn lọ s'ẹ́wọ̀n fún wípé wọ́n ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ ".
mt0: <pad> In a statement, Amnesty International refused to use "anti-human rights legislation" because it would not prevent Nigerians from "expressing their opinion" and "sending them to jail for doing so."</s>

en: The parliament, under the pretext of curbing mis- and disinformation, is considering the enactment of a draconian law.
yor: Lábẹ́ àbùradà à ń dẹ́kun gbólóhùn irọ́ àti ọ̀rọ̀ àhesọ, ń gbèrò ìṣòfin tí kò ní ìfẹ́ ará ìlú lọ́kàn.
mt0: <pad> Under the colonialism we suppressed lies and rumors, passed unpopular laws that did not serve the people.</s>

en: Ironically, the greatest propagators of false information online are political actors.
yor: Ó jẹ́ ohun ìyàlẹ́nu, àwọn olóṣèlúu ló léwájú níbi ká gbé gbólóhùn irọ́ sórí ayélujára.
mt0: <pad> It is interesting that politicians are the frontrunners in posting lies on the internet.</s>

en: Both Nigeria's ruling and main opposition parties turned Twitter into a minefield of ethnic hate speech, disinformation and propaganda during the 2019 presidential elections.
yor: Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu tí ó ń jẹ lọ́wọ́ àti ẹgbẹ́ alátakò gbòógì sọ Twitter di pápá ogun fa ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá, ìròyìn tí kò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀tàn lásìkò ìdìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019.
mt0: <pad> The political parties and the opposition parties have made Twitter a battlefield for sexism, fake news and history during the 2019 presidential election.</s>

en: Read more:
yor: Kà síwájú sí i:
mt0: <pad> You don't know</s>

en: Social media propelled ethnocentric disinformation and propaganda during the Nigerian elections
yor: Ẹ̀rọ alátagbà fa ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹlẹ́yàmẹ́lẹ́yá, ìròyìn tí kò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀tàn lásìkò ìdìbò ààrẹ ọdún-un 2019
mt0: <pad> The smartphones became the focus of controversy, misinformation and history during the 2019 presidential election.</s>

en: Twitter was a minefield of false information during the 2019 Nigerian elections
yor: Twitter di pápá ogun fún gbólóhùn irọ́ lásìkò ìdìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ọdún-un 2019
mt0: <pad> Twitter is a frontline for trolling during the 2019 Nigerian presidential election.</s>

en: In these troubling times of freedom of expression in Nigeria, the wise charge from American writer Toni Morrison evokes hope:
yor: Ní àkókò bíi ti òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní Nàìjíríà tí a wà yìí, ọ̀rọ̀ ọlọ́pọlọ láti ẹnu òǹkọ̀wé orílẹ̀-èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Toni Morrison tí ó mú ìrétí dání:
mt0: <pad> In the age of free speech in Nigeria, a famous quote from American author Toni Morrison which captured my attention when I read it on the radio.</s>

en: This is precisely the time when artists go to work. There is no time for despair, no place for self-pity, no need for silence, no room for fear.
yor: ‎Èyí ni ìgbà tí àwọn ayàwòrán ń ṣiṣẹ́. Kò sáyé fún ìsọ̀rètínù, kò sáyé fún ìkáàánú-ara, kò nílò ìdákẹ́ jẹ́jẹ́, kò sí àyè fún ìbẹ̀rù bojo.
mt0: <pad> This is when the photographers work. No room for regret, no room for compassion, no need for a heavy hand, no room for fear of death.</s>

en: We speak, we write, we do language.
yor: A sọ, a kọ, a p'èdè.
mt0: <pad> They say, they write, they speak.</s>

en: The bill is currently at its second reading in the Senate. To become law, it will need to move to committee stage where legislators will review it.
yor: Ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà ti jẹ́ kíkà ní ìgbà kejì nínú ìgbìmọ̀ Aṣojú-ṣòfin.
mt0: <pad> The bill on the use of mobile phones has been passed by the House of Representatives for the second time.</s>

en: The committee presents its report to Parliament, the bill is debated, a clean copy is re-presented to the Senate for a final vote and then, there's the presidential assent.
yor: Kí ó tó di òfin, ó gbọdọ̀ gba ìgbìmọ̀ kan tí àwọn aṣojú-ṣòfin yóò yẹ̀ ẹ́ wò. Ìgbìmọ̀ọtẹ̀ẹ́kótó náà yóò sì jábọ̀ àbájáde àyẹ̀wòo rẹ̀ fún Ìgbìmọ̀ àgbà, láti gbé e yẹ̀ wò, tí wọn yóò tẹ òmíràn jáde fún àyẹ̀wò tí ó kẹ́yìn, kí ààrẹ ó tó bu ọwọ́ lù ú.
mt0: <pad> Before it can be made a law, it must be examined by a legislative commission. The commission will report its report to the House of Representatives for review, and then it will be sent to the Senate for final review, before the president can sign it.</s>

en: The Parliament must be hard-pressed to throw out the social media bill in its entirety.
yor: A gbọdọ̀ fajú ro sí ìgbésẹ̀ Ìgbìmọ̀ kí wọ́n ba ju ìwé àbádòfin ìlò ẹ̀rọ alátagbà náà dànù sígbó.
mt0: <pad> We need to see the Committee's action before the bill is approved.</s>

en: This is because Africa’s most populous country will slide smoothly into full dictatorship once freedom of expression has been extinguished.
yor: Nítorí orílẹ̀ èdèe tí ó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ yóò yẹ̀ gẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ìjọba ìfipámúnisìn ní kété tí òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ bá di títẹ̀ bọlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> Because the most popular language in Africa will be heading for a communist state soon as the power of speech begins to decline.</s>

en: Tanzania high court upholds ruling to end child marriage despite attempts to repeal it
yor: Ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania pa á láṣẹ fún ìfòpinsí ìsoyìgì láàárín àgbàlagbà àti ọmọdé láì wo ti ìgbésẹ̀ ìmúpadàa rẹ̀
mt0: <pad> The Tanzanian Supreme Court has banned the rape of an adult and a child without considering his revocation.</s>

en: "This is the best decision the court has ever made"
yor: "Èyí ni ìpinnu tí ó dára jù lọ tí ilé-ẹjọ́ yóò ṣe"
mt0: <pad> "This is the best decision a court can make."</s>

en: Schoolgirls in Tanzania pose for a photo on July 10, 2007. Photo by Fanny Schertzer, used with permission via Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
yor: Àwọn Ọmọiléèwé ọmọdébìnrin ní Tanzania dúró fún àwòrán lọ́jọ́ 10 oṣù Agẹmọ ọdún-un, 2007. Fanny Schertzer ni ó ya àwòrán, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ láti Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.
mt0: <pad> Girls in Tanzania standing for a photo on 10 August 2007. Fanny Schertzer took the photo, used with permission from Wikimedia Commons, CC BY 2.0.</s>

en: In October 2019, Tanzania's high court upheld the landmark 2016 ruling that increased the minimum age of marriage for girls and boys to 18.
yor: Nínú oṣù Ọ̀wàrà 2019, ilé ẹjọ́ gíga Tanzania ṣe ìdímú ṣinṣin ìdájọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí ó pàṣẹ ó kéré jù, ọmọbìnrin àti ọmọkùnrin gbọdọ̀ pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún kí ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó.
mt0: <pad> In August 2019, the Tanzanian Supreme Court upheld a 2016 ruling that required at least, girls and boys to be 18 years old before marrying.</s>

en: The Tanzanian government attempted to repeal this decision, claiming that girls mature earlier and marriage is a form of protection for pregnant young women, and should, therefore, be allowed to marry earlier than 18.
yor: Àjọ ọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania gbéègbésẹ̀ láti ṣe ìmúpadà ìpinnu yìí, nítorí wípé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin ń yára bàlágà àti wípé ààbò ni ìgbéyàwó jẹ́ fún ọ̀dọ́bìnrin aláboyún.
mt0: <pad> The Tanzanian Royal Society has tried to change this decision, because girls are getting stronger and that marriage is a protection for young girls.</s>

en: But on October 23, 2019, the Tanzanian government lost its appeal and the high court ruling remains: The marriage age for both males and females is 18, reinforcing the ban on child marriage in Tanzania.
yor: Àmọ́ ní ọjọ́ 23 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019, ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe Tanzania pàdánù ẹjọ́ọ kòtẹ́milọ́rùnun rẹ̀ tí àṣẹ ilé ẹjọ́ gíga ṣì dúró: akọ àtabo gbọdọ̀ pé ọjọ́ orí méjìdínlógún kí wọn ó tó ṣe ìgbéyàwó, tí èyí sì ń fi agbára kún ìgbẹ́sẹ̀ ìsoyìgì ọmọdé ní Tanzania.
mt0: <pad> But on October 23, 2019, the Tanzanian government lost its key legal battle against the High Court ruling: men and women must be 18 years old before marrying, which strengthens the fight against childbirth in Tanzania.</s>

en: According to the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), Tanzania has one of the highest prevalence rates of child marriage in the world.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA) ti ṣe wí, Tanzania ni ìsoyìgì ọmọdé pọ̀ sí jù lọ lágbàáyé.

en: Gyumi is the founder and executive director of Msichana Initiative (Young Woman Initiative), a Tanzanian nongovernmental organization that empowers girls through education.
yor: Gyumi ni olùdásílẹ̀ àti alákòóso àgbà Msichana Initiative (Ètò fún àwọn Ọ̀dọ́mọbìnrin), iléeṣẹ́ tí kì í ṣe tìjọba tí ó ń ró àwọn ọmọdébìnrin lágbára nípasẹ̀ ti ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé.

en: In 2016, Gyumi challenged the constitutionality of the Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) that allowed females under the age of 18 to get married.
yor: Lọ́dún-un 2016, Gyumi na ọwọ́ ìka àbùkù sí agbára Òfin Ìgbéyàwó; Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) tí ó gba obìnrin tí kò tó ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún láyè láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó.
mt0: <pad> In 2016, Gyumi signed the Law of Marriage Act, 2002 (LMA) which gives women under 18 years of age the right to marry.</s>

en: According to Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS),  36 percent of women aged 25-49 get married before their 18th birthday compared to only 5 percent for men the same age.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí nípa ìlera Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS) ṣe ti ṣàlàyé, ìdá 36 obìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọ́n wà ní 25-49 ní í ṣe ìgbéyàwó kí wọn ó tó pé ọmọ ọdún méjìdínlógún, tí àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ wọn lọ́kùnrin sí jẹ́ ìdá 5.
mt0: <pad> According to the Tanzania Demographic and Health Survey (TDHS), 36 percent of women aged 25-49 got married before they reached 16, while their male counterparts were only 16 percent.</s>

en: The LMA allowed girls as young as 14 to get married with consent from a court and age 15 with the consent of the parents whereas 18 years was the minimum age for a male.
yor: Òfin LMA fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin tí ọjọ́ oríi wọn kò ju ọdún mẹ́rìnlá lọ láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó pẹ̀lú ìlọ́wọ́sí ilé-ẹjọ́, ìlọ́wọ́sí òbí fún ọmọ ọdún márùn-ún-dínlógún, nígbà tí ọdún méjìdínlógún jẹ́ ọjọ́ orí tí ó kéré jù lọ fún ọmọkùnrin.
mt0: <pad> The LMA law allows girls under the age of 15 to marry with court approval, parental consent for children under 16, and 14 is the minimum age for men.</s>

en: Through her attorneys, Gyumi argued that the LMA provisions were discriminatory for giving preferential treatment to males in the matter of eligible marriage age.
yor: Nípasẹ̀ àwọn aṣojú rẹ̀, Gyumi ṣàlàyé wípé àlàálẹ̀ LMA kọ iyán obìnrin kéré nítorí pé ó fún àwọn ọkùnrin ní àǹfààní ju àwọn obìnrin lọ.
mt0: <pad> Through his representatives, Gyumi stated that the LMA system had been rejected by women because it gave men more advantages than women.</s>

en: They further argued that the provisions infringed the right to equality and they were too vague and too susceptible to arbitrary interpretation to deny female children their right to education.
yor: Nítẹ̀síwájú, wọ́n sọ wípé àlàálẹ̀ náà fi ẹ̀tọ́ dídọ́gba ọmọ ènìyàn yí ẹrẹ̀fọ̀ àti pé wọn fi ẹ̀tọ́ àǹfààní sí ẹ̀kọ́ ìwé dun àwọn ọmọdébìnrin.
mt0: <pad> They also said that the bill would violate human rights and deprive girls of the right to education.</s>

en: Gyumi petitioned the High Court to find the provisions of LMA null and void.
yor: Gyumi rọ Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga láti gbé àlàálẹ̀ LMA tì sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.
mt0: <pad> Gyumi asked the High Court to lift the LMA's ban.</s>

en: The High Court never declared the provisions in the LMA null and void.
yor: Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga kò ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> The Supreme Court didn't do that.</s>

en: But they found the provisions unconstitutional and gave the government one year to correct the anomalies in the LMA provisions.
yor: Àmọ́ wọ́n rí i lóòótọ́ wípé kò bá òfin mu wọ́n sì fún ìjọba lọ́dún kan láti ṣe àtúnṣe sí ohun tí kò tọ̀nà nínú àlàálẹ̀ LMA.
mt0: <pad> But they found it unlawful and gave the government a year to make amendments to the inadequacies of the LMA proposal.</s>

en: Through the attorney general, the government was directed to put 18 years as the eligible age of marriage for both females and males.
yor: Nípasẹ̀ aṣojú àgbà àwọn adájọ́, a pa ìjọba láṣẹ láti gbé ọjọ́ orí ìgbéyàwó sí ọdún méjìdínlógún fún obìnrin àti ọkùnrin.
mt0: <pad> By the Chief Justice, the government was ordered to lower the age of marriage to 18 for both men and women.</s>

en: However, then-Attorney General George Masaju was aggrieved by the ruling and immediately served a notice of appeal to the High Court:
yor: Síbẹ̀, aṣojú àgbà àná banújẹ́ sí ìdájọ́ náà ó sì kọ ìwé àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ sí Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga náà:
mt0: <pad> However, the chief prosecutor expressed displeasure with the verdict and wrote a reconsideration letter to the High Court.</s>

en: Grounds for appeal

en: In four months of court proceedings, the government sought to appeal the 2016 ruling that required the revision of the provisions LMA that allowed girls to be married at the age of 15.
yor: Láàárín oṣù mẹ́rin ìgbẹ́jọ́, ìjọba gbèrò láti ṣe àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ ọdún-un 2016 tí yó ṣe àtúnṣe sí àlàálẹ̀ LMA èyí tí ó fi àyè gba ọmọdébìnrin ọlọ́jọ́-orí márùn-úndínlógún gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹni tí ó ti bàlágà fún ìgbéyàwó.
mt0: <pad> In the four months of the assembly, the government agreed to make a 2016 re-election that would make amendments to the LMA provision that allowed a 16-year-old girl to be eligible for marriage.</s>

en: The appellant, represented by principal state attorneys, Mark Mulwambo and Alesia Mbuya, provided biological differences and customary and Islamic laws as grounds for the appeal.
yor: Atẹ́jọ́pè, tí ó jẹ́ aṣojú àwọn adájọ́ ìpínlẹ̀, Mark Mulwambo àti Alesia Mbuya, ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìyàtọ̀ ìwà ẹ̀dá obìnrin àti ọkùnrin tí wọ́n sì fi àṣà ìbílẹ̀ àti òfin ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle gbá àtúnpè-ẹjọ́ náà nídìí.
mt0: <pad> The judges, Mark Mulwambo and Alesia Mbuya, presented the gender differences and used culture and religion to argue for the retrial.</s>

en: Ms. Mbuya argued that biological differences put boys and girls in "different categories" and that therefore, the law treats them differently.
yor: Ms. Mbuya sọ wípé ìyàtọ̀ ìwà ẹ̀dá fi ọmọdékùnrin àti ọmọdébìnrin sí "ìsọ̀rí ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ " àti pé, òfin fi ojú ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ wò wọ́n.
mt0: <pad> Ms. Mbuya said that gender differences place men and women in "different categories" and that the law should treat them differently.</s>

en: She argued that because girls matured earlier, the law took that into consideration. She argued that marriage could protect unmarried girls who get pregnant at an early age.
yor: Ó sọ síwájú sí i wípé nítorí àwọn ọmọdébìnrin máa ń tètè bàlágà ju ọmọdékùnrin lọ ni òfin fi la àlàálẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀. Ó sọ wípé ìgbéyàwó lè fi ààbò bo ọmọdébìnrin tí kò sí nílé ọkọ tí ó ti di abaraméjì láì tó ọjọ́ orí tí ó tọ́.
mt0: <pad> He went on to say that the law was passed because girls are more likely to be pregnant than boys. He said that a couple can protect a girl who is already an adult before she reaches her full legal age.</s>

en: Further, she argued the court erred by “equating the age of the child and the age of marriage,” meaning that the court should consider male and female children differently when it comes to marriageable age.
yor: Ó sọ síwájú sí i wípé ilé ẹjọ́ kùnà bí ó ṣe “ṣe ìmúdọ́gbandọ́gba ọjọ́ orí ọmọ àti ọjọ́ orí tí ó yẹ fún ìgbéyàwó”, èyí tí ó túmọ̀ sí wípé ọ̀tọ̀ ni ti tọ́lú ọ̀tọ̀ ni ti tọ́lùú wò, ọ̀tọ̀ ni ó yẹ kí ilé ẹjọ́ ó là kalẹ̀ fún ọjọ́ orí ìgbéyàwó ọkùnrin àti obìnrin.
mt0: <pad> He went on to say that the court "misjudged the birth date and the proper wedding date", meaning that the right was violated, the right was abused, the right was wrongly established, the right was wrongly established for both men and women.</s>

en: Netizens were quick to criticize the grounds the appellant provided in court.
yor: Àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára ti yára bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lu ìdí tí àtẹ́jọ́pè fi sílẹ̀ nínú ìgbẹ́jọ́.
mt0: <pad> The internet has been abuzz with criticism of the judge's decision to drop the case.</s>

en: According to the United Nations, in order to achieve gender equality by 2030, governments need to change discriminatory laws and adopt legislation that proactively advances equality.

mt0: <pad> According to the UN, before we can achieve zero childbirth by 2030, governments have to change and implement separate legislation that will take into account the goals we are calling for.</s>

yor: Àbájáde ìwádìí ṣe àfihàn-an rẹ̀ wípé ọjọ́ orí tí ó tọ́ láti ṣe ìgbéyàwó bá ìpele ìwé tí ènìyàn kà àti ọrọ̀ tí ènìyán ti kó jọ (TDHS 201) tan.
mt0: <pad> The results of the study showed that the cutoff date for the marriage to the highest level of reading and knowledge (TDHS 201) was January 31,</s>

mt0: <pad> Childbirth offers protection to girls, regardless of how they get into school.</s>

en: In Tanzania, child marriage bars girls from education and leads to school dropout, according to data from the Tanzania National Survey, 2017).

mt0: <pad> In Tanzania, childbirth does not allow girls to continue their education and they do not have the chance to finish their studies, as a result of a survey by the Tanzania National Survey, 2017 recorded.</s>

en: This ban creates better conditions for schoolgirls to finish school without barriers.
yor: Ìfòfinde ìsoyìgì yìí ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìgbé ayé tó dára fún akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin láti parí ẹ̀kọ́ọ wọn láì sí ìdádúró.
mt0: <pad> This innovative approach provides a good environment for students to finish their studies without interruption.</s>

en: Even so, impregnated schoolgirls are still faced with an unconstitutional ruling that prohibits them from returning to school.
yor: Pẹ̀lú bẹ́ẹ̀, akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìnrin tí ó bá fẹ́rakù ṣì ń kojú òfin tí ó ní wọn kò gbọdọ̀ padà wá sílé ìwé.

en: American rapper Kanye West brought his "Sunday Service" pop-up concert to Kingston, Jamaica, at the start of its National Heroes Day holiday weekend (October 19-21, 2019).
yor: Ọ̀kọrin tàkasúfèé tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Amẹ́ríkà Kanye West gbé àríyá "Ìsìn Ọjọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀ " pop-up concert wá sí Kingston, Jamaica, ní kété tí ìsinmi ọjọ́ ọ̀sẹ̀ fún Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Àwọn Málegbàgbé Ọmọ Orílẹ̀-èdè náà (19-21, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019) yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> American pop star Kanye West has announced a "Sunday Mass" pop-up concert in Kingston, Jamaica, just before the weekend of the National Day celebrations (19-21 August 2019) begins.</s>

en: This was the first time the rapper had taken his huge gospel choir outside the United States, reportedly at the request of a Jamaican member of his staff.
yor: Èyí ni ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ tí ọ̀kọrin náà yóò kó ẹgbẹ́ akọrin ìyìnrere rẹ̀ kúrò ní Amẹ́ríkà, ní ìjẹ́pèe ti agbè fún ìjọba orílẹ̀ èdèe kan tí ó Ja kí ó gbé ètò náà wá sílùú òun.
mt0: <pad> This is the first time the singer has led his evangelical band outside of America, in a local partnership with a government that he had been working for before bringing the show to his homeland.</s>

en: However, the event was besieged with criticism from the outset, culminating with West's unapproved use of Jamaican emblems on merchandise being sold on his website.
yor: Síbẹ̀, àríyá náà tí rí ìtakò láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀, tí ó Ho forí sọlẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àmì ìdánimọ̀ọ orílè-èdèe Jamaica tí West we lórí ọjà tí ó ń tà lóríi ibùdó ìtakùn àgbáyée rẹ̀ láì gba àṣẹ láti lò ó.
mt0: <pad> However, the plan has been criticized since the beginning, which was lowered by a Jamaican national flag warning West about his sales on his global phone base without permission.</s>

en: With just two days’ notice, the free concert took place at Emancipation Park in Kingston, the capital city — a location that jarred some commentators because of controversial comments West had made about slavery during a media interview in May 2018.
yor: Láàárín ọjọ́ méjì ni ìkéde fi lọ síta, inúu gbàgede Emancipation Park tó wà ní Kingston, olú ìlú orílẹ̀ èdè náà ni bẹbẹ́ ti wáyé — ojú ibi tí ó mú àwọn sọ̀rọ̀sọ̀rọ̀ kan wí tẹnu wọn látàrí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ tó mú àríyànjiyàn dání tí West sọ nípa òwò ẹrú nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò kan báyìí lóṣù karùn-ún ọdún-un 2018.
mt0: <pad> In just two days, the Emancipation Park in Kingston, capital of Canada was transformed into a site of protest that sparked some controversy after West's controversial comments about slavery in an interview this month in March 2018.</s>

en: The park was opened in 2002 in honour of the "full freedom" of 300,000 slaves in Jamaica on August 1, 1838.
yor: Ọdún-un 2002 ni gbàgede náà di lílò ní ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún "òmìnira dójú àmì" fún àwọn ẹrú 300,000 ní Jamaica lọ́jọ́ 1, oṣù kẹjọ ọdún-un 1838.
mt0: <pad> In 2002, the compound became a symbol of "over-the-counter" freedom for 300,000 slaves in Jamaica on August 1, 1838.</s>

en: That may have been the first bone of contention around the concert, but it was not the last.
yor: Ó lè jẹ́ èyí gan-an ni oun àkọ́kọ́ nípa àríyá orin náà, ṣùgbọ́n òun kọ́ ni ó gbẹ̀yìn.
mt0: <pad> He may have been the first to write the song, but he was the last.</s>

en: Even as Culture Minister Olivia "Babsy" Grange responded to early criticism by saying the country was benefitting from the concert, one music promoter felt the show, which was livestreamed on the Sunday Service website, "upstaged" other cultural activities over Heroes Day weekend.
yor: Pàápàá jù lọ bí Olóòtú Ètò Àṣà Olivia "Babsy" Grange ṣe bẹnu-àtẹ́ lu àwọn alátakò nígbà tí ó sọ wípé orílẹ̀ èdè náà ṣe àbápín nínú èrè àríyá náà, ní èyí tí aṣagbátẹrù orin kan lérò wípé àríyá náà tí ó ṣe é wò lójú ẹsẹ̀ bí ó ṣe ń lọ lóríi ìtakùn àgbáyée Ìsìn Ọjọ́ Ọ̀sẹ̀, "gba" àwọn ètò tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ àṣà ìbílẹ̀ tí ó jẹ́ ti Ìsinmi àwọn Málegbàgbé Ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè sẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́.
mt0: <pad> Especially after Olivia "Babsy" Grange, the Cultural Program Director, struck critics with a punchline when she said that the country was sharing in the profits of the concert, which one musician thought the concert, which he saw on his way to the World Sunday Mass., "took" the traditional cultural events of the National Day of Remembrance.</s>

en: In addition, Kingston residents, who suffered unusually heavy traffic flows throughout the week, predicted chaos and confusion during the evening rush hour.
yor: Láfikún, àwọn olùgbée Kingston, tí ó bá súnkẹrẹ fàkẹrẹ kòdìmú lọ́sẹ̀ yẹn, fọ àfọ̀tẹ́lẹ̀ làásìgbò àti rọ̀tìrọti bí àwọn tó ṣíwọ́ iṣẹ́ bá ń darí lọ sílé nírọ̀lẹ́.
mt0: <pad> Kingston, which had been in a state of emergency for the past week, broke windows and broken doors as workers were driving home in their cars.</s>

en: Nevertheless, the concert went smoothly, several thousand Jamaicans  enjoyed the show and Jamaican media companies earned online kudos for their flawless production:
yor: Láì sí àní-àní, àríyá náà lọ ní ìrọwọ́-ìrọsẹ̀, ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn Nev orílẹ̀-èdèe Jamaica gbádùn-un àríyá náà tí àwọn iléeṣẹ́ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica náà gba ìgbóríyìn fún iṣẹ́ takuntakun tí wọ́n ṣe:
mt0: <pad> No complaints, the ceremony went smoothly, thousands of Nevilles from Jamaica enjoyed the ceremony and the Jamaican radio stations were praised for their hard work.</s>

en: Word on the street is that there may be a move by [Sunday Service] to seek patent/ownership rights on the Kingston, Jamaica logos as well as the fabled streamer-tailed humming bird.
yor: Ìròyìn etíìgbọ́ ìgboro ni wípé ó ṣeé ṣe kí ìgbésẹ̀ wà láti (Ìsìn Ọjọ́-àìkú) láti gba àsẹ èmi-ni-monií/ẹ̀tọ́ oníhun ààmì ìdánimọ̀ọ Kingston, orílẹ̀ èdè Jamaica àti ti ẹyẹ olùlànà onírù gígùn.
mt0: <pad> The latest news is that it is possible that a move will be made by (the Sabbath Church) to acquire the ownership/rights of the Kingston, Jamaica and the high-flying eagle of the Jamaican National Guard.</s>

en: I have done a fair amount of online searches for information to corroborate the claim without luck but have come across their online release of merchandise bearing these landmark symbols, which coincided with the concert...
yor: Mo ti ṣe àwọn ìwádìí kan lórí ayélujára tí mo sì ṣe àwárí láti fi ti ẹ̀rí lẹ́yìn àmọ́ kádàrá kò ṣe mí lóore, mo ṣalábàápàdé ọjàa wọn tí wọ́n ń tà lórí ayélujára tó ní àwọn ààmi ìdánimọ̀ wọ̀nyí, tí ó sì ṣe dọ́gba-n-dọ́gba pẹ̀lú àríyá náà...
mt0: <pad> I've done some research on the internet and tried to find evidence but the camera didn't work for me, I found their online store that had these licenses, which was compatible with the photo.</s>

en: Jamaica’s reality is that successive political administrations have never fully appreciated the economic value of the brand "Jamaica" nor the symbols that [represent] that brand including its flag and its coat of arms.
yor: Òtítọ́ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica ni wípé àwọn ìjọba àná kò fi ìgbàkan kọbiara sí ìgbéró èto ọrọ̀ Ajée ‘Jamaica’ tàbí àwọn ààmi ìdánimọ̀ tó jẹ́ ti wọn bíi àsíá àti àsíá apata.
mt0: <pad> The truth of Jamaica is that the British governments never took any time to register the name 'Jamaica' or their own distinctive symbols such as the flag and the anthem.</s>

en: The same is true for our music and its associated brand marks, Ska, Mento, Rock Steady, Reggae among others.
yor: Bákannáà ni ó rí fún orin wa àti ohun tí ó rọ̀ mọ́, Ska, Mento, Rock Steady, Reggae àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.
mt0: <pad> He also knew our music and its influences, Ska, Mento, Rock Steady, Reggae and so on.</s>

en: That Jamaica was blindsided by the release of clothing bearing the island’s important symbols is a classic case of guerilla marketing.
yor: Ilẹ̀ Jamaica kò tètè lajú sí òwò aṣọ ṣíṣe tí ó ní ààmì pàtàkì erékùṣù tí yóò mú àwọn ènìyàn rà á wìtìwìtì.
mt0: <pad> Jamaica has never been a good tourist destination but it has a very important ecological marker that will make people want to visit it quickly.</s>

en: Having a concert to promote the line at the historic Emancipation Park provides tacit assent of not only the line of garments by the government and people of Jamaica, but also of the use of the country’s national symbols in their creation.
yor: Bí a bá fi ètò àríyá ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àwọn ọjà wọ̀nyí nínúu gbàgede Emancipation Park tí ó mú ìlọsíwájú bá ohun tí ó ju aṣọ lọ láti ọ̀dọ̀ ìjọba àti àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica náà, pẹ̀lú lílo àwọn ààmìi orílẹ̀ èdè náà ní ọ̀nà àrà.
mt0: <pad> When we successfully marketed these goods in the Emancipation Park district, it brought about a greater appreciation from the government and the people of Jamaica, with the use of national symbols as signs of pride.</s>

en: I have noticed that there is now hurried pushback by the Ministry of Culture as well as from the Mayor of Kingston. Both should realize that this isn’t a bottle that will be easy to re-cork.
yor: Mo ti ṣe àkíyèsí wípé Iléeṣẹ́ Ètò Àṣà àti Olùdarí ìlúu Kingston ti ń gbé ìgbésẹ̀ẹ pàjáwìrì láti ra nǹkan padà. Kí àwọn méjèèjì mọ̀ pé àtúnṣe kì í ṣe nǹkan tó ma yá kíákíá.
mt0: <pad> I have verified that the Kingston Heritage and Culture Trust are taking steps to buy back the property. Let both of them know that restoration is not something that will happen overnight.</s>

en: I hope that the government has good lawyers.
yor: Mo lérò wípé ìjọba ní àwọn agbẹjọ́rò tó ká ojú òṣùwọ̀n.
mt0: <pad> I think the government has competent lawyers.</s>

en: Indeed, lawyers may still have quite a bit of work to do to untangle the confusion surrounding the use of Jamaica's national symbols.
yor: Lóòótọ́, àwọn agbẹjọ́rò ṣì níṣẹ́ láti ṣe láti tú kókó awuyewuye etí aṣọ ti lílo àsíá orílẹ̀ èdèe Jamaica.
mt0: <pad> However, the prosecutors are working to bring down the controversy over the use of Jamaican black people in the clothing.</s>

en: Deadly police raids in Guinea as President Alpha Condé clings to power
yor: Ìrọ́lù ọlọ́pàá tí í mú ikú bá ‘ni ní Guinea bí Ààrẹ Alpha Condé ṣe kọ̀ láì gbé’ jọba sílẹ̀
mt0: <pad> Guinean President Alpha Condé refused to resign without being forced out of office</s>

en: "Cities have been paralyzed"
yor: "Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìlú ti kọ̀yìn síjọba lórí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí"
mt0: <pad> "Many cities have backed the government on this measure."</s>

en: Screenshot from a France 24 news flash about the situation in Guinea.
yor: Àgékù ohun tí ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní Guinea láti ìròyìn ránpẹ́ France 24 kan.
mt0: <pad> Guinea: A summary of the situation in Guinea from a French television news channel France 24.</s>

en: Police violence erupted in Guinea on October 14, resulting in the death of several people and massive arrests, following demonstrations protesting against current president Alpha Condé's plans to modify the constitution to run for a third term.
yor: Ìwà ipá bẹ́ sílẹ̀ ní Guinea lọ́jọ́ 14 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, tí ó ti fa ikú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn tí wọ́n sì ń kó àwọn ènìyàn kiri lẹ́yìn ìyíde ìféhónúhàn tí ó tako ìjọba ààrẹ tí ó wà lórí oyè ìyẹn Alpha Condé, ẹni tí ó ń gbèrò láti yí ìwé-òfin padà kí ó bá fi ààyè gba òun láti lọ fún ìgbà kẹta.
mt0: <pad> The violence broke out in Guinea on 14 August, causing the deaths of many people and detainments of others after a protest against the government of President Alpha Condé, who is trying to change the constitution to allow him to run for a third term.</s>

en: The streets of the capital, Conakry, and other cities have turned into battlefields between law enforcement forces and demonstrators.
yor: Ojúu pópó olú ìlú náà, Conakry, àti àwọn ìlú tó kù ti di ojú ogun láàárín àjọ agbófinró àti àwọn ọmọ ìlú tó ń fi èhónú hàn.
mt0: <pad> The streets of the capital, Conakry, and other towns have become a frontline of war between the police and protesters.</s>

en: Police forces have the advantage of new legal privileges that allow them to use deadly force if they deem it necessary for security reasons.
yor: Iléeṣẹ́ ọlọ́pàá ti lo àǹfààní tuntun tí ó fún wọn láṣẹ láti lo ohun ìjà aṣekúpani bí ó bá dé ojú ẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> The police department has used its new power to fire tear gas whenever they see a suspect.</s>

en: The demonstrations have already killed six people, including one police officer, and wounded many.
yor: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ti rán ẹni mẹ́fà sí ọ̀run àjànto, ní èyí tí ó jẹ́ pé ọlọ́pàá kan wà nínúu àwọn tí ó jẹ́ Ògún nípè, ọ̀pọ̀ èèyàn ló sì fi ara pa.
mt0: <pad> Protesters have sent five people to the scene of the riots, a policeman among them, who is a Friday, and many people have been killed.</s>

en: Read more: Security forces in Guinea now have the right to use deadly force
yor: Kà síwájú sí i: Àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò ní Guinea ti ní àṣẹ láti lo ohun ìjà aṣekúpani
mt0: <pad> Next: Security forces in Guinea have been ordered to use machine gun fire.</s>

en: Demonstrators oppose any change to the constitution seen as an attempt by the president to run legally for a third mandate.
yor: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn kò lọ́wọ́ sí kílàńkó àyípadà sí ìwé-òfin tí wọ́n rí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìgbésẹ̀ ààrẹ láti wà lórí ipò fún ẹlẹ́ẹ̀kẹ́ta.
mt0: <pad> Protesters rejected the bill to change the constitution that they saw as a way for the president to stay on as president for a third term.</s>

en: Indeed, the constitution limits the total number of presidential mandates to two in a row. Condé, now 81, should end his mandate in October 2020.
yor: Ní tòótọ́, ìwé-òfin náà fi ààyè ọdún méjì gba ẹni tí ó bá wà ní ipò ààrẹ láti ṣèjọba. Condé, ẹni ọdún 81, yẹ kí sáà rẹ̀ ó parí ní oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2020.
mt0: <pad> In fact, the bill allows the president to serve two more years. Condé, 81, is due to end his term in August 2020.</s>

en: Demonstrators are particularly vulnerable as they operate in violation of the law, as Human Rights Watch reminds:
yor: Àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn ni a lè ṣá lọ́gbẹ́ jù lọ nítorí wípé wọ́n tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin náà bí Human Rights Watch ṣe pè fún àkíyèsí:
mt0: <pad> The media could be the most likely target for this law since they were already aware of it when Human Rights Watch called for an investigation.</s>

en: Translation Original Quote
yor: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an
mt0: <pad> Understand the meaning of the speaker's words</s>

en: The government of Guinea has effectively banned street protests for more than a year, citing threats to public security, Human Rights Watch said today.
yor: Human Rights Watch sọ lónìí wípé, ìjọba orílẹ̀-èdèe Guinea ti gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ìfèhònúhàn l'ójúu pópó fún ọdún kan, ó tọ́ka sí ìdojú-ìjà-kọ ààbò ìlú.
mt0: <pad> Human Rights Watch said today that the government of Guinea has banned public protests for a year, including those against the city's security.</s>

en: Local authorities have prohibited at least 20 political or other demonstrations.
yor: Àwọn aláṣẹ ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ ti fọ́n ó tó bíi ogún ìfèhònúhàn ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú àti àwọn mìíràn ká yángá.
mt0: <pad> Officials of the local government have reportedly arrested about 100 protesters from the political party and others.</s>

en: Security forces have tear gassed those who defy the ban, and arrested dozens of demonstrators.
yor: Àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò ti sọ tajútajú sí àárín àwọn tí kò gbọ́ràn láti tú wọn ká, wọ́n sì kó àìmọye ènìyàn.
mt0: <pad> The authorities have been very harsh on the unwilling to comply, and have arrested hundreds of people.</s>

en: Regarding the political situation, the government is delivering conflicting messages: On October 13, President Condé welcomed a dialogue:
yor: Ní ti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ òṣèlú náà, àjọ ọba náà ń kéde iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ tí ó ń tako ara wọn: Ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà Ààrẹ Condé fẹ́ ìsọ̀rọ̀-ní-tùnbí-ǹ-nùbí:
mt0: <pad> In the wake of the political incident, the royal family announces a series of actions against each other: On 13th June, President Condé requested a televised debate.</s>

en: Translation Original Quote
yor: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an
mt0: <pad> Understand the meaning of the speaker's words</s>

en: Alpha Condé has reiterated his call for a responsible dialogue and for a permanent process of discussions in order to iron out differences and answer all the challenges the country is facing.
yor: Alpha Condé ti pè fún ìsọ̀rọ̀ ní tùnbíǹnùbí ó sì fẹ́ kí ìjókòó gẹ́gẹ́ bí tọmọtìyá tí yóò fi pẹ̀lẹ́pùtù yanjú gbọ́nmi-síi-omi-ò-tóo tí ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ àti ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí àwọn ìpèníjà tí ó ń kojú orílẹ̀-èdè náà.
mt0: <pad> Alpha Condé has called for a national dialogue and wants it to be used as a vehicle to address the ongoing crisis and find ways to respond to the violence that is sweeping the country.</s>

en: Yet, Ahmed Tidiane Traoré, a presidential counselor, stated the following day on October 12, —two days before the demonstrations started, — to a crowd of RPG youth [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea party]:
yor: Síbẹ̀, Ahmed Tidiane Traoré, olùdámọ̀ràn ipò ààrẹ, sọ lọ́jọ́ tí ó tẹ̀lé e, ìyẹn ní ọjọ́ 12 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, — ọjọ́ méjì kí ìfẹ̀hònúhàn ó tó bẹ̀rẹ̀, — fún àwọn èrò tó jẹ́ ọ̀dọ́ langba RPG ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu [ruling Reunion of the People of Guinea]:
mt0: <pad> But, Ahmed Tidiane Traoré, acting president's advisor, said the day afterward, on August 12, — two days before the protests began, — to the young members of the ruling RPG party, the youth branch of the governing Reunion of the People of Guinea.</s>

en: Translation Original Quote
yor: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an
mt0: <pad> Understand the meaning of the speaker's words</s>

en: We invite the party's youth to remain vigilant in the districts.
yor: A rọ àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú náà láti kún fún ìṣọ́ra ní ojúu pópó.
mt0: <pad> We urged the young members of the party to contribute to the security in front of the public.</s>

en: They [the opposition activists] have stocked use tires in wholes, we invite young people from the party to get those tires out, prevent them from acting, get those hidden tires, do not attack anyone, do not destroy anything, just defend yourselves.
yor: Àwọn [tí àwọn jẹ́ ajìjàngbara alátakò] ti fa ìṣòro, a pe àwọn ìpẹ́ẹ̀rẹ́ láti inú ẹgbẹ́ náà láti wá ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí ìṣòro tó wà nílẹ̀, àmọ́ kí ẹ máà dojú ìjà kọ ẹnikẹ́ni, kí ẹ máà ba dúkìá kankan jẹ́, ju ìdáàbò bo ara yín lọ.
mt0: <pad> They [the rebels] have caused problems, we call the leaders from the party to find a solution to the problem, but don't fight anyone, don't destroy any property, and protect yourself more than you protect others.</s>

en: All evil-doers will be found and shown to the people.
yor: Gbogbo àwọn oníṣẹ́-ibi ni ó di àwárí tí a ó fi ojúu wọn hàn f'áráyé rí.
mt0: <pad> All the actors will be discovered and their faces will be shown to the world.</s>

en: This double talk amongst those in power has further angered the opposition and civil society, according to the site globalguinee.info:
yor: Ẹnu méjì àwọn tí ó ń tukọ̀ ìlú ti túbọ̀ mú inú bí ẹgbẹ́ alátakò àti àwọn àjàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn, ó ní bí ìtakùn globalguinee.info ṣe sọ:
mt0: <pad> Two types of rebels and human rights activists have been involved in the riots, according to a report by Globalguinee.info.</s>

en: Translation Original Quote
yor: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an
mt0: <pad> Understand the meaning of the speaker's words</s>

en: October 14, 2019, is a dark Monday, if not black, responding to the call made by the FNDC [National Front for the Defense of the Constitution], Guineans took massively to the streets to oppose the project of constitutional changes.
yor: Ọjọ́ 14 oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2019 jẹ́ ọjọ́ Ajé burúkú Èṣù gbomi mu, ní ti ìfèsì sí ìpè àjọ FNDC [Àwọn tí ó ń lé wájú ń'nú Ìdáàbò bo Ìwé-òfin Orílẹ̀-èdè], àwọn ọmọ Guinea tú yáyá tú yàyà sí ojúu títì láti tako ìgbésẹ̀ àtúnṣe sí ìwé-òfin.
mt0: <pad> On 14th October 2019, in response to the call of the FNDC (Front for National Defence of the Constitution), Guineans went on the streets to protest against the proposed amendments to the constitution.</s>

en: Clashes were reported in different districts of the Guinean capital.
yor: Ìkọlù wáyé ní àwọn agbègbè tí ó wà ní àárín olú ìlú orílẹ̀-èdè náà.
mt0: <pad> The explosions occurred in the central districts of the capital city of the country.</s>

en: Business in the administrative center of Kalou was almost entirely stopped.
yor: Káràkátà dẹnu kọlẹ̀ ní àárín gbùngbùn ibi ìṣàkóso ìlú ní Kalou.
mt0: <pad> A brick fell on the roof of Kalou Municipal Hall.</s>

en: Inside the country, people also responded to the call in Middle and Lower Guinea.
yor: Àwọn tí ó wà ní Àárín àti Odò orílẹ̀ èdè Guinea náà gbọ́ ìpè, wọ́n sì darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn ọmọ ìlú tó kù.
mt0: <pad> Guineans in the Middle and North areas heard the call, and joined the other residents.</s>

en: In the forest and in Higher Guinea, not so much.
yor: Ènìyàn díẹ̀ ni ó jáde ní ìgbèríko àti Òkèe Guinea.
mt0: <pad> A few people have been killed in the region and in the Gulf of Guinea.</s>

en: Yet, cities have been paralyzed.
yor: Àmọ́ ṣá, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìlú ti kọ̀yìn síjọba lórí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí.
mt0: <pad> But many cities have opposed the government on this measure.</s>

en: Expressing himself on benbere.org, a Malian platform for youth, Malian blogger Adam Thiam writes:
yor: Ní oríi benbere.org, gbàgede ìtàkùrọ̀sọ fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ní Mali, akọ̀ròyin búlọ́ọ̀gù Adam Thiam kọ:
mt0: <pad> On benbere.org, a forum for young Malians, the blogger Adam Thiam wrote:</s>

en: Serious things are now happening in Guinea, with incendiary escalation, almost random dead demonstrators riddles with bullets, blood trails on pavements with barricades and crossroads smoking with tires in flames and tear gas.
yor: Nǹkan kàyèéfì ń lọ lọ́wọ́ lọ́wọ́ báyìí ní Guinea, pẹ̀lú ìrógbàmù tí ó ń wáyé, ọta ìbon ti fọ́ sí ara àwọn afẹ̀hónúhàn tí ó sì ti ṣekú pa ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ọ wọn, ẹ̀jẹ̀ ní ojúu pópó, ìdígàgá ní gbogbo, iná ẹsẹ̀ ọkọ̀ọ sísun àti tajútajú nínú afẹ́fẹ́.
mt0: <pad> A terrible thing is happening in Guinea, with bombs exploding, a wild animal has attacked the protesters and killed many of them, blood on the streets, destruction everywhere, fire coming from the wheels of cars and loud bangs in the air.</s>

en: #SexForGrades, a BBC documentary on sexual harassment of female students by university professors in Nigeria and Ghana, has ignited heated online conversation and raises many questions about how to put an end to it:

mt0: <pad> #SexForGrades, a BBC radio show that was based on the sexual exploitation of university students with girls in Nigeria and Ghana has become a viral internet meme and has prompted individual questions about how to stop social abuse.</s>

en: The groundbreaking investigation, released on October 7, 2019, was anchored by journalist Kiki Mordi, who was forced to abandon her own university degree because she refused to yield to the sexual advances by a university teacher who kept failing her:

mt0: <pad> The largest study, published on August 5, 2019, was led by journalist Kiki Mordi who did not finish his university education because she did not want to be treated like a cheat by her university professor who used her name in tests because she wasn't given her permission to do her thesis.</s>

en: However, the Academic Staff Union of Nigerian Universities opposed the bill, claiming that it was discriminatory since it targeted teachers and that it undermined university autonomy.

en: Thousands of visitors to the historic city of Stone Town, Zanzibar, have followed the sound of music to the Dhow Countries Music Academy (DCMA), a music school that promotes and preserves the islands’ musical traditions of the Swahili Coast along the Indian Ocean.
yor: Ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún àlejò tí ó ń rọ́ wìtìwìtì wá sí ìlú Stone Town, Zanzibar tí ó kún fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá, ti tẹ̀lé ìró orin Iléèwé Orin kíkọ Àwọn Orílẹ̀-èdèe Dhow (DCMA), ilé ẹ̀kọ́ orin kíkọ tí ó ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àwọn àṣà orin erékùṣù náà tí ó sún mọ́ Swahili ní ẹ̀báa Omi Òkun India.
mt0: <pad> Thousands of visitors who have been pouring into Stone Town, Zanzibar for the next event, have followed the music of Dhow Country Music Academy (DCMA), a music school that is promoting and preserving the island's Swahili-based music in the Indian Ocean.</s>

en: Since 2002, the school has promoted and preserved the Zanzibar's unique mix of Arab, Indian and African cultures through music.
yor: Láti ọdún-un 2002, ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà ti ṣe ìgbélárugẹ àti ìpamọ́ àkójọpọ̀ orin Lárúbáwá, India àti Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tí kò lẹ́lẹ́gbẹ́.
mt0: <pad> Since 2002, the school has been preserving and preserving an unprecedented collection of Indian, Rajasthani and Arab music.</s>

en: After 17 years, the school faces a financial crisis that threatens its closure.
yor: Lẹ́yìn-in ọdún kẹtàdínlógún, iléèwé náà kò rí owó tí ó tówó nínú àpò ìkówó sí tí ó sì leè fa kí iléèwé náà ó di títì pa.
mt0: <pad> After January 16, the school had no funding from the state and was at risk of closing.</s>

en: Nearly 70% of its 80 full-time students can't afford to pay their tuition, which comes to about $13 USD per month, according to an official DCMA press release.
yor: Nínú ìwé ìgbéròyìnjáde tí àwọn aláṣẹ DCMA tẹ̀ jáde, ìdá àádọ́rin nínú àwọn ọgọ́rin akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ni kò rí owó iléèwé wọn tí ó tó bíi $13 USD lóṣù san.
mt0: <pad> In a DCMA report, eighty percent of the 40 students said they did not receive their $13 USD monthly tuition fee.</s>

en: While the school has received support over the years from international donors and diplomatic missions, they face a gap in funding that may force them to shut their doors at the historic Old Customs House.
yor: Pẹ̀lú àtìlẹ́yìn àwọn onínúure tí ó ti dáwó fún iléèwé náà, owó tí ó kù ní sísan ṣì pọ̀ tó bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó fi jẹ́ wípé, ó ṣe é ṣe kí ilẹ̀kùn-un iléèwé náà tí ó wà nínú Ilé Àwọn Ẹ̀ṣọ́ Aṣọ́bodè Àtijọ́.
mt0: <pad> With the donations from engineers to the library, the remaining money is so much that the building of the library in the Old Curiosity Shop can be demolished.</s>

en: Without crucial funds to continue, DCMA students and staff fear that the soulful sounds that flow through the hallways of this iconic institution that make these islands sing — may cease.
yor: Láìsí owó tí ó tówó nílẹ̀ láti tẹ̀síwájú, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA àti òṣìṣẹ́ ń fòyà kí ìró amọ́kànbalẹ̀ tí ó ń sun jáde láti inúu gbọ̀ngán olókìkí ilé ẹ̀kọ́ yìí tí ó mú erékùṣù yìí kọrin — leè wọ òkùnkùn.
mt0: <pad> With no funds to continue, DCMA students and staff are screaming at the smoke that is coming from the historic building of the school that made this country sing — you can't wear a dress.</s>

en: The school not only teaches and promotes traditional culture and heritage through music, but it's also home to a community of young musicians who seek alternatives to making a living as creatives.
yor: Orin àti ìgbélárugẹ àṣà àti àjogúnbá nìkan kọ́ ni ilé ẹ̀kọ́ náà fi gbajúmọ̀, àmọ́ ó jẹ́ ilé fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ń wà ibi tí wọn yóò ti fi ìmọ̀ kún ìmọ̀.
mt0: <pad> The school is known for music and the promotion of culture and tradition, but it is also a place for young people who are looking for a place to share knowledge.</s>

en: A DCMA student learns the qanun, a featured instrument in classical taarab songs. Photo courtesy of the DCMA.

mt0: <pad> A DCMA student is learning the qanun, a modern taarab instrument. Photo from the DCMA school.</s>

en: "We [have started] to face a very challenging financial moment", said Alessia Lombardo, managing director of the DCMA, in an official DCMA video.

mt0: <pad> "We [have] started to see a significant increase in attention during the difficult times," DCMA's deputy director, Alessia Lombardo, said in a video conference with DCMA.</s>

en: "From now to the next six months, we are not sure that we can guarantee the salaries to our teachers and staff".
yor: Láti ìsinsìnyí lọ títí di oṣù mẹ́fà sí àsìkò yìí, a kò rí àrídájú tí ó rinlẹ̀ wípé a ó leè san owó oṣù àwọn olùkọ́ni àti òṣìṣẹ́ẹ".
mt0: <pad> From the start to now, we haven't seen a clear indication that we can pay the monthly salary of our teachers and employees.</s>

en: At the moment, 19 master teachers and small core staff have gone without salaries for over three months as the school struggles to secure strong funding partnerships and explore sustainable funding models for a school.
yor: Ní àkókò tí a wà yìí, àwọn àkàwé-gboyè olùkọ́ 19 àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ mìíràn ti ṣiṣẹ́ fún oṣù mẹ́ta gbáko láì gba owó lọ sílé nítorí àìsí owó nínúu kóló iléèwé.

en: While the archipelago is known as a tourist destination for its pristine beaches and luxury hotels, the majority of local people struggle with high unemployment even as poverty has slightly decreased, according to The World Bank.

mt0: <pad> As the UNESCO has explained, although the area is known as a tourist attraction for its old windows and the large luxury hotels that are located nearby, locals complain about unemployment, especially since the work has been delayed more than once.</s>

en: For 17 years, the DCMA has worked tirelessly to promote and protect Zanzibar’s rich heritage and traditions through music.
yor: Fún ọdún mẹ́tàdínlógún, DCMA ti ṣiṣẹ́ àṣekúdórógbó nípa lílo orin ṣe ìgbélárugẹ tòun ìpamọ́ ọ̀rọ̀ àjogúnbá àti àṣà Zanzibar.

en: The birthplace of legendary taarab singers Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, or Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar is home to musical genres that emerged through cultural exchange and collaboration along the Swahili Coast for hundreds of years.

mt0: <pad> The songs of the two female taarab singers, Siti Binti Saad and Fatuma Binti Baraka, also known as Bi. Kidude, Zanzibar is a music hall that has been a cultural and elderly association between the Swahili villages of the northern coast of the island.</s>

en: Today, students can learn traditional musical genres like taarab, ngoma and kidumbak, along with instruments like drums, qanun and oud, as gatekeepers — and interpreters — of culture and tradition.

mt0: <pad> Over the modern day, students can learn traditional music such as taarab, ngoma and kidumbak, with the addition of musical instruments such as the drums in the percussionist, qanun and oud, as a preserver and exponent of — and a creator of — culture and traditions.</s>

mt0: <pad> At the end of the DCMA certification exams, after receiving their certificate and at the end of a year-long course, most of the DCMA students have become established actors and performing on international television.</s>

en: Zanzibar’s Amina Omar Juma, a former DCMA student and current DCMA teacher, recently returned from a tour in South Africa with her critically acclaimed, "Siti and the Band", known for "fusing the roots" by blending traditional taarab sounds with contemporary, layered rhythms.
yor: Ọmọ bíbíi Zanzibar, tí ó jẹ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ọ DCMA nígbà kan rí, tí ó jẹ́ olùkọ́ni ní iléèwé kan náà báyìí, Amina Omar Juma tòun ti ìlú mọ̀ọ́ká ẹgbẹ́ akọrin rẹ̀, tí ó ń "fi àṣà ìró orin ìbílẹ̀ " taarab papọ̀ mọ́ ti ìgbàlódélonígbàńlò kọrin, ìyẹn "Siti àti Ẹgbẹ́ ", ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ padà wọ̀lú láti ìrìnàjò orin kíkọ kan ní orílẹ̀-èdèe South Africa.
