en: A history of cultural crossroads and collaboration
yor: Ìtàn nípa àyálò àṣà àti àjọṣepọ̀
mt0: <pad> History of cultural transitions and cooperation</s>

en: Over 15,000 visitors have passed through the academy’s iconic building to enjoy live performances, workshops and classes and interact with passionate DCMA musicians who represent the future of Zanzibar culture and heritage, according to the DCMA.
yor: Ó tó ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́ẹ̀ẹ́dógún àlejò ni ó ti wo eré, gba ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti bá àwọn akọrin lóríṣiírísí ọjọ́ ọ̀la ní iléèwé olókìkí náà ní gbólóhùn rí.
mt0: <pad> Over 1,200 guests have watched the show, signed autographs and talked with the singers on Saturday at the historic library, according to a statement by the museum.</s>

en: Drawing from a complex history of Indian, Arab and African exchange, the school celebrates the influence of "dhow countries", with inspiration from cultures that converged along the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.
yor: Iléèwé náà ti ṣe àyálò àti àmúpapọ̀ ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan àṣà "àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè dhow", tí ó wà ní ìtòsíi Òkun India àti Ọ̀gbùn-un Persia.
mt0: <pad> The library has studied and analyzed the cultures of the "dhow nations", which were located around the Indian Ocean and the Persian Gulf.</s>

en: The Omani Sultanate, a "major maritime force from the 17th to 19th centuries", shifted its seat of power from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840.
yor: Agbègbèe Omani Sultanate, tí ó jẹ́ " ibi gbòógì àwọn alágbára atukọ̀ orí omi ní ọgọ́rùn-ún Ọdún-un kẹtàdínlógún sí kọkàndínlógún sẹ́yìn", gbé àga agbára rẹ̀ láti Muscat sí Zanzibar ní ọdún-un 1840.
mt0: <pad> The Oman Sultanate, which was "the hub of the sea merchants in the 16th and 17th centuries", moved its capital from Muscat to Zanzibar in 1840.</s>

en: From Stone Town, Omani kings oversaw elaborate systems of maritime trade, including cloves, gold, and textiles, powered by strong winds that set dhows — traditional Arab vessels — sailing across the Indian Ocean, from India to Oman to East Africa.
yor: Láti Stone Town, àwọn ọba Omani ń tukọ̀ọ okòwò orí omi ìgbà náà tí ó fẹjú, títí kan kànáfùrù, wúrà, àti aṣọ , látàrí àwọn ìjì líle tí ń tu àwọn ọkọ̀ ìbílẹ̀ẹ Lárúbáwáa — dhows — ní oríi Òkun Indian, láti India sí Oman títí lọ dé Ìlà-Oòrùn Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> From Stone Town, the Oman sultans were transporting precious ships of the time, including cinnamon, gold, and cloth, due to strong winds that were blowing Arab dhows across the Indian Ocean, from India to Oman and east to the Middle East.</s>

en: Young Zanzibaris recognize the importance of connecting with the past to determine their future and the music created today expresses that desire to bridge the old with the new.
yor: Àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ní Zanzibar mọ rírìi ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá tí ó ní ohun ńlá ní í ṣe fún ọjọ́ ọ̀la wọn, ni wọ́n fi ń ṣe àdàlù èyí tí a rí nínú àwọn orin òde òní tí wọn ń gbé jáde.
mt0: <pad> The young people in Zanzibar know that they have something big to do for their future, so they are making a change that we see in the modern music they are playing.</s>

en: DCMA students and teachers recently formed "TaraJazz", a blend of traditional taarab and modern jazz.
yor: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti olùkọ́ni DCMA ṣe ìdásílẹ̀ẹ "TaraJazz" láì pẹ́ yìí, èyí tí ó jẹ́ àdàlù orin ìbílẹ̀ taarab àti orin Jazz òde òní.
mt0: <pad> Students and teachers of DCMA recently founded TaraJazz, a fusion of the traditional taarab music and modern jazz music.</s>

en: Their violinist, Felician Mussa, 20, has only been studying the violin for 3.5 years; TaraJazz is one of the most sought-after bands on the islands, captured here by photographer Aline Coquelle:
yor: Ata violin, Felician Mussa, ọmọ ogún ọdún, ti ń kọ́ ohun èlò ìkọrin olókùn tín-ín-rín náà fún ọdún mẹ́ta àtààbọ̀; TaraJazz jẹ́ ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ẹgbẹ́ akọrin tí ó àwọn ènìyàn máa ń pè sí òde jù lọ ní àwọn erékùṣù náà, ni ó wà nínú àwòrán tí ayàwòrán tí Aline Coquelle yà:
mt0: <pad> Felician Mussa, a 12-year-old violin player, has been learning the instrument for the past three years; TaraJazz is one of the most popular bands in the archipelago, as seen in the photo by Aline Coquelle.</s>

en: The Swahili coast tells the story of epic cultural exchanges and the DCMA continues this tradition through its musical collaborations.
yor: Agbègbèe Swahili sọ ìtàn pàṣípààrọ àṣà ìbílẹ̀ tí DCMA ṣì ń tẹ̀síwájú nínúu rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àjọṣepọ̀ àwọn orin-in rẹ̀ .
mt0: <pad> The Swahili region tells the story of a cultural renaissance that DCMA is continuing to pursue with its partnerships with its artists.</s>

en: Every year, the school hosts an initiative called "Swahili Encounters", matching well-known musicians hailing from Africa, the Middle East, Europe and North America with DCMA students to create original musical compositions within a week-long period.
yor: Lọ́dọọdún, iléèwé náà máa ń gbàlejò fún ètò tí a pè ní "Ìkọlù Swahili", tí ó mú àgbárijọpọ̀ọ àgbà akọrin láti Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀, Ìlú Abẹ́-àkóso Lárúbáwá, Ilẹ̀ Éróòpù àti Àríwá Amẹ́ríkà pẹ̀lú àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ DCMA láti ṣe orin láàárín ọ̀sẹ̀ kan.
mt0: <pad> Every year, the school hosts a special event called "Swahili Week", which brings together leading singers from Africa, Sub-Saharan Africa, Europe and North America with DCMA students to perform for a week.</s>

en: At the end of the "encounter", the newly-formed collaboration performs at Sauti za Busara, and many of these collaborations turn into life-time friendships that transcend the boundaries of language and culture, proving music is a universal language.
yor: Ní ìgbẹ̀yìngbẹ́yín "ìkọlù" náà, àgbárijọpọ̀ tuntun náà yóò ta bí elégbé ní Sauti za Busara, tí àjọṣepọ̀ wọ̀nyí yóò sì di ìbáṣepọ̀ ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́ tí kò mọ ìyàtọ̀ èdè àti àṣà, tí ó fi hàn gbangba wálíà wípé èdè kan náà tí gbogbo ayé gbọ́ ni orin.
mt0: <pad> After the "attack", the new alliance will die like a fire in Sauti za Busara, and the partnership will become a long-term friendship that ignores language and culture differences, showing clearly that the same language is spoken by everyone in music.</s>

en: DCMA offers weekly live performances showcasing students’ talents and collaborations with visiting musicians, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. Photo courtesy of DCMA.
yor: DCMA máa ń ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ètò orin kíkọ tí ó ń ṣe ìgbélárugẹ ẹ̀bùn orin kíkọ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ àti àfihàn àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀kọrin àlejò hàn ní, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA ni ó ni àwòrán.
mt0: <pad> DCMA will present a literary program that will promote students' literary talents and show collaborations with guest artists in, Stone Town, Zanzibar, 2019. DCMA is the owner of the image.</s>

en: The DCMA recognizes that music empowers and unites people across cultures — and it also employs talented youth living in a struggling economy with limited job opportunities.
yor: DCMA mọ rírì orin gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun tí ó leè ró àwọn ènìyàn lágbára àti gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohun tí ó lè mú ìṣọ̀kan àti ìrẹ́pọ̀ bá àwọn ènìyàn láì wo ti àṣà — ó sì tún ń pèsè àǹfààní iṣẹ́ fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí ó ní ẹ̀bùn àmọ́ tí ó ń tiraka láti jẹ.
mt0: <pad> DCMA recognizes music as a tool that can empower people and bring together people regardless of culture — and it also provides employment opportunities for young talented people who struggle to be successful.</s>

en: For the 1,800 students who have trained at the DCMA, this is the only musical home they know, where they can learn and grow as professional musicians and artists.
yor: Fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ 1,800 tí ó ti gba ìdánilẹ́kọọ́ ní DCMA, èyí nìkan ni ibi ilé orin tí wọ́n mọ̀, níbi tí wọ́n ti ń kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́ tí wọ́n sì ti ń ní àlékún ìmọ̀ nípa iṣẹ́ orin kíkọ àti bí a ṣe ń di òǹkọrin.
mt0: <pad> For the 1,800 students who have graduated from DCMA, this is the only music school they know, where they learned and gained knowledge about writing music and becoming a singer.</s>

en: One traveler from Spain, who recently visited the DCMA, wrote on TripAdvisor: "Personally, meeting the musicians was the best piece of my time on this island".
yor: Arìnrìn-àjò kan láti Spain, tó bẹ DCMA wò ní kò pẹ́ yìí, kọ sí oríi TripAdvisor: "Ní tèmi, ìṣalábàápàdée àwọn akọrin ni ìgbà tí ó meet jù lọ fún mi ní erékùṣù yìí".
mt0: <pad> A Spanish tourist, who recently visited DCMA, wrote on TripAdvisor: "To me, the concerts were the best time of my trip to this island."</s>

en: As Zanzibar’s tourism sector rapidly grows, the DCMA believes that music plays an essential role in the celebration, preservation and promotion of Swahili culture, heritage and history.
yor: Bí ẹ̀ka ìrìn-àjò afẹ́ẹ Zanzibar ṣe ń gbèrò sí i, DCMA nígbàgbọ́ wípé orin ní ipa kan gbòógì ní í ṣe nínú àjọyọ̀, ìpamọ́ àti ìgbélárugẹ tòun ìpolongo àṣà, àjogúnbá àti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwáa Swahili.
mt0: <pad> As the Zanzibar Tourist Board has said, DCMA believes that music plays a major role in promoting, preserving and spreading Swahili culture, history and heritage.</s>

en: Zanzibar is far more than its beaches and luxury hotels — it’s a place bursting with talent that stems from an extraordinary history of cultural connection and collaboration.
yor: Zanzibar ju àwọn etíkun àti ilé ìtura olówó iyebíye rẹ̀ lọ — ó jẹ́ ibi tí ó kún fún àwọn ènìyàn ọlọ́pọlọ tí ó ní ẹ̀bùn ní poolo orí wọn látàrí àjọṣepọ̀ ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́ tí ó mú agbègbè náà dá yàtọ̀ gedegbe.
mt0: <pad> Zanzibar is more than just beaches and luxury hotels - it's a place for the intellectually gifted and fortunate thanks to its long-standing association with the indigenous people that has made the region so distinctive.</s>

en: Editor's note: The author of this post has volunteered with DCMA.
yor: Ìfiyèsí Alákòóso Ìwé Títẹ̀: Òǹkọ̀wé àtẹ́jádé yìí ti ṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀fẹ́ pẹ̀lú DCMA.
mt0: <pad> Copyright Notice: This publication has been edited for free by DCMA.</s>

en: Witch-hunting still claims lives in rural India
yor: Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ṣì ń gba ẹ̀mí àwọn ènìyàn ní ìgbèríko India
mt0: <pad> a riot killed people in the church</s>

en: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India
yor: Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India
mt0: <pad> Superstition and lack of awareness behind witch-hunting in India</s>

en: A village near Jamshedpur in Jharkhand. Picture courtesy Anumeha Verma
yor: Ìletò kan ní ẹ̀báa Jamshedpur ní Jharkhand. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Anumeha Verma
mt0: <pad> A hotel in the suburbs of Jamshedpur in Jharkhand. Image by Anumeha Verma.</s>

en: On 20 July, four elderly people were lynched by a mob in the Gumla District of Jharkhand, India after being accused of practicing witchcraft.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Agẹmọ, àgbájọ àwọn ènìyànkéènìà gba ẹ̀mí àwọn àgbàlagbà mẹ́rin kan láì dá wọn lẹ́jọ́ ní agbègbèe Gumla ní Jharkhand, India lẹ́yìn tí a fi ẹ̀sùn-un àjẹ́ kàn wọ́n.
mt0: <pad> On 20 August, a mob court executed four elderly men without trial in Gumla, Jharkhand, India after they were accused of rape.</s>

en: According to reports, the victims were accused of causing a man's death and they were eventually found guilty of witchcraft by a Panchayat (a village assembly).
yor: Gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí ìjábọ̀ ìròyìn, àwọn àgbàlagbà wọ̀nyí ṣe ikú pa ọkùnrin kan, ni ìgbìmọ̀ abúlée Panchayat ṣe dá wọn lẹ́bi.
mt0: <pad> According to the report, the two men killed a man, and the Panchayat Committee of Abulée accused them of murder.</s>

en: The victims were dragged out of their homes and beaten to death by masked men wielding sticks.
yor: Wọ́n wọ́ àwọn àgbàlagbà mẹ́rin wọ̀nyí jáde síta ilée wọn, àwọn ọkùnrin tí ó bòjú sì fi igi lù wọ́n títí tí ẹ̀mí fi bọ́ lára wọn.
mt0: <pad> They brought the four elderly men out of their homes, and a group of strong men beat them with sticks until they died.</s>

en: Eight of the attackers were subsequently arrested by police.
yor: Mẹ́jọ nínú àwọn ènìyànkéènìà wọ̀nyí ti wà ní akóló ọlọ́pàá.
mt0: <pad> Fourteen of these men have been in police custody.</s>

en: According to police data published by The Times of India, witch-hunting in Jharkhand has claimed 123 lives from May 2016 to May 2019.
yor: Gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí àkọsílẹ̀ ọlọ́pàá tí Times of India tẹ̀jáde, ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ní Jharkhand ti rán àwọn ènìyàn 123 sọ́run àpàpàǹdodo ní àárín-in oṣù Èbìbí ọdún-un 2016 sí oṣù Èbìbí ọdún-un 2019.
mt0: <pad> According to police records, the Jharkhand state government sent 123 people to a mental hospital between January 2016 and January 2019.</s>

en: Across the country, 134 people were killed for the alleged use of "black magic" in 2016, according to the National Crime Records Bureau.
yor: Jákèjádò, ènìyàn 134 di ẹni ẹbọra-ń-bá-jẹun látàrí èsùn-un lílo “ògùngùn” ní ọdún-un 2016, ìyẹn gẹ̀gẹ̀ bí Àjọ Aṣàkọsílẹ̀ Ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ Orílẹ̀-èdè náà ṣe kọ́ ọ sílẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> According to the National Crime Records, 134 people were convicted of using "cannabis" in 2016, according to the agency.</s>

en: A Perpetual Malady
yor: Àrùn T’ó Ń Peléke Sí i
mt0: <pad> i don't know the disease</s>

en: "Witch-hunting is not new in Jharkhand", says Prem Chand, the Founding Chairman of the Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) in Jharkhand, in a telephonic interview.
yor: "Ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ kò jẹ́ tuntun ní Jharkhand", Prem Chand, Olúdásílẹ̀ àti Alága Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) ní Jharkhand, sọ nínúu ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀ro-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ kan.
mt0: <pad> "Theft is not new in Jharkhand," Prem Chand, President and Advocate of Free Legal Aid Committee (FLAC) in Jharkhand, said in an interview on radio.</s>

en: FLAC has been instrumental in bringing about legislation against witch-hunting in Jharkhand.
yor: FLAC ti ń ṣe àtọ́nàa ìṣòfin tí ó tako ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ ní Jharkhand.
mt0: <pad> FLAC has been protesting against the anti-terrorism law in Jharkhand.</s>

en: The organisation first began working in this area in 1991 when a woman was accused by her neighbour of causing a boy’s death.
yor: Iléeṣẹ́ náà bẹ̀rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ ní agbègbè yìí ní ọdún-un 1991 nígbà tí àwọn aládùúgbò fi ẹ̀sùn kan obìnrin kan pé ó lọ́wọ́ nínú ikú ọmọdékùnrin kan.
mt0: <pad> The agency began its work in the area in 1991 when neighbors accused a woman of involvement in the death of a young boy.</s>

en: An irate mob attacked her and killed her husband and son.
yor: Àgbájọ àwọn ènìyànkéènìà kan dìgbò lù ú, wọ́n sì pa ọkọ àti ọmọ rẹ̀ ọkùnrin.
mt0: <pad> A mob of angry men attacked her, burned her car and her son.</s>

en: She sustained injuries.
yor: Òún fi ara pa.
mt0: <pad> They don't know</s>

en: When Prem Chand and his colleagues visited the offenders in the prison, they were met with defiance:
yor: Nígbàtí Prem Chand àti àwọn ẹlẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ ṣe ìbẹ̀wò sí àwọn ẹlẹ́ṣẹ̀ wọ̀nyí nínúu túbú, wọ́n bá ìpèníjà:
mt0: <pad> When Prem Chand and his colleagues visited the prisoners in the compound, they were confronted by a fight.</s>

en: They told us that they stood by their accusation.
yor: Wọ́n sọ fún wọn wípé àwọn dúró lé oríi ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n fi kan àwọn.
mt0: <pad> They were told they were standing by the charges.</s>

en: They also shared a belief that when the blood of a woman branded as a witch falls on the ground, she loses her so-called powers of sorcery.
yor: Wọ́n sì tún gbàgbọ́ wípé bí ẹ̀jẹ̀ẹ ẹni tí a pè ní àjẹ́ bá kan ilẹ̀ ọ̀gẹ́rẹ́, yóò pàdánù agbára ẹlẹyẹ rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> They also believed that if the blood of the owl touched the ground, it would lose its power of flight.</s>

en: Prem Chand says that it affects specific sectors of the population:
yor: Prem Chand sọ wípé ó kan apá kan nínú àwọn ọmọ ìlú:
mt0: <pad> Prem Chand said that he was only a part of the city's people.</s>

en: Usually, it is the women from the weaker sections of the society and economically backward regions that are targeted.
yor: Nígbàgbogbo, àwọn obìnrin tí kò lárá tí ó tálákà ní í máa ń fi ara kááṣá.
mt0: <pad> Always, unmarried women who are being molested by men are very ashamed.</s>

en: The victims are mostly Adivasis, Harijans and Dalits.
yor: Àwọn tí ó f’ara kááṣá wọ̀nyí ni àwọn Adivasis, Harijans àti Dalits.
mt0: <pad> These include the Adivasis, Harijans and Dalits.</s>

en: It is an assault on the dignity of women and a violation of constitutional rights for a dignified life for every human being.
yor: Ìfojú iyì àwọn obìnrin àti ìtasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin ẹ̀tọ́ sí ayé iyì fún gbogbo ọmọ ènìyàn.
mt0: <pad> The demonstrations and protests of women and girls have led to the introduction of this law on the right to life for all human beings.</s>

en: The Social and Political Realities
yor: Òtítọ́ Àwùjọ àti Ìṣèlú
mt0: <pad> Political and Social Issues</s>

en: Activists say that deeply rooted superstitions prevalent in the hinterlands are a major cause behind the practice.
yor: Àwọn ajìjàngbara sọ wípé ìgbàgbọ́-asán tí ó rinlẹ̀ ní ìgbèríko ni ó ń fa ìwà pálapalà náà.
mt0: <pad> Scientists say the rising temperatures in the region are causing the eruptions.</s>

en: A lack of education, poor health facilities and economic backwardness mark the regions where these practices are prevalent.
yor: Àìgbẹ̀kọ́, ètò ìlera tí ò pójú òṣùwọ̀n àti kòlàkòṣagbe tí ó ń gb’àgbègbè tí ìwà pálapalà wọ̀nyí ti gbalẹ̀ bí i ìtàkùn ni ó fi wọ́pọ̀.
mt0: <pad> However, poor health care and a lack of infrastructure are common in the areas where these behaviors have been established as a normality.</s>

en: The cases so far show that often a rumor started by someone is enough to get the ball rolling.
yor: Ọ̀ràn wọ̀nyí ti fi hàn wípé àhesọ ni ó máa fi ń bẹ̀rẹ̀ .
mt0: <pad> These lessons have shown that it is the beginning of the journey.</s>

en: Despite the laws enacted by various Indian states which declare witch-hunting to be illegal, participants in these cases see it as a form of self-defense.
yor: Pẹ̀lú òfin àwọn ìpínlẹ̀ India tí ó ka ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ sí ohun tí ó lòdì sófin, àwọn akópa ọ̀ràn wọ̀nyí rí i gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀nà ìdáààbò-ara-ẹni.
mt0: <pad> With Indian state laws calling rape an anti-social behavior, these journalists see it as a way to protect themselves.</s>

en: It is also used as an excuse for grabbing resources owned by women, exacting revenge or even exploiting women for sex.
yor: Bákan náà ni wọ́n ń wí àwáwí fún gbígba ohun ìní àwọn obìnrin, fi agbára gbẹ̀san tàbí fi ipá bá obìnrin lò pọ̀.
mt0: <pad> They also accuse women of stealing, taking over or exploiting women.</s>

en: According to Prem Chand:
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Prem Chand ṣe ti sọ:
mt0: <pad> As Prem Chand said,</s>

en: The premise is that once you brand a woman as a witch, you can subject her to any treatment.
yor: Àtètèròtẹ́lẹ̀ ni wípé ní kété tí o bá ti pe obìnrin ní àjẹ́, o lè tẹríi rẹ̀ ba fún ìlòkulò.
mt0: <pad> The advantage is that once you've called a woman a lady, you can approach her for a compliment.</s>

en: However, it is important to note that the practice is used as a justification for exploitation and is not a cause behind it per se.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, ó ṣe kókó láti mọ̀ wípé wọn máa ń lo ìwà pálapàla yìí fi gba tara àwọn obìnrin, kò sì kìí ṣe ìdí tí ó ń fà á pàtó.
mt0: <pad> However, it is important to know that this behavior is used to trick women, and not a specific purpose.</s>

en: Ironically, the panchayat often provides tacit approval for branding a person a witch even if does not pass ruling on the punishment to be meted out.
yor: Ní ti ẹ̀fẹ̀, láì wí tó, panchayat náà sábà máa ń lọ́wọ́ sí ìpènìyàn ní àjẹ́ pàápàá bí kò bá pàṣẹ ìjìyà t'ó tọ́.
mt0: <pad> In the voluntary, without saying much, panchayats often help people in agriculture particularly if they don't order proper irrigation.</s>

en: In addition to the elected panchayat, there are self-styled caste panchayats with no legal mandate whatsoever that operate in certain parts of the country.
yor: Ní àfikùn sí panchayat tí ìbó yàn, àwọn kan ńbẹ tí wọ́n pe ara wọn ní panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ láì ní àṣẹ kankan tí ó fún wọn lágbara níbikíbi ní orílẹ̀-èdè.
mt0: <pad> In complaints against the election-run panchayat, some are fighting who call themselves low-level panchayats without any power to act anywhere in the country.</s>

en: These bodies pass verdicts and mete out punishments and remain largely unchallenged.
yor: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ yìí máa ń dájọ́ àti fi ìyà jẹ ènìyàn tí kò sì sí ẹni tí ó ká wọn lápá kò.
mt0: <pad> These groups are often judged and punished by no one, and no one can stop them.</s>

en: An incident in Ajmer district of Rajasthan in 2017 reported involvement of caste panchayat leading to the death of a 40-year-old woman.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan ní agbègbèe Ajmer ní Rajasthan lọ́dún-un 2017 jábọ̀ ìlọ́wọ́sí panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀ tí ó ṣ’okùnfa ikú obìnrin ogójì ọdún kan.
mt0: <pad> A case in the Ajmer district of Rajasthan in 2017 reported the failure of a local panchayat to prevent the deaths of eighteen women in one year.</s>

en: Legally, the courts can take action against such verdicts in case of both elected panchayats and caste panchayats.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí òfin, ilé ẹjọ́ lé gbé ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó tako irúu ìdájọ́ báwọ̀nyí yálà láti ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn panchayat tí ìbó yàn àti panchayat ipò-ìsàlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> As per the law, a court can take action against such decisions by the elected panchayat and the lower-level panchayat.</s>

en: However, the victims seldom get the opportunity to reach a court of law before they become targets of mobs.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àwọn tí ó fara kááṣá ò tilẹ̀ ní àǹfààní sí ilé-ẹjọ́ òfin kí àgbájọ-àwọn-ènìyànkéènìà ó tó kojúu wọn.
mt0: <pad> However, the victims of the accident did not have access to legal action before the jury convicted them.</s>

mt0: <pad> Reports of violence have also been reported in Chattisgarh, Odisha, Gujarat, West Bengal Assam, Bihar, Maharashtra and Rajasthan.</s>

mt0: <pad> In 2014, a female Indian boxer, Debjani Bora, was able to walk on the skin of a cat.</s>

en: According to Debjani’s statements, she was accused of being the cause of several deaths in Cherekali village located 180 km from Guwahati, the capital of the eastern state in India.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀rọ̀ọ Debjani, a f’ẹ̀sùn-un ìgbẹ̀mí ènìyàn púpọ̀ kàn án ní abúlée Cherekali tí ó wà ní kìlómità 180 láti Guwahati, olú-ìlúu India ti apáa ìlà-oòrùn.
mt0: <pad> According to Debjani, the attack occurred in Cherekali village, 180 kilometers from Guwahati, the capital of north-east India.</s>

en: She was allegedly named by a headman of a village prayer hall and brutally assaulted by the villagers.
yor: Olóríi gbọ̀gán àdúrà abúlé l’ó dárúkọ rẹ̀ tí àwọn ará abúlé sí fi ìyà jẹ́ ẹ.

en: 2017 witnessed several cases in the state of Rajasthan.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ 2017 ní ipínlẹ̀ Rajasthan.
mt0: <pad> 2017 in Rajasthan</s>

en: Among these, a 40-year-old woman Kanya Devi was attacked and beaten to death after being accused by her family members in Ajmer district of the state.
yor: Lára èyí ni, ọmọbìnrin ogójì ọdún kan Kanya Devi rí ìkọlù tí a sì lù ú pa lẹ́yìn tí mọ̀lẹ́bíi rẹ̀ fi ẹ̀sùn kàn án ní agbègbèe Ajmer.
mt0: <pad> Yesterday, the fourteen-year-old girl Kanya Devi was beaten and killed in Ajmer after her family accused her of rape.</s>

en: Victims and Survivors
yor: Àwọn Ẹni-tó-fara-kááṣá àti Ẹni-tórí-kó-yọ
mt0: <pad> those who are responsible and those who are not</s>

en: People blame accused witches for causing a slew of misfortunes: the death of a person or animal, droughts, crop failures, etc.
yor: Àwọn ènìyàn ń f’ẹ̀sùn kan àwọn ẹlẹyẹ fún iṣẹ́-ibi ọwọ́ọ wọn: ikú ènìyàn tàbí ẹranko, ọ̀dá òjò, àìso jìngbìnnì irúgbìn, àti bẹ́èbẹ́è lọ.
mt0: <pad> People blame birds for their own deeds: the death of people or animals, flooding, spoiling crops, and so on.</s>

en: The attacks on these women (and some men) are vicious and inhuman.
yor: Ìkọlù tí ó kọ lu àwọn obìnrin wọ̀nyí (àti àwọn ọkùnrin kan) rorò bí ẹranko ẹhànnà.
mt0: <pad> The violence that he used to attack these women (and some men) felt like a wild animal.</s>

en: At times, the accusations and punishment are meted out by their families.
yor: Nígbà mìíràn, àwọn èsùn náà àti ìjìyà ẹṣé máa wá láti ọ̀dọ̀ mọ̀lébíi wọn.
mt0: <pad> Other times, the complaints and accusations of witchcraft come from their own family.</s>

en: Some have lived to tell the tale and fight. Chutni Mahato of Saraikela in Jharkhand is one of them.
yor: Àwọn kan ń gbé tí wọ́n sì ń sọ ìtàn-an wọn tí wọ́n sì ń jà fún ẹ̀tọ́ọ wọn.
mt0: <pad> Some live and tell their stories and fight for their rights.</s>

en: People from the region call her a "tigress".

mt0: <pad> Chutni Mahato of Saraikela in Jharkhand is one of them.</s>

en: She was accused of practicing witchcraft in 1995.
yor: Àwọn ènìyàn láti agbègbè náà máa ń pè é ní "tigress".
mt0: <pad> People from the region call it "tigress".</s>

en: Since then, she has transformed into an activist crusading against the victimization of women in the name of witch-hunting with the help of NGOs working to end the practice.
yor: Wọ́n fi ẹ̀sùn-un àjẹ́ kàn-án ní ọdún-un 1995. Láti ìgbà náà, ó ti yírapadà di ajìjàǹgbara olùtako ìfìyàjẹ àwọn obìnrin pẹ̀lú àtìléyìn Ilé-iṣẹ́-tí-kìí-ṣe-tìjọba.
mt0: <pad> He was convicted in 1995. Since then, he has become a prominent feminist activist with the support of an NGO.</s>

en: Chutni expresses how the lack of resources often makes it a struggle to fight against the practice.
yor: Chutni sọ bí àìsí àtìlẹ́yìn tó késejárí ṣe mú u nira láti jà tako ìwà pálapàla yìí.
mt0: <pad> Chutni explained how the lack of support from the previous generation made it difficult for him to fight this behavior.</s>

en: I wish there was more support from the authorities and government for the work that we are doing here.
yor: Ìbájẹ́pé àtìlẹ́yìn tó tó wá láti ọwọ́ àwọn oníṣẹọba àti ìjọba fún iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe níbí.
mt0: <pad> Thank you for the support and recognition from politicians and government for the work we are doing here.</s>

en: However, I have suffered because of this practice.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, mo ti jìyà nítorí ìwà pálapàla yìí.
mt0: <pad> But I've been very upset with this behavior.</s>

en: When someone comes to me for help, I am always going to stand by them, she said in a telephonic interview.
yor: Bí ènìyàn bá tọ̀ mí wá fún ìrànlọ́wọ́, mo máa dúró tì wọ́n gbágbágbá, ó sọ nínúu ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò orí ẹ̀ro-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ kan.
mt0: <pad> If someone comes to me for help, I'll stand by and wait for them to be saved," he said in an interview on the radio.</s>

en: Formulating Public Opinion
yor: Dídá Ohùn Gbogboògbò Sí i
mt0: <pad> Everyone's voice</s>

en: Both the survivors and activists feel that there is a lack of public opinion in support of ending witch-hunting.
yor: Àwọn ẹni-tórí-kó-yọ àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́-ènìyàn rò wípé àwọn ènìyàn gbogbo kò ti ìfòpin sí ìṣọdẹ-àjẹ́ lẹ́yìn.
mt0: <pad> Critics and analysts think that not everyone is back to the eating habits after the war.</s>

en: The activists who were interviewed for this story expressed a paucity of political will and intellectual engagement to provide the momentum required for the campaign against the heinous practice to succeed.
yor: Àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́-ènìyàn tí a fọ̀rọ̀ wá lẹ́nu wò lórí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí jẹ́ kí á mọ̀ wípé àbùkù ìrànwọ́ ìjọba àti àwọn onímọ̀ ni kò mú ìwà àìbójúmu náà ṣíra kásẹ̀ ńlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> The citizens we interviewed on the incident told us that the lack of government and expert support did not bring down the violence.</s>

en: A silver lining in this dark cloud is that people working against the practice believe that the situation can be turned around.
yor: Ohun tí ó dára jù lọ ni wípé àwọn tí ó ń tako ìwà burúkú yìí gbàgbọ́ wípé àyípadà lè dé.
mt0: <pad> The best part is that those who oppose this behavior believe that change can be made.</s>

en: According to Prem Chand:

mt0: <pad> According to Prem Chand,</s>

mt0: <pad> Aims to end poverty could follow the government's promotion of a knowledge-sharing program.</s>

en: Also, the intellectuals would have to lend their support to the cause to mold the public opinion.
yor: Bákan náà, àwọn onímọ̀ ní láti f’ọwọ́ sí i k’áwọn ènìyàn ó ba f’ohùn sí i.

en: Tobago's coral bleaching alert makes it clear there is ‘no alternative’ to fighting the climate crisis

en: Tobago's coral reefs are an integral part of both the island's marine ecosystem and its economy.

en: Home to numerous species of marine life (and a main source of fish for local fishermen), they also protect the coastline from wave erosion and the effects of tropical storms.
yor: Ibùgbé ọ̀kan-òjọ̀kan ẹ̀yà ẹ̀dá inú omi (àti ibi ẹja pípa fún àwọn apẹja ìbílẹ̀), tí ó sì tún ń dá ààbò bo èbúté, èyí tí kò mú kí àwọn ìjì líle etí omi ó pọ̀ kọjá àlà ni à ń sọ.
mt0: <pad> A sanctuary for the unique aquatic life (and fisheries for local fishermen), and also a buffer for the beach, which prevents waves from breaking over the edge.</s>

en: Popular spots like Buccoo Reef are also popular tourist attractions.
yor: Òkúta inú òkun Buccoo Reef tí o gbajúmọ̀ bí ìṣáná ẹlẹ́ta tí àwọn arìnrìn-àjò afẹ́ máa ń wọ́ tùùrùtù níbẹ̀ náà kò gbẹ́yìn.
mt0: <pad> The Buccoo Reef, which is known as the third most popular spot for snorkeling, has not dried up.</s>

en: But after a press release issued by the country's Institute of Marine Affairs (IMA) on August 22, 2019, in which it warned that — based on findings from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch — Tobago's coral reefs have been placed on a watch for "Bleaching Alert Level One", all eyes are on the island.
yor: Àmọ́ lẹ́yìn àtẹ̀jáde kan sí ilé ìròyìn tí Àjọ tí ó ń ṣàkóso Omi orílẹ̀ èdè náà (IMA) tẹ̀ jáde ní ọjọ́ 22, oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2019, èyí tí ó kìlọ̀ wípé – ìwádìíi National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch sọ wípé — iyùn abẹ́ òkúta òkun Tobago ti bọ́ sì abẹ́ ìṣọ́ láti ṣe òfíntótó "Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dàa Ìpele Ìkíni", gbogbo ojú ló ń wo erékùṣù náà.
mt0: <pad> But after a press release by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Coral Reef Watch on August 22, 2019, which warned that — the underwater coral reef of the Tobago Sea has been monitored to determine the "First Stage Collapse" warning, all eyes were on the reefs.</s>

en: There is a distinct possibility that the bleaching could advance to Level Two within a matter of weeks, which would threatens not only the existence of the reefs themselves, but also the island's marine life and people.
yor: A ì í ṣe é mọ̀, ìpàwọ̀dà náà lè fò fẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ìpele kejì láàárín ọ̀sẹ̀ díẹ̀, tí yóò sì fa àkóbá fún ìwàláàyè àwọn iyùn wọ̀nyí, àwọn ẹ̀dá inú omi mìíràn àti àwọn olùgbé erékùṣù náà.
mt0: <pad> As far as we know, the concentration can rise to second-level in a few weeks, causing significant harm to these fish, other aquatic animals and the people of the island.</s>

en: What exactly is bleaching?

en: Corals coexist with and become home to symbiotic algae, helping it store nutrients and remove waste.
yor: Alábàágbé àti alájọṣe iyùn ni àwọn ewé inú omi tí ó máa ń bá a kó ohun aṣaralóore pamọ́ àti da èérí ara nù.
mt0: <pad> Bubbles and jellyfish are marine organisms that help to store and release chemicals in the body.</s>

en: In return, the algae gives the coral the energy it needs to grow, but drastic changes in water temperature can threaten this cooperative relationship.
yor: Ewé wọ̀nyí yóò sì fún iyùn ní okun tí ó nílò fún ìdàgbàsókè, àmọ́ àyípadà ìgbóná inú omi ń dí àjọṣepọ̀ yìí lọ́wọ́.
mt0: <pad> These plants will also provide the fish with the proteins it needs to grow, but water quality changes are hampering this relationship.</s>

en: When water becomes too hot (or too cold) the corals expel the algae — and with it, its main source of food.
yor: Bí omi bá gbóná ju bí ó ṣe yẹ lọ (tàbí bí ó bá tutù jù) àwọn iyùn yóò lé ewé omi — tí yóò sì pàdánù ọwọ́ tí ó ń fi oúnjẹ nù ún.
mt0: <pad> If the water is too hot (or too cold) the fish will jump out of the water — and lose their hand that provides them with food.</s>

en: Eventually, the coral starves to death; the most noticeable outward sign of this phenomenon is that the coral loses its colour, going from shades of brown and green to a crisp, brittle, bone white.
yor: Àṣèyìnwá àṣẹ̀yìnbọ̀, ebi yóò pa iyùn kú; àwọ̀ ara tí yóò yí padà ni àmì tí a ó fi mọ̀, ìpàwọ̀dà láti àwọ̀ olómi-ọkà àti ewéko sí funfun egungun.
mt0: <pad> When they die, they will be eaten by the beasts; the color of the body will change, a change from green and yellow to bone white.</s>

en: Bleaching Level Alert One means that the corals are extremely likely to start the bleaching process.
yor: Ìkéde Ìpàwọ̀dà Ìpele Kìíní ń kéde wípé bí a kò bá wá nǹkan ṣe sí i, àwọn iyùn náà yóò bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í pàwọ̀dà.
mt0: <pad> The First Level Warning of Extinction is a warning that if no action is taken, the viruses will begin to spread.</s>

en: The IMA therefore suggests that both biologists and citizens should keep an eye out for signs of bleaching over the next 9-12 weeks.
yor: IMA dábàá wípé kí àwọn onímọ̀ ìṣẹ̀dá àti ọmọ ìlú ó máa ṣọ́ àwọn ẹ̀dá inú omi náà fún àwọn àmì ìpàwọ̀dà ní àárín-in ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́sàn-án sí méjìlá tí ó ń bọ̀.

en: According to local coral reef ecologist Anjani Ganase, the main contributors to coral bleaching in Tobago are the warmer water temperatures — a result of climate change.

mt0: <pad> As archaeologist Anjani Ganase has described, the main reason for the collapse of the Tobago Islands is the rise in sea level — which is a result of climatic change.</s>

en: Via email, Ganase explained that the ocean absorbs much of the heat in the atmosphere, which in turn causes the water — especially shallower bodies of water, like the Caribbean Sea — to heat up.
yor: Nínú ímeèlì, Ganase ṣàlàyé wípé òkun máa ń fa èyí tí ó pọ̀ nínú ooru inú afẹ́fẹ́ mu, tí ó sì ń fa kí omi — pàápàá jù lọ àwọn ibú omi jínjìn gbungbunrungbun bíi Ọ̀sàa Caribbean — ó gbóná janjan.
mt0: <pad> In an email, Ganase explained that the oceans absorb much of the heat from the air, which makes the waters — particularly in the deeper waters like the Caribbean Sea — very hot.</s>

en: Because reefs provide fishes with a habitat that allows them to have access to shelter, food and most importantly, shelter for their young until they are ready to survive in the wider ocean, the proposition of losing them will impact the ability of fish species to survive.

en: Tobago relies very heavily on its local tourism industry; its reefs reportedly attract around 40 per cent of the island's tourists.

mt0: <pad> Tobago is a major tourist destination; 40 percent of the island's tourists come to see the waterfalls.</s>

en: Should coral bleaching continue, there will be fewer thriving reefs for people to explore and quite likely, a reduction in tourism dollars, which affects a range of hospitality-related industries: hotels, restaurants, transport services and tour companies.

mt0: <pad> If the restrictions continue, people will not have access to food, the dollar of tourism will fall, and it will affect the hospitality industry such as hotels, restaurants, car Rental and travel agencies.</s>

en: The great irony is that, as tropical storms intensify as a result of the climate crisis, reefs are needed more than ever to absorb the force of waves and create a buffer between the ocean and the shore — but the reefs are compromised by global heating.
yor: Bí ìjì líle bá ń pọ̀ sí i látàrí ségesège ojú-ọjọ́, òkúta iyùn-ún níṣẹ́ pàtàkì ní ṣíṣe láti fa agbára àwọn ìgbé omi àti ìdúró gẹ́gẹ́ bí alárinà láàárín òkun àti etí òkun — àmọ́ ìgbóná àgbáńlá ayé ń dí i lọ́wọ́ láti ṣiṣẹ́ẹ rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> When the wind becomes stronger due to climate change, the tides play a crucial role in drawing energy from the currents and acting as a buffer between oceans and coasts — but the global warming prevents it from doing its job.</s>

en: Studies show that coral reefs protect around 90 per cent of Tobago's shoreline from wave-induced erosion.

mt0: <pad> Research has found that almost 90% of the Tobago Islands are covered by marshes, which are often flooded during the high tide.</s>

en: In a feature address at the International Year of the Reef at the University of the West Indies in 2018, Professor John Agard said that this function will only become more important as storm intensities increase and sea levels rise.

mt0: <pad> When he was speaking at the 2018 annual tuberculosis conference at the University of the West Indies in 2018, Dr. John Agard said that this work will be more and more intense as the wind increases and the rainfall rises.</s>

en: Ganase says the lack of proper management that has allowed overfishing and pollution to go unchecked has made Tobago's coral bleaching worse.

mt0: <pad> Ganase says that these water quality problems have caused overfishing and a decrease in the biodiversity of the fisheries that has led to the extinction of the Tobago sharks.</s>

mt0: <pad> If so, a focus on management and protection of the elephants can only prevent them from returning to their youth and growth.</s>

mt0: <pad> While it is easy to get a visa in some countries, it is not necessary in others.</s>

en: On the 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan and Singapore hold the top spot for access to most countries, while Angola, Egypt and Haiti are at the bottom.
yor: Ní oríi 2019 Henley Passport Index, Japan àti Singapore ni orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó rọrùn fún jù lọ láti ríwèé gbà wọ̀lú oríṣìíríṣi, nígbàtí Angola, Egypt àti Haiti wà ní ìsàlẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> Japan and Singapore are the easiest countries to get a passport in the 2019 Henley Passport Index, while Angola, Egypt and Haiti are the least accessible.</s>

en: Read more: ‘No Visa Mix': Tanzanian singeli stars denied visas to US music festival
yor: Kà síwájú sí i: ‘Kò Sí Àpòpọ̀ Ìwé Ìrìnnà': Àwọn ìràwọ̀ olórin orílẹ̀-èdè Tanzania ò rí ìwé ìrìnnà wọ àjọ̀dún orin ní US
mt0: <pad> Next: 'No Many Visas': Tanzanian music stars can't get visas to perform at the annual festival in Kenya</s>

en: Kenyan author Ciku Kimeria describes the indignity of living without "passport privilege".
yor: Òǹkọ̀wée ọmọbíbíi Kenya Ciku Kimeria ṣe àlàyé gbígbé láìsí iyì "ẹ̀tọ́ sí ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà".
mt0: <pad> Kenyan Foreign Minister Dr. Cyrus Kimeria described the deportation as a "lack of citizenship for travel".</s>

en: She notes that even a visa does not guarantee entry because "you still have to deal with the surly immigration official who will suspiciously ask, ‘And what are you here to do?’"
yor: Obìnrin náà sọ wípé ìwé ìrìnnà nìkan kò gbé ènìyàn wọ orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn nítorí pé "o ní láti dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè bíi, ‘Kí ló wa síbí wá ṣe?"
mt0: <pad> The woman said that a visa alone is not enough to get into another country because "you have to answer questions like, ‘What do you want to do here?'"</s>

en: If the answer to this question isn’t to the official’s satisfaction, visitors could find themselves being marched back to the departure gate.
yor: tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ibodè yóò béèrè, bí èsì ìbéèrè kò bá tẹ́ wọn lọ́rùn, arìnrìn-àjó lè bá ara rẹ̀ ní ẹnu ìloro àlọ.
mt0: <pad> simply say you don't know to the customs officers who will ask, if the answer is not clear to them, the traveler can find himself at the entrance of the border.</s>

en: For Africans traveling outside the continent, applying for a visa can feel like offering sacrifices to a ravenous god.
yor: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fẹ́ ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè tí kìí ṣe ti adúláwọ̀, ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú máa ń dà bíi ṣíṣe ẹbọ fún òòṣà tí ebi ń pa.
mt0: <pad> For Africans who want to travel outside of Africa, applying for a visa feels like offering a sacrifice to an hungry god.</s>

en: Adéṣínà Ayẹni (Ọmọ Yoòbá), Global Voices Yoruba translation manager, recounts his recent experience trying to procure a visa to Lisbon, Portugal, for the 2019 Creative Commons Summit:
yor: Adéṣínà Ayẹni (Ọmọ Yoòbá), alákòóso Ohùn Àgbáyé ní èdèe Yorùbá, sọ ìríríi rẹ̀ nígbà tí ó ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lúu Lisbon, Portugal, fún àpéròo àwọn alátinúdá 2019 Creative Commons Summit:
mt0: <pad> Adesina Ayeni (Oluwatobi), a World Voices broadcaster in Yoruba, expressed his experience when he applied for a visa to Lisbon, Portugal, for the 2019 Creative Commons Summit of creators.</s>

en: It was the greatest news of my life when I received a mail to deliver a keynote address at the 2019 CC Summit in Lisbon...
yor: Ìdùnnù ǹlá gba ọkàn-an mi nígbà tí mo gba ìròyìn tẹl mí lọ́wọ́ wípé n ó máa sọ̀rọ̀ àkórí ètò níbi Àpérò CC ọdún-un 2019 ní Lisbon. . . .
mt0: <pad> I was very pleased to receive the news that I will be speaking on this topic at the CC Conference 2019 in Lisbon....</s>

en: On April 18, 2019, some days to my birthday, I submitted my visa application to attend the Lisbon summit at the VFS Global office in Lekki, Lagos.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 18 oṣù Igbe, 2019, ọjọ́ díẹ̀ sí àyájọ́ ọjọ́ ìbíì mi, mo kó àwọn ohun tí wọn béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà láti wọ̀lúu Lisbon ki n ba kópa nínúu àpérò náà sílẹ̀ ní ilé-iṣẹ́ẹ VFS Global ní ìdádò Lekki, ní Èkó.
mt0: <pad> On 18 July 2019, a day before my birthday, I lodged the application for a visa to Lisbon to participate in the event at VFS Global in Lekki, Eko.</s>

en: The summit was slated for May 9-11, 2019, but visa processing takes a minimum 15 days.
yor: Ọjọ́ 9 sí 11 ọdún-un 2019 ni àpérò náà ṣùgbọ́n ọjọ́ márùnúndínlógún ni yó gbà fún ìwé ìrìnnà láti jáde fún gbígbà.
mt0: <pad> The event is from 9 to 11 October 2019, but the visa application will be open on March 16 for the departure.</s>

en: On the day I was to depart for Portugal, I still [hadn’t] received my passport...
yor: Lọ́jọ́ tí ó yẹ kí n kúrò nílé fún Portugal, n kòì tí ì rí ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà mi gbà padà...
mt0: <pad> The day before I was due to leave for Portugal, I didn't get my passport back.</s>

en: 11 days after the summit elapsed, I received a text from the VFS for collection of my passport.
yor: ọjọ́ mọ́kànlá lẹ́yìn tí àpérò ti di àfìsẹ́yìn ti eégún aláré ń fiṣọ, mo gba iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ kí n wá gba ìwé-ẹ̀rí-ọmọìlú-fún-ìrìnnà mi ní VFS.
mt0: <pad> 11 days after the deadline for my travel documents had passed, I took a day off to get my passport at VFS.</s>

en: The elders say, you cannot be at your best when sad.
yor: Awọn àgbá bọ̀, inú dídùn l’ó ń mú orí yá.
mt0: <pad> When they come back, it brings joy to my heart.</s>

en: It is one thing that I was not given a visa to attend the summit, another is that the huge scholarship grant to attend the summit went down the drain, wasted.
yor: Ìṣòro kan ni ti àìrí ìwé ìrìnnà gbà, òmíràn ni ti owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ gọbọi tí ó wọlẹ̀ nítori n kò le è lọ si àpérò.
mt0: <pad> One problem is the lack of a visa, the other is the free bus fare that fell because I couldn't go to the meeting.</s>

en: I am miserable because I have not been able to refund the scholarship due to the Central Bank of Nigeria’s policy on wire transfers.
yor: Ìbànújẹ́ gba ọkàn mi poo látàríi àlàálẹ̀ Ilé-Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbà orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà tí kò mú ìfowó ránṣẹ́ sí òkè òkun rọrùn; n kò le è dá owó ìrìnàjò ọ̀fẹ́ tí ó pọn dandan láti dá padà padà fún àwọn tí ó ni owó.
mt0: <pad> I was very disappointed with the announcement of the National Bank of Nigeria that it made money transfers to foreign countries difficult; I could not pay the free travel fee that was required to be paid for the rich.</s>

en: It is excruciatingly painful that my right to associate as a free citizen of the global village was violated.
yor: Ó dùn mí wọ akínyẹmí ara wípé wọ́n gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ẹ̀tọ́ọ mi gẹ́gẹ́ bí olómìnira láti darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ̀ mi.
mt0: <pad> I am very upset that my right as an adult to join my peers has been denied.</s>

en: I was stripped of my voice!
yor: Wọ́n pa ohùn mọ́ mi lẹ́nu!
mt0: <pad> They shouted at me.</s>

en: For Africans traveling within Africa: A painful irony
yor: Ìṣòro: Fún àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀
mt0: <pad> Problem: For Muslims traveling in the Islamic Republic of Iran.</s>

en: It’s difficult for Africans to travel outside Africa — but it can be equally grim to travel within the continent.
yor: Ó ṣòro fún ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ láti ṣe ìrìnàjò jáde kúrò ní Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ — ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó nira láti ṣe ìrìnàjò nílẹ̀ náà.
mt0: <pad> It is difficult for a Solarian to travel outside of the Solar System — but it is also difficult to travel inside the Solar System.</s>

en: Citizens of many countries in the global North can travel to most Africa countries visa-free, or with few restrictions, but the majority of Africans need visas to travel to over half of the other African countries.
yor: Àwọn ọmọ onílùú àìmọye orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà ní Àríwá àgbáńlá ayé lè ṣe ìrìnàjò lọ sí ọ̀pọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ láì ní ìwé ìrìnnà, tàbí pẹ̀lú hìhámọ́ tí ò tó nǹkan, àmọ́ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni ó nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú láti ṣe ìrìnàjò sí ìdajì àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó kù.
mt0: <pad> Children of indigenous nations in the North Pole can travel to many countries in Africa without a visa, or with little or no effort, but most Africans need a national visa to travel to the majority of the rest of the continent.</s>

en: Nigerian Global Voices contributor Rosemary Ajayi captures the "struggle of Africans traveling within Africa":
yor: Aládàásí Ohùn Àgbáyé ọmọbíbí orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà Rosemary Àjàyí ṣe àpèjúwe "ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò ní àárín ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ":
mt0: <pad> Rosemary Ajayi, a native of Nigeria, described the "migration of Africans within Africa" as "the flood of Africans traveling through Africa."</s>

en: I am happy that we, and many others, are highlighting the challenges Africans face getting Western visas.
yor: Inúu mi dùn nítorí wípé à ń gbé ọ̀ràn ohun tí ojú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ máa ń rí ní wọ́n bá béèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Orílẹ̀-èdè òyìnbó àti ohun ti ó tan mọ́ ọn yè wò.
mt0: <pad> I'm happy that we are taking a look at what young people see when they ask for a visa and what they experience.</s>

en: This doesn't annoy me as much as the struggles of Africans travelling within Africa.
yor: Èyí kò gbé mi lọ́kàn bíi ti ìlàkàkà àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> This didn't surprise me like the enthusiasm of many young Europeans traveling in Europe.</s>

en: At RightsCon in Tunis, and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I took the time to ask Africans if they had needed visas.
yor: Ní RightsCon tí ó wáyé ní Tunis, àti GlobalFact tí ó wáyé ní Cape Town, mo bi àwọn Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ bóyá wọ́n ti nílòo ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: <pad> At RightsCon in Tunis, and GlobalFact in Cape Town, I knew Muslims whether they needed a visa.</s>

en: Just this weekend, I learnt of a Nigerian journalist who was unable to attend GlobalFact because he didn't have a visa.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ ìsinmi tí a wà yìí, mo gbọ́ wípé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn ọmọ Nàìjíríà kan kò le è wà níbí GlobalFact nítorí wípé kò ní ìwé ìrìnnà.
mt0: <pad> Last weekend, I heard that a Nigerian journalist couldn't come to GlobalFact because he didn't have a visa.</s>

en: Let's not talk about how most of the African delegates at RightsCon had to fly out of Africa first, in order to get to Tunis.
yor: Kí a máà sọ ti àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó fò kúrò nílẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí wọn ó tó lè wọ Tunis.
mt0: <pad> What about the Tunisians who fled their country before they could enter Tunisia?</s>

en: Last month, I met an East African journalist applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to supply the driver's license of the professional driver picking him up from the airport!
yor: Ní oṣù ti ó kojá, mo ṣe alábàápàdé oníṣẹ́-ìròyìn tí ó wá láti Ìlà-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí ó ń ṣe ìbéèrè fún ìwé ìrìnnà wọ Nàìjíríà. Wọ́n ní kí ó pèsèe ìwé-ẹ̀rí ìwákọ̀ọ ti akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ awakọ̀ tí yóò wá gbé e bí ó bá balẹ̀ ní pápá-ọkọ̀-òfuurufú!
mt0: <pad> Last month, I met a journalist from the East African region who was applying for a visa to Nigeria. He was asked to provide proof of education from a driver's license company that will pick him up at the airport.</s>

en: As Rosemary points out, intra-continental travel is often further complicated by having to travel out of the continent in order to reach a destination within Africa.
yor: Bí Rosemary ti sọ, ìrìnàjò nínúu ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ máa ń gba ṣíṣèrìnàjò kúrò ní ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kí aṣèrìnàjò ó tó le è dé ibi tí ó ń lọ ní àárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> As Rosemary said, a transcontinental journey involves leaving the continent before the traveller can get to where he wants to go within the continent.</s>

en: At the International Air Transport Association (IATA) regional aviation forum in Accra in June, Ghana's Vice President, Dr. Mahamudu Bawumia lamented the fact that “a business person from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, should travel for nearly two days to go to Banjul (often through a third country) for a journey which a straight-line flight would have taken only one hour.”
yor: Ní ibi àpérò òṣìṣẹ́ ọkọ̀-òfuurufú agbègbè tí Àjọ Ìgbókègbódò Ọkọ̀-òfuurufú Àgbáyé (IATA) gbé kalẹ̀ tí ó wáyé ní Accra nínúu oṣù Òkúdù, Igbákejì Ààrẹ Orílẹ̀-èdèe Ghana, Oníṣègùn Mahamudu Bawumia pohùnréré-ẹkún látàríi wípé “ó yẹ oníṣòwò láti Freetown [Sierra Leone], fún àpẹẹrẹ, láti ṣe ìrìnàjò fún ọjọ́ méjì gbáko láti lọ sí Banjul (nípasẹ̀ẹ orílẹ̀-èdè kẹ́ta) fún ìrìnàjò tí kò ju wákàtí kan lọ.“
mt0: <pad> In a speech at the International Air Transport Association's regional conference in Accra in October, the Deputy President of Ghana, Dr. Mahamudu Bawumia expressed concern that "tourists from Freetown [Sierra Leone], for example, have to travel for two days to go to Banjul (through a third country) for a short flight of less than an hour."</s>

en: The convoluted flight routes are then compounded by the extraordinarily high cost of air travel within the continent.
yor: Ìpòyì lórí òfuurufú náà gbọ́mọ pọn pẹ̀lú owó kanangú fífò lókè láàárín Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> The aircraft was full of money flying over the sky between Africa and Asia.</s>

en: Is it true that Africans are unlikely to return home?
yor: Ǹjẹ́ òtítọ́ ni wípé ó ṣeéṣe kí Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ó máà padà wálé?
mt0: <pad> Is it true that the Sun can return to its atmosphere?</s>

en: A rescue operation off the Canary Islands in 2006.
yor: Iṣẹ́ ìdóòlà-ẹ̀mí ní oríi omi Erékùsù Canary ní 2006.
mt0: <pad> Fishing in the waters of the Canary Islands in 2006.</s>

en: Photo by Noborder Network. (CC BY 2.0)
yor: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Noborder Network. (CC BY 2.0)
mt0: <pad> Image by Noborder Network. (CC BY 2.0)</s>

en: Between 2010-2017, migrants from sub-Saharan African countries accounted for the largest migrant population in the world after Syria.
yor: Ni àárín-n ọdún-un 2010-2017, àwọn aṣípòkiri láti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wà lábẹ́ Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara ni ó ṣepò tí ó tẹ̀lé Syria gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìlú tí ó ní ènìyàn tó pọ̀ jù nínú àwọn aṣípòkiri lágbàáyé.
mt0: <pad> In the period 2010 to 2017 migrants from the countries under the Sahara Desert doubled and overtook Syria as the second most populous country in the world for refugees.</s>

en: Many Africans leave the countries fleeing poverty or violent conflict, to seek asylum, refugee status or permanent residence in North America or Europe.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ń sá kúrò nílùú nítorí ebi àti rògbòdìyàn, láti wábi forípamọ́síeek, didi ogúnlémidébí tàbí didi agbélùú ní Àréwá Amẹ́ríkà tàbí ní Éróòpù.
mt0: <pad> Many Ethiopians flee their villages for poverty and hunger, to seek a better life, higher education or higher status in the United States or Europe.</s>

en: A 2018 Pew Research study reports that the number of migrants from sub-Saharan Africa "grew by 50% or more between 2010 and 2017, significantly more than the 17% worldwide average increase for the same period".
yor: Àbájáde Ìwádìí Pew ọdún-un 2018 sọ wípé iye àwọn aṣípòkiri láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "ti fi ìdá 50 lọ sókè tàbí jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ ní àárín-in ọdún-un 2010 àti 2017, ju gbogbo rẹ̀ lọ wọn ju ìdá 17 lọ káríayé ní àsìkò kan náà".
mt0: <pad> The Pew Research Center 2018 report said the number of migrants from the Southern Sahara "has grown by 50 percent or more between 2010 and 2017, and has gone global by 17 percent at the same time."</s>

en: Sub-Saharan Africans are also emigrating to countries far and wide.
yor: Awọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara náà ń ṣí kiri orílẹ̀-èdè jákèjádò àgbáyé.
mt0: <pad> The migrants from the Southern Sahara are scattered throughout the world.</s>

en: In 2014, over 170,000 migrants without legal documents ferried across the Mediterranean Sea to Italy.
yor: Ní ọdún-un 2014, ó tó aṣíkiri 170,000 tí ò ní ìwé-àṣẹ lábẹ́ òfin ni ó ń wọ ọkọ̀ gba orí òkun Mediterranean lọ sí orílẹ̀-èdè Italy.
mt0: <pad> In 2014, approximately 170,000 undocumented migrants crossed the Mediterranean Sea to Italy by ship.</s>

en: Many hailed from sub-Saharan Africa.
yor: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ ló wá láti àwọn Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara.
mt0: <pad> The word came from the southern cities of the Sahara.</s>

en: In December 2018, Brazilian police rescued 25 sub-Saharan African nationals who had “been at sea for over a month” in the Atlantic Ocean.
yor: Ní oṣù Ọ̀pẹ ọdún-un 2018, Ọlọ́pàá Brazil dóòlà ẹ̀mí èèyàn 25 ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ tí ó wá láti Ìlú Gúúsù Aṣálẹ̀ Sahara "tí ó ti wà lọ́rí omi òkun Atlantic fún oṣù kan gbáko".
mt0: <pad> In August 2018, the Brazilian police rescued 25 refugees from the Sahara "who had been on the Atlantic for a full month."</s>

en: The travelers had paid “hundreds of dollars apiece” for the trip from Cape Verde. In June 2019, US Customs and Border Protection in Del Rio, Texas, USA, arrested more than 500 Africans from Republic of the Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, and Angola, for trying to cross into the USA via the Rio Grande River.
yor: Àwọn arìnrìnàjòó san "ẹgbẹlẹmùkù owó lọ́wọ́ ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan" fún ìrìnàjò láti Cape Verde. Ní oṣù Òkúdù ọdún-un 2019, US Customs Àjọ Aṣọ́bodè àti Ààbò Ibodè US ní Del Rio, Texas, USA, fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìkún òfin mú àwọn ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ 500 tí ó wà láti Ilẹ̀-olómìnira Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, àti Angola, tí wọn ń fẹ́ gba omi Odò Rio Grande wọ USA.
mt0: <pad> Tourists paid "a hundred dollars per person" for the trip from Cape Verde. In October 2019, US Customs and Border Protection in Del Rio, Texas, USA, formally arrested 500 illegal immigrants from the Republic of Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, and Angola, who were trying to cross the Rio Grande into the United States through the waters of the Rio Grande.</s>

en: While dominant narratives in the media perpetuate Africa as a continent of mass migration driven by poverty or violent conflict, however, Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, scholars from University of Oxford and University of Amsterdam, respectively, take issue with this stereotype.
yor: Onírúurú ìròyìn ni ó ti rò ó wípé Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ ni àárín-ín gbùngùn òtòṣì àti ogun, síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, Marie-Laurence Flahaux àti Hein De Haas, àwọn onímọ̀ láti Ifásitì ti Oxford àti Ifásitì ti Amsterdam, ní ṣísẹ̀ntèlé, kò gbà pé bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ó rí.
mt0: <pad> There have been many reports that the Middle East is in a state of economic and political upheaval, however, Marie-Laurence Flahaux and Hein De Haas, researchers from the University of Oxford and the University of Amsterdam, respectively, do not agree that this has happened.</s>

en: Flahaux and De Haas argue that these narratives are propagated not only by "media and politicians" but also by scholars.
yor: Flahaux àti De Haas jiyàn wípé kò rí bí ìròyín ti ṣe rò ó sí etígbọ̀ọ́ ọmọ aráyé pàápàá "àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ àti olóṣòlú" àti àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n náà.
mt0: <pad> Flahaux and De Haas argue that they don't see how the media has been so successful in getting people to listen, particularly "the companies and bosses" and the scientists.</s>

en: Their research shows that migration from the continent is multi-layered and driven by global "processes of development and social transformation" that have increased the "capabilities and aspirations" of Africans’ to migrate — similar to migrants from other parts of the world.
yor: Iṣẹ́ ìwádìí fi yé wípé àwọn ìṣípòkiri láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ kò déédéé wáyé, ohun tí ó fà á ni "ìlànà ìdàgbàsókè àti ìyípadà àwùjọ" èyí tí ó ń mú ṣíṣíkiri lọ sí àwọn agbègbè àgbáyé wu Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ — tí kò yàtọ̀ sí aṣípòkiri láti ibòmìíràn lágbàáyé.
mt0: <pad> The study found that the migration from Africa was not a common phenomenon, attributing it to the "system of development and social change" that led Africans to migrate to other parts of the world — not different from other migrants from other parts of the world.</s>

en: These stereotypical narratives, however, often inform visa policy:

mt0: <pad> These misleading reports, which are often caused by the visa application process, are responsible for the cancellation of many visas.</s>

en: Most countries’ authorities assume that all Africans who travel will not return to their home countries, leaving African visa applicants to bear the burden of proof.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè ni ó nígbàgbọ́ wípé gbogbo arìnrìnàjò tí ó bá jẹ́ Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ ni kò ní padà sí orílẹ̀-èdèe rẹ̀, àfi bí arìnrìnàjó bá ní ẹ̀rí tí ó yanrantí tó ni ó lè rí ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú gbà.
mt0: <pad> Many countries believe that all non-European travellers are not to be repatriated, unless the traveller has sufficient proof that he can prove his presence in the country.</s>

en: Getting non-African nations to take a more nuanced approach to visa approvals for African nationals is a long battle.
yor: Kò rọrùn láti ṣí ojú àwọn tí kì í ṣe ọmọ-adúláwọ̀ lójú nípa orúkọ búburú tí wọn ti sọ orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó wá láti Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀.
mt0: <pad> It is not easy to convince non-Africans of the negative name that they have given the country that came from Africa.</s>

en: Meanwhile, African nations can take action to improve mobility across the continent.

mt0: <pad> Today, African countries are working towards a system for the movement and repatriation of Africans. A single passport for all African countries is a good idea — but not enough.</s>

en: A common African passport is one step  — but it's not enough. The Single African Air Transport market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, both launched last year, have laid the foundation for some of these shifts, but widespread implementation is still a long way off.
yor: Single African Air Transport market náà (SAATM), àti Continental Free Trade Agreement náà, tí a fi lọ́lẹ̀ lọ́dún tí ó kọjá, ti se àlàálẹ̀ ìgbésẹ̀ wọ̀nyí, ṣùgbọ́n ìmúṣẹ ṣì kù díẹ̀ káàtó.
mt0: <pad> The Single African Air Transport Market (SAATM), and the Continental Free Trade Agreement, signed last year, have already outlined these measures, but the implementation is still a long way off.</s>

en: Meanwhile, as an African, to dare to travel is to be subjected to cruel humiliations when travelling outside Africa — or to be jolted out of the fantasy of African unity by the harshness of travelling within the continent.
yor: Lásìkò yìí, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Ọmọ-adúláwọ̀, ìyànjú láti rìnrìnàjò ni láti ní ìrírí ìrẹnisílẹ̀ tí àwọn tí ó ń se ìrìnàjò lọ sí òkè-òkun ń rí — tàbí jẹ́ títají nínú àlà ìsọ̀kan Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ tí kò sí.
mt0: <pad> Nowadays, as a Native American, the attempt to travel is to experience the indigenous culture that foreign tourists see — or to be a part of the Native American community that is not present in the map.</s>

mt0: <pad> Because of this, it was difficult for him to follow the international news during the 2019 election.</s>

en: False and misleading information, promoted as gospel truth, was amplified by supporters of the two major parties in Nigeria: the All Progressive Congress (APC) and the People's Democratic Party (PDP).
yor: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú ni wọ́n polongo gẹ́gẹ́ ìhìn rere tòótọ́, tí àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì tí ó gbajúmọ̀ jù lọ ní orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà sì lukoro rẹ̀: Àjọ Ìtẹ̀síwájú Gbogboògbò All Progressive Congress (APC) àti Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú Ìjọba-tiwantiwa Àwọn Ènìyàn People's Democratic Party (PDP).
mt0: <pad> A false news was promoted as good news, and the supporters of the two powerful political parties in Nigeria: All Progressive Congress (APC) and People's Democratic Party (PDP) endorsed it.</s>

en: Based on ethnographic participant observation conducted between October 28, 2018, and May 29, 2019, ethnic hate was employed as a tool for disinformation and propaganda by both sides of the political divide on Twitter Nigeria during the 2019 presidential elections.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìkíyèsí ẹ̀yà tí ó wáyé láàárín ọjọ́ 28 oṣù kẹwàá, 2018, àti ọjọ́ 29, oṣù karùn-ún 2019, ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin jẹ́ irinṣẹ́ fún ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n ń'nú tí ó kún fún irọ́ láti sàkání ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú méjèèjì ní oríi Twitter ti Nàìjíríà lásìkò ìbò ààrẹ 2019.
mt0: <pad> As a result of the 28th and 29th of October, 2018, and 29th of June 2019, the term 'blackout' is a tool for fake news and lies to separate two Nigerian politicians on Twitter during the presidential election in Nigeria.</s>

en: These observations were captured as screengrabs of tweets or saved URLs collected over this period.
yor: A ká àwọn ìkíyèsí yìí sílẹ̀ láti orí ayélujára ní àsìkò yìí.
mt0: <pad> We are going to publish these certificates on the internet at this time.</s>

en: In terms of ethnically-charged disinformation, some APC supporters accused Obi of being a bigot for purportedly deporting northerners while he was governor of Anambra State, in southeast Nigeria.
yor: Tí a bá sọ nípa ìròyìn irọ́ nípa ti ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà, àwọn agbárùkù ti ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlúu APC yọ ẹnu ìwọ̀sí sí Obi lára nítorí pé ó dá àwọn ará òkè Ọya padà nígbà tí ó wà lórí ipò gẹ́gẹ́ bí aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Anambra, ní ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> If we talk about ethnicity, the APC officials praised Obi for restoring the Oya people to their homes when he was governor of Anambra state, north-eastern Nigeria.</s>

en: Tweets went viral that claimed that Yoruba people were burning shops of Igbo traders in Lagos. Both stories were false and will be explored further in Part II of this essay.
yor: Túwíìtì tàn kárí ilé kárí oko tí ó sọ pé àwọn ọmọ Yorùbá ń tiná bọ ìsọ̀ àwọn oníṣòwò tí ó jẹ́ ẹ̀yà Igbo ní Èkó. Irọ́ funfun báláwú ni àwọn ìròyìn wọ̀nyí, a ó gbé e yẹ̀ wò síwájú sí i nínú Apá kejì àròkọ yìí.
mt0: <pad> Tweets spread like wildfire that said Yoruba people were threatening to kill Igbo workers in Eko. These tweets are white lies, we will look into them in Part 2 of this article.</s>

en: Figure 1: Misinformed propaganda tweet by Festus Keyamo
yor: Àwòrán 1: Túwíìtì irọ́ ti Festus Keyamo
mt0: <pad> Image 1: The false flag of Festus Keyamo</s>

en: Figure 2: The true location of the image that Keyamo shared.
yor: Àwòrán 2: Àṣírí bi tí àwòrán tí Keyamo tari síta wà ní ti òtítọ́.
mt0: <pad> Image 2: The content of the image that Keyamo took is true.</s>

en: In another example, a photograph was used to misconstrue facts. On October 28, 2018, Festus Keyamo, then-media director of the Buhari Campaign Organisation, tweeted an image (Figure 1) of a tree growing between an apparently abandoned Nigerian rail track:
yor: Fún àpẹẹrẹ òmíràn, a lo àwòrán kan báyìí lọ́nà tí kò yẹ. Lọ́jọ́ 28, oṣù kẹwàá, ọdún-un, 2018, Festus Keyamo, olùdarí ètò ìkéde àná fún Iléeṣẹ́ Ìpolongo fún Buhari, túwíìtì àwòrán kan (Aworan 1) ti igi kan tí ó ń wù láàárín ojú irin kan tí ó ti di àpatì:
mt0: <pad> For another example, an image was used inappropriately. On 28 October 2018, Festus Keyamo, the director of media for the Buhari campaign office, tweeted an image (Figure 1) of a tree falling between a rusty train that had been damaged.</s>

en: This is how trees grew in-between rail tracks between 1999 and 2015...
yor: Bí igí ṣe ń wù sí àárín ojú irin ní 1999 sí 2015...
mt0: <pad> How the passengers commute on train from 1999 to 2015</s>

en: Now, this is the 'Completion Era' as the tracks are beginning to roar back to life.” The PDP government was in power between 1999 and 2015.
yor: Báyìí, ‘Sáà Ìparí iṣẹ́’ rè é, àwọn ojú irin náà ti ń jí padà sáyé.” Ìjọba PDP ló ń tukọ̀ ètò ní 1999 sí 2015.
mt0: <pad> Now, at the end of the 'work hours', the trains are back on the tracks." The PDP government was planning for this project from 1999 to 2015.</s>

en: However, a Nigerian Twitter user later traced back the image to an original Arabic-language tweet (Figure 2) posted earlier that same month.
yor: Lẹ́yìn-ò-rẹyìn, òǹlò Twitter kan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà tọ ipasẹ̀ẹ àwòrán náà sí túwíìtì kan lédèe Lárúbáwá (Àwòrán 2) tí ẹnìkan tari síta nínú oṣù yẹn.
mt0: <pad> Afterwards, a Nigerian Twitter user posted the image on Saturday night (Image 2) that was shared by someone else in the same month.</s>

en: According to the tweet, the photo is from Lebanon.
yor: Túwíìtì náà jẹ́rìí wípé Lebanon ni àwòrán ọ̀hún ti ṣẹ̀ wá.
mt0: <pad> The tweet claimed that the image of the plane was taken in Lebanon.</s>

en: Keyamo's intention may have been to show that the Buhari government had surpassed previous administrations on the revamping of the morbid rail lines in the country.
yor: Ohun tí Keyamo fẹ́ ṣe ni láti fi hàn wípé ìṣàkóso ìjọba Buhari ti gbé ìgbésẹ̀ àtúnṣe sí àwọn ọ̀nà ọkọ̀ọ ojú irin tí ìjọba àná pa tì.
mt0: <pad> What Keyamo wanted to do was to show that the Buhari administration has taken action to rebuild the railways that the previous governments have closed.</s>

en: However, the use of an image from a different country made the so-called "gains" questionable.
yor: Àmọ́ ṣá, àwòrán orílẹ̀-èdè mìíràn tí ó lò láti fi sọ "ìtẹ̀síwájú" náà, fọ́ gbogbo rẹ̀ lójú.
mt0: <pad> But the image of another country used to say "progress" destroyed everything.</s>

en: Figure 3: Ethnic hate speech
yor: Àwòrán 3: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin
mt0: <pad> Image 3: The Gender Races of the World</s>

en: Figure 4: El-Rufai later apologized for the “insensitive” tweet shown in Figure 3.
yor: Àwòrán 4: El-Rufai tọrọ àforíjì fún túwíìtì “tí ó lè dá wàhálà sílẹ̀” náà tí ó wà ń'nú Àwòrán 3.
mt0: <pad> Image 4: El-Rufai apologized for the "potentially deadly" tweets he posted</s>

en: Online ethnic hate speech was also pronounced before, during and after the elections.
yor: Ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra ẹ̀yà tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin ṣẹ́ yọ kí ọjọ́ ìbò ó tó kò, lásìkò ìbò àti lẹ́yìn ìbò.
mt0: <pad> Political violence occurs before, during and after the election.</s>

en: In an ethnic slurred tweet (Figure 3) Bashir El-Rufai, son of the Kaduna State Governor, inferred that the Nigerian Civil War was ignited by the Igbo vengeance.
yor: Túwíìtì ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà kan (Àwòrán 3) Bashir El-Rufai, ọmọ Aláṣẹ Ìpínlẹ̀ Kaduna, wí pé ẹ̀yà Igbo ló fi ìbínú tan iná ọ̀tẹ̀ tí ó fa Ogun Abẹ́lée Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> A political tweet (Photo 3) Bashir El-Rufai, governor of Kaduna state, said the Igbo people were the ones who ignited the fire that sparked the Civil War in Nigeria.</s>

en: Between 1967 and 1970, Nigeria fought a bitter civil war with the secessionist state of Biafra inhabited mostly by the Igbo in the southeastern part of the country.
yor: Láàárín 1967 sí 1970, orílẹ̀-èdèe Nàìjíríà ja ogun kíkorò kan pẹ̀lú ìlúu Biafra tí í ṣe àwọn ẹ̀yà Igbo tí ó wà ní apá ìlà-oòrùn gúúsù, tí ó ń gbèrò láti pín yà kúrò lábẹ́ ìṣàkóso ìjọba Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> From 1967 to 1970, Nigeria fought a bloody war with Biafra, the Igbo-speaking state in north-eastern Nigeria, which wanted to break away from the control of the Nigerian government.</s>

en: Hence, according to Bashir El-Rufai, the result of the 2019 elections which was won by his party, the APC, should also be taken as a sweet "revenge" from the Hausa, Fulani.
yor: Síbẹ̀, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Bashir El-Rufai ti ṣe sọ, àbájáde ìbò ọdún-un 2019 tí ẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀, APC, gbégbà-orókè. Ó yẹ kí a rí i bíi “ẹ̀san” láti apá ọ̀dọ̀ àwọn ẹ̀yà Hausa, Fulani.
mt0: <pad> But, as Bashir El-Rufai has said, the result of the 2019 election should be seen as a "gift" from the Hausa, Fulani youths.</s>

en: He later apologized, after a backlash, for his previous "insensitive" tweet as shown in Figure 4.
yor: Ó padà wá á tọrọ àforíjì, lẹ́yìn tí a ti bu ẹnu àtẹ́ lù ú, fún túwíìtì "tí ó lè dá wàhálà sílẹ̀ " bí a ti rí i nínú Àwòrán.
mt0: <pad> He also apologized, after being accused of making a tweet "potentially defamatory," as he was seen in the pictures.</s>

en: He also deleted the earlier tweet (Figure 3).
yor: Bákan náà ni ó mú túwíìtì ìsọkúsọ náà wálẹ̀ (Àwòrán 3).
mt0: <pad> He also took down the landing site (Figure 3).</s>

en: Ethnic-motivated false information on social media during the elections falls into two categories: disinformation and propaganda.
yor: Ìròyìn irọ́ tí ó ti ara ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà wá lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà lásìkò ìbò ṣe é pín sábẹ́ ẹ̀ka méjì: ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú àti ìròyìn irọ́.
mt0: <pad> Politically motivated fake news on social media during the election was classified into two categories: unsubstantiated and misleading.</s>

en: Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, communication scholars at the University of Zagreb, Croatia, define disinformation as "intentionally deputed mistaken information with the purpose to mislead the user".
yor: Miroslav Tudjman àti Nives Mikelic, ọ̀mọ̀wé nípa ìtàkùrọ̀sọ ní Ifáfitì ti Zagreb, Croatia, túmọ̀ ìròyìn tí kò ní gbọ́ngbọ́n nínú sí "ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣi àwọn ènìyàn lọ́kàn".
mt0: <pad> Miroslav Tudjman and Nives Mikelic, a media expert at the Institute of Zagreb, Croatia, define fake news as "intentionally spreading information to deceive the people."</s>

en: Hence, the intention to pass across inaccurate, distorted and false evidence as true, distinguishes dis-information from misinformation.
yor: Ète títari ìròyìn irọ́ síta bí òtítọ́, ló ya ìròyìn tí ó ń ṣini lọ́kàn àti ìròyìn irọ́ sọ́tọ́.
mt0: <pad> They spread lies as truths, spread false information and false propaganda.</s>

en: Tudjman and Mikelic assert that propaganda is much more than disinformation or misinformation.
yor: Tudjman àti Mikelic sọ wípé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn fẹ̀jú ju ìròyìn àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ tari síta láti ṣini lọ́kàn tàbí ìròyìn irọ́ lọ.
mt0: <pad> Tudjman and Mikelic said that the spread of information was faster than the spread of false or misleading information.</s>

en: This is because propaganda "aims to manipulate the attitudes of the user" through an "accidental or intentional handling with information in [the] communication process".
yor: Ìdí ni pé ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn "máa ń yí ìhùwàsí ẹni padà" nípasẹ̀ "ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àìròtẹ́lẹ̀ kan tàbí ìgbésẹ̀ àmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ dá lásìkò ìtari ìtàkùrọ̀sọ [náà] síta".
mt0: <pad> Because media "change behavior" through "a sudden event or an intentional action that occurs at the time of the release of [the] news report."</s>

en: Thus, propaganda weaponizes biased or inaccurate information for political interests and consequently manipulates perception.
yor: Bí irú èyí, ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn máa ń tẹ̀sí apá kan tàbí àìpé ìròyìn fún àǹfààní ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú àti yíyí ìrònú padà níparí.
mt0: <pad> In this way, the media often favours one side or not giving any information for the benefit of politicians and their political debate and re-evaluation.</s>

en: Justifiable fears emerged surrounding 2019 elections because online disinformation and propaganda incites electoral violence but also poses "a threat to reconciliation after the elections".
yor: Ìbẹ̀rùbojo ọkàn bẹ́ sílẹ̀ látàrí ìbò ọdún-un 2019 nítorí ìròyìn irọ́ àti ọ̀nà ìtànkálẹ̀ ìròyìn ń ṣe àgbédìde àìbalẹ̀ ọkàn tí ó ti ọ̀rọ̀ ìbò bẹ̀rẹ̀ àmọ́ tí ó ń fa "ìdẹ́rùbà fún ìparí-ìjà tí ìbòó bá kásẹ̀ ńlẹ̀ ".
mt0: <pad> The 2019 elections have been marred by fake news and media coverage of the election campaign, which has already sparked anger that has been simmering since the election campaign began but which is causing "a predisposition for war if the election results are declared."</s>

en: Part II of this essay will examine how this played out online, especially on Twitter, with specific examples.
yor: Apá kejì àròkọ yìí yóò ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò bí èyí ṣe wáyé lórí ayélujára, pàápàá lóríi gbàgede Twitter, pẹ̀lú àwọn àpẹẹrẹ mélòó kan.
mt0: <pad> The second part of this article will explore how this has happened on the internet, particularly on Twitter, with a few thousand examples.</s>

en: This article is part of a series of posts examining interference with digital rights through methods such as network shutdowns and disinformation during key political events in seven African countries: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.
yor: Àpilẹ̀kọ yìí jẹ́ ara àtẹ̀jádé ìròyìn oníṣísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé tí ó ń ṣe àgbéyẹ̀wò ìṣúsí pẹ̀lú ẹ̀tọ́ ìlò ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá nípa àwọn ìlànà bíi ìṣánpa ìṣàsopọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere àti ìròyìn ẹlẹ́jẹ̀ lásìkò ètò ìṣèlú tí ó pọn dandan ní orílẹ̀-èdè méje ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nàìjíríà, Tunisia, Uganda, àti Zimbabwe.
mt0: <pad> This article is part of a series of press releases that investigate the impact of censorship and copyright on political violence through measures such as internet blockade and anonymous news during the 2014 African elections: Algeria, Ethiopia, Mozambique, Nigeria, Tunisia, Uganda, and Zimbabwe.</s>

en: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).
yor: Africa Digital Rights Fund àti The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) ni agbátẹrù iṣẹ́ àkànṣe yìí.
mt0: <pad> Africa Digital Rights Fund and The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) are the co-sponsors of this initiative.</s>

en: From Kenya to Ethiopia, these men received divine dream ‘maps’ to carve caves
yor: Ní Kenya àti Ethiopia, àwọn ọkùnrin wọ̀nyí ríran ‘àwòrán-ìtọ́nà’ àt'ọ̀run wá láti gbẹ́ ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀
mt0: <pad> In Kenya and Ethiopia, these men saw the "image of God" and the "angel" come to dry the caves under the earth.</s>

en: Both men say they received explicit instructions from God
yor: Àwọn ọkùnrin méjèèjì sọ wípé Ọlọ́run ló yọ sí àwọn
mt0: <pad> The two men said that God had angry them.</s>

en: Dunbar caves in southern Ethiopia were dug by Mohammed Yiso Banatah with his bare hands.
yor: Ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ Dunbar ní gúúsù Ethiopia tí Mohammed Yiso Banatah gbẹ́ jáde pẹ̀lú ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ láì lo ohunkóhun.
mt0: <pad> The cave under the Dunbar Mountain in Ethiopia that Mohammed Yiso Banatah sculpted with his own hands without using any tools.</s>

en: He was instructed by Allah to create underground wedding chapels.
yor: Allah l'ó pa á láṣẹ láti gbẹ́ ilé Ọlọ́run fún ètò ìgbéyàwó sísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> Allah ordered him to clean the house of God for the purpose of marriage on earth.</s>

en: Photo by Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein, used with permission.
yor: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein, a fi àṣẹ lò ó.
mt0: <pad> Image by Amanda Leigh Lichtenstein, licensed.</s>

en: On December 26, 2019, BBC Swahili released a video featuring Francisco Ouma, an elder from Busia, western Kenya, who received a message from God to carve a cave.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 26 oṣù Ọ̀pẹ, BBC Swahili gbé àwòrán-àtohùn kan tí ó ṣe àfihàn-an Francisco Ouma, ẹni àgbà kan láti Busia, ìlà-oòrùnun Kenya, ẹni tí ó gbọ́ ohùn Ọlọ́run láti gbẹ́ ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ jáde.
mt0: <pad> On August 26, BBC Swahili broadcast a documentary featuring Francisco Ouma, an aged man from Busia, north-eastern Kenya, who heard God's voice to dig a hole in the ground.</s>

en: The message came in the form of a map that he received through his dreams.
yor: Ìran náà wá nípasẹ̀ àwòrán ìtọ́nà tí ó rí lójú àwọn àláa rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> The idea came from the image of justice he saw in his dream.</s>

en: Since February 1967, Ouma has followed the divine map delivered in his dream.
yor: Láti inú oṣù kejì ọdún-un 1967, ni Ouma ti ń tọ ipasẹ̀ẹ ìtọ́nà látọ̀run wá náà tí ó gbà Iójú àláa rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> From February 1967, Ouma has been following the path of divine grace that led to his death.</s>

en: Today, his cave has 24 rooms and counting.
yor: Lónìí, ihò nísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀ ti ní yàrá 24 tí ó sì ń lé sí i.
mt0: <pad> Today, the cave under his feet has 24 rooms and is growing.</s>

en: Screenshot of Francis Ouma, who received a message from God to carve a cave with 24 rooms via BBC Swahili / Instagram.
yor: Àgékù àwòrán-an Francis Ouma, tí ó gbọ́ ohùn Ọlọ́run láti gbẹ́ ihò sísàlẹ̀ ilẹ̀ tí ó ní 24 ìyàrá lóríi BBC Swahili / Instagram.
mt0: <pad> Francis Ouma, a photographer who heard God's voice to dig a hole down the land with 24 houses on BBC Swahili / Instagram.</s>

en: Throughout history, many have questioned the veracity of divine intervention through dreams, even casting doubt on one's mental health and stability.
yor: Láti ayébáyé, ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ló ti ní kò sí ẹ̀rí tí ó dájú wípé ìran àt'ọ̀run wá ni àwọn irú àlá báwọ̀nyí, tí wọn ń dẹ́jàá ìlera ọpọlọ irú ẹni bẹ́ẹ̀ tí ó pé òún ríran lójú àlá.
mt0: <pad> From the beginning, many people have claimed that there is no clear evidence that such dreams exist, and have questioned the brain power of those who say they have seen in dreams.</s>

en: But prophets from Islam, Judaism and Christianity have all testified to messages from God sent through dreams for millennia.
yor: Àmọ́ àwọn òjíṣẹ́ ẹ̀sìn Ìmàle, Júù àti Onígbàgbọ́ gbogboó ti jẹ́rìí sí ìran láti ọ̀dọ̀ Ọlọ́run ent tí ó wá lójú àlá fún ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún ọdún.
mt0: <pad> But the chief priests of Israel, Judah and the Christian have all denied the revelation from God, who has been hidden for thousands of years.</s>

en: "God brought me something like a map", Ouma told BBC Swahili.
yor: "Ọlọ́run fi nǹkankan bí àwòrán-ìtọ́nà hàn mí", Ouma sọ fún BBC Swahili.
mt0: <pad> "God showed me something like a picture," Ouma told the BBC.</s>

en: Then, when I was digging, this map is what I followed.
yor: Nígbà yẹn, nígbà tí mò ń wa ilẹ̀, àwòrán-ìtọ́nà yìí ni mo tẹ̀lé.
mt0: <pad> When I was going down, I followed this picture.</s>

en: It wasn't just that when I was digging, better to keep digging, no.
yor: Kì í ṣe nígbà tí mò ń walẹ̀ nìkan, ó dára jù kí n máa walẹ̀ lọ, rárá.
mt0: <pad> Not only when I'm playing, it's better to play all the time.</s>

en: Using just a plow and his own two hands, Ouma faced trial and error as he hit on stones that prevented him from digging.
yor: Ìtúlẹ̀ àti ọwọ́ọ rẹ̀ méjèèjì ni ó lò, Ouma kan àwọn òkúta abẹ́lẹ̀ tí kò mú ìwalẹ̀ náà rọrùn fún un.
mt0: <pad> He used a step and both his hands, Ouma complained about the bottom stones that didn't make it easy for him to get down.</s>
