en: On October 22, Burundian security forces battled with an armed anti-government group — reportedly RED-Tabara, based in the Democratic Republic of Congo — around the Kibira forest border area.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 22, oṣù Ọ̀wàrà, àwọn ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò Burundi wà á kò pẹ̀lú ẹgbẹ́ agbébọrìn alátakò ìjọba kan — tí à ń pè ní RED-Tabara, tí ó fi Democratic Republic of Congo ṣe ilé — ní agbègbè ibodè igbó Kibira.
mt0: <pad> On August 22, Burundian security forces came into conflict with a rebel cattle group - the Red Tabara, based in the Democratic Republic of Congo - near the Kibira mountain crossing in the province of Kibira.</s>

en: Armed groups have often used this area to move through the region.
yor: Àwọn ẹgbẹ́ ọlọ́tẹ̀ agbébọrìn ti máa ń fi ibí yìí kiri àgbègbè náà.
mt0: <pad> Farmers' organizations have been using this plant to make their own fertilizer.</s>

en: In the battle, 14 insurgents were said to be killed, while security forces suffered about 10 casualties.
yor: Nínú ìjà akátá náà, àwọn agbébọrìn 14 ni ikú pa, tí ẹ̀ṣọ́ aláàbò 10 sì bá a lọ.
mt0: <pad> In the afternoon battle, 14 farmers were killed, and 10 guards were killed.</s>

en: Later that day, police detained the four Iwacu journalists and their driver, Adolphe Masabarakiza, when they went to report at the Musigati commune, Bubanza province, to speak to people who had fled the fighting.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ yẹn náà, àwọn ọlọ́pàá fi àwọn akọ̀ròyìn Iwacu mẹ́rin àti awakọ̀ wọn Adolphe Masabaakiza sí àtìmọ́lé, nígba tí wọn lọ kóròyìn jọ ní àdúgbò Musigati, ní Bubanza, níbi tí wọ́n ti fẹ́ bá àwọn ènìyàn tí ó sá kúrò ní àdúgbò nígbà tí ìjà náà bẹ́ sílẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> On the same day, police detained four Iwacu journalists and their driver Adolphe Masabaakiza while they were investigating at Musigati farm in Bubanza, where they were trying to contact the people who fled the farm when the fighting broke out.</s>

en: At first, they were detained without charge, and Christine Kamikazi was reportedly hit when arrested.
yor: Lákọ̀ọ́kọ́, a fi wọn sí àtìmọ́lé láì fi ẹ̀sùn kàn wọ́n, tí a sì lu Christine Kamikazi nígbà tí wọ́n mú wọn.
mt0: <pad> First, they were taken into custody without charges, and Christine Kamikazi was beaten when she was arrested.</s>

en: Police confiscated their phones and materials and the intelligence services demanded account passwords in order to search their phones.
yor: Ọlọ́pàá gba ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ àti àwọn ohun èlò iṣẹ́ wọn tí àwọn ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ sí béèrè fún gbólóhùn ìfiwọlé sí orí ẹ̀rọ wọn láti yẹ̀ ẹ́ wò fínnífínní.
mt0: <pad> Police confiscated the victims' cell phones and other work equipment and requested for their passwords to access their computers.</s>

en: The journalists were then transferred to other cells with deplorable conditions.
yor: Àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà di ẹni tí à ń gbé kiri lọ sí túbú mìíràn tí kò sunwọ̀n.
mt0: <pad> The reporters looked like they were being carried to another unfamiliar tub.</s>

en: On October 26, in Bubanza province, they were finally charged with "complicity in threatening state security".
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 26 oṣù Kẹwàá, ní Bubanza, a jàjà fẹ̀sùn "Ìlọ́wọ́sí ìdúkokò mọ́ ààbò ìlú" kàn wọ́n.
mt0: <pad> On October 26, in Bubanza, we were arrested for "Delaying the protection of the city."</s>

en: On October 31, the public prosecutor confirmed this and accused them of having information on the insurgents’ attack.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 31, oṣù Kẹwàá, abánirojọ̀ náà fi ẹ̀rí èyí lélẹ̀ ó sì fẹ̀sùn kàn wọ́n ní pé wọ́n mọ̀ sí ìkọlù àwọn kọ̀lọ̀rànsí ẹ̀dá náà.
mt0: <pad> On October 31, the court presented this evidence and charged them with knowing about the abuse of the wildlife conservationists.</s>

en: Various organizations promptly called for their release, including Human Rights Watch, International Federation of Journalists, Olucome, African Journalists’ Federation and the Association Burundaise des Radiodiffuseurs.
yor: Àwọn iléeṣẹ́ ní ẹ̀ka-ò-jẹ̀ka ni ó ti pè fún ìdásílẹ̀ wọn, títí kan Human Rights Watch, International Federation of Journalists, Olucome, African Journalists’ Federation àti Àjọ Burundaise des Radiodiffuseurs.
mt0: <pad> He has already invited several media organizations to join him, including Human Rights Watch, International Federation of Journalists, Olucome, African Journalists' Federation and the Burundian Radio and Television Broadcasters' Association.</s>

en: However, the National Communications Council said at the time that it could not discuss the matter.
yor: Síbẹ̀, Iléeṣẹ́ Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ Àpapọ̀ sọ wí pé àwọn kò tíì lè sọ sí ọ̀ràn náà báyìí.
mt0: <pad> However, the National Radio Corporation said that they cannot comment on the report at this time.</s>

en: Iwacu criticized this reaction, recalling that they were first held without charge and that the council is supposed to support journalists.
yor: Iwacu bu ẹnu àtẹ́ ohun tí àjọ náà sọ, ní pé wọn kò fẹ̀sùn kankan kàn wọ́n nígbà tí wọ́n mú wọn àti pé ojúṣe àjọ náà ni láti gbèjà àwọn akọ̀ròyìn.
mt0: <pad> Iwacu denied the organization's statement, saying that they were not charged when they were arrested and that the organization's role was to protect journalists.</s>

en: Many people expressed support online and signed a petition. International media discussed it as a threat to press freedom, while Iwacu continues to follow the situation closely.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ní ó gbè lẹ́yìn àwọn akọ̀ròyìnnáà tí wọ́n sì fi ọwọ́ bọ ìfẹ̀sùnkàn lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára. Àwọn iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìn ríi gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìfojú-ẹ̀tọ̀ sí òmìnira oníròyìn gbolẹ̀, tí Iwacu sì ń tọ okùn ọ̀ràn náà lọ pẹ́kípẹ́kí.
mt0: <pad> Many people took to the internet to protest the reports and sign a petition. Media outlets saw it as a violation of press freedom, and Iwacu was taking the lead in the warning.</s>

en: Journalist Esdras Ndikumana tweeted:
yor: Akọ̀ròyìn Esdras Ndikumana túwíìtì:
mt0: <pad> Esdras àti ìdílé rẹ̀</s>

en: Burundi: 4 Iwacu journalists (and their driver) accused of "complicity in threatening the interior security of the state" for having covered a rebel incursion in Bubanza languish in the this province’s prisons (Drawing by Yaga)
yor: Burundi: àwọn akọ̀ròyìn Iwacu mẹ́rin (àti awakọ̀ wọn) ni a fi ẹ̀sùn "ìlọ́wọ́sí ìdúkokò mọ́ ààbò ìlú" kàn nítorí wọ́n lọ kó ìròyìn ìkọlù tí ó wá sáyé tí wọ́n sì di ẹ̀rọ ọgbà ẹ̀wọ̀n Bubanza (Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Yaga)
mt0: <pad> Burundi: Four Iwacu journalists (and their driver) have been charged with "interference in the protection of the city" for reporting the violence and being a cameraman at Bubanza prison (Photo by Yaga)</s>

en: After appealing the decision on their detention, the date for their court hearing was set for November 18, To their surprise, they were summoned on November 11, to appear before judges for questioning — but without lawyers.
yor: Lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n ti ní ẹjọ́ tí ó fi àwọn sí inú àtìmọ́lé náà kò tẹ́ àwọn lọ́rùn, a dá ọjọ́ ìgbẹ́jọ́ wọn sí ọjọ́ 18, oṣù Kọkànlá, kàyéfì ni ó jẹ́ fún wọn nígbà tí wọ́n gbé wọn lọ sílé ẹjọ́ ní ọjọ́ 11, oṣù Kọkànlá kí wọn ó wá gbọ́wọ́ pọ̀nyìn rojọ́ níwájú adájọ́ — láì sí àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò.
mt0: <pad> After being accused of stealing, they were taken to court on November 11 to be heard by a judge — without lawyers.</s>

en: They refused to answer without legal assistance, asking why their lawyers had not been informed beforehand, and then returned to detention, to be heard on November 18.
yor: Wọ́n kọ̀ wọn kò fèsì nítorí kò sí àwọn agbẹ́jọ́rò wọn níkàlẹ̀, wọ́n sì dá wọn padà sí àtìmọ́lé, kí ọjọ́ 18 tí a dá fún ìgbẹ́jọ́ ó kò.
mt0: <pad> They were refused entry because there were no lawyers present, and they were sent back to jail, before the 18th day of trial.</s>

en: On November 20, the decision came that the four journalists would remain in detention, but the driver was provisionally released.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Kọkànlá, ìpinnu dé tí wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin yóò padà sínú àtìmọ́lé, àmọ́ wọ́n dá awakọ̀ sílẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> On November 20, it was decided that the four journalists would return to the base, but the driver was released.</s>

en: The prosecution originally called for a 15-year prison sentence.
yor: Ìdájọ́ tí a fún wọn tó ọdún 15 nínú ẹ̀wọ̀n.
mt0: <pad> The sentences were up to 15 years in prison.</s>

en: President Pierre Nkurunziza said during a press conference on December 26 that he wanted a fair trial but he could only intervene as a last resort, even though he could use his power to grant a presidential pardon.
yor: Ààrẹ Pierre Nkurunziza sọ níbi àpéjọ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn kan tí ó wá sáyé ní ọjọ́ 26 oṣù Kejìlá wí pé ohun ohun kò ní fẹ́ dídijú mọ́rí dájọ́ àmọ́ ó dìgbà tí a bá ti ṣánpá tí kò ṣe é ṣán mọ́ ni òun yóò tó ká a lérí, pẹ̀lú pé ó lè fi àṣẹ tí ó ń bẹ ní ìkáwọ́ rẹ da ẹjọ́ náà nù.
mt0: <pad> President Pierre Nkurunziza said in a press conference on December 26 that he will not interfere with the judiciary but will only take action when it is impossible to avoid it, and that he can use his power of veto to overturn the court.</s>

en: On January 30, in Bubanza, the four journalists were sentenced to two and a half years in prison and a fine of a million francs each ($521 United States dollars) under article 16 of the Penal Code, while the driver was acquitted.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 30, oṣù Kìn-ín-ín ní Bubanza, a rán to àwọn akọ̀ròyìn mẹ́rẹ̀ẹ̀rin náà lọ sí ẹ̀wọ̀n ọdún méjì àti àbọ̀ pẹ̀lú kí ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan ó sanwó ìtanràn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún owó francs ($521 owó orílẹ̀ èdè Amẹ́ríkà) lábẹ́ òfin 16 ti Òfin Ọ̀daràn, tí awakọ̀ sì gba ilé-e rẹ̀ láì sanwó ìtanràn.
mt0: <pad> On 30 June in Bubanza, the four journalists were sent to jail for two and a half years with each of them being ordered to pay a fine of 5,000 francs ($521 U.S. dollars) under Article 16 of the Criminal Code, while the driver was arrested without paying a fine.</s>

en: The prosecution could not prove any actual link or contact with the rebels, so the charge was changed to "impossible attempt at the complicity in undermining state security", that is — that they intended to threaten state security but it was not possible.
yor: Ìdájọ́ náà kò fi hàn ní pàtó wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà mọ ohunkóhun nípa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà, látàrí èyí ẹ̀sùn náà yíra padà di "ìgbésẹ̀ ìlọ́wọ́sí ìdúkokò mọ́ ààbò ìlú tí kò ṣe é ṣe", ìyẹn ni pé — wọ́n pète láti dúnmọ̀rurumọ̀ruru mọ́ ààbò ìlú àmọ́ ó ṣòro láti gbé ṣe.
mt0: <pad> The court did not clearly show that the reporters knew anything about the incident, so the charge changed to "unreasonable attempts to disrupt public order", that is, they were willing to disrupt public order but it was difficult to do so.</s>

en: Iwacu pointed out that the reporters went to the area after authorities had publicly mentioned the incident, were accredited, and there were no restrictions on the area.
yor: Iwacu ṣàlàyé wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà lọ síbi ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà lẹ́yìn tí àwọn aláṣẹ tí fi léde, wọ́n gba ìwé àṣẹ kò sì sí òfin tí ó ní kẹ́nìkan ó máa dé agbègbè ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà.
mt0: <pad> Iwacu explained that the journalists went to the site after being notified by authorities, received a permit and no law allowed them to enter the site.</s>

en: The key element used as evidence against the journalists was a WhatsApp message sent by one of the reporters to a friend, which said they were going to "help the rebels".
yor: Ẹ̀rí kan ṣoṣo tí wọ́n rí dìmú tí ó kó àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà sí yáwúyáwú ni àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ orí WhatsApp tí ọ̀kan lára àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà fi ṣọwọ́ sí ọ̀rẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ kan, tí ó sọ wí pé àwọn fẹ́ lọ "ran àwọn ọlọ́tẹ̀ ìjọba náà lọ́wọ́ ".
mt0: <pad> The only evidence they have of the plot to bomb the media is a WhatsApp message one of the journalists sent to a friend, in which he said they were going to "help the government protesters."</s>

en: They argued it was clearly a dry joke —  the government has often conflated critics, political opponents, and armed groups to justify generalized crackdowns. But the text was taken literally as evidence against them.
yor: Àmọ́ ẹ̀fẹ̀ lásán ni wọ́n fi ṣe — ìjọba ti máa ń sábà kó àwọn alátakò, ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú àti àwọn agbébọnrìn papọ̀ láti jàre irú ìgbésẹ̀ báyìí. the àtẹ̀jíṣẹ́ náà ni a fi kàn wọ́n mọ́lẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> But they were given free rein — the government has often brought together protesters, politicians and farmers to fight such a move.</s>

en: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) said the journalists should be able to report on sensitive topics without fear of reprisals, particularly ahead of Burundi's May 20 election.
yor: Reporters Without Borders (RSF) sọ wí pé àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà lẹ́tọ̀ọ́ láti jábọ̀ ìròyìn tí ó kan gbogbo ìlú gbọ̀ngbọ̀n láì fòyà ìgbẹ̀san, papàá ní ìgbaradì ìbò orílẹ̀-èdèe Burundi ọjọ́ 20 oṣù karùn-ún tí ó ń bọ̀ lọ́nà.
mt0: <pad> Reporters Without Borders (RSF) said the journalists were entitled to report on all aspects of the city, but without bias, a papal visit to Burundi on 20 April is underway.</s>

en: They made a petition calling for their release, which had almost 7,000 signatures in early May.
yor: Wọ́n kọ ìwé ìfẹ̀sùnkànni kan tí ó ń pè fún ìdásílẹ̀ wọn, èyí tí ènìyàn tí ó tó 7,000 tọwọ́bọ̀ ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ oṣù Karùn-ún.
mt0: <pad> They wrote a petition calling for their founding, which over 7,000 people signed in the beginning of March.</s>

en: European Union deputies, the European Parliament, and UN human rights experts are among those who called for their release.
yor: Àwọn igbá-kejì àjọ European Union, Ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba Yúróòpù, àti àwọn àgbà UN nípa ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn wà lára àwọn tí ó ti pè fún ìdásílẹ̀ wọn.
mt0: <pad> The European Union Commission, European Council and UN Human Rights Representatives are among the people who have been invited to join them.</s>

en: On February 20, the journalists appealed, questioning the quality of the legal process, including the change to the original charge without proper notification.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 20 oṣù Kejì, àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà ní ìdájọ́ náà kò-tẹ́ àwọn lọ́rùn, tí wọ́n sọ wí pé aláìṣẹ̀ ni wọ́n ń fìyà jẹ, àti àyípadà pàjáwìrì tí ó déédéé bá ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n kọ́kọ́ fi kàn wọ́n.
mt0: <pad> On February 20, the journalists said the verdict was unsatisfying, claiming that they were being bullied, and that there had been a substantial change in the original charges.</s>

en: On May 6, the journalists appeared at an appeal hearing, after approximately six months in jail.
yor: Lọ́jọ́ 6, oṣù karùn-ún, àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà fojú hàn nílé ẹjọ́ kòtẹ́milọ́rùn kan, lẹ́yìn tí wọ́n ti fi ẹ̀wọ̀n oṣù mẹ́fà jura.
mt0: <pad> On June 6, the journalists appeared in court after being jailed for six months.</s>

en: Responding to the accusation based on the WhatsApp message, the defense noted that in another message, one journalist said the rebels were coming to "threaten the peace".
yor: Ní ìfèsìpadà sí ẹ̀sùn náà látàrí iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ orí WhatsApp, ní èyí tí akọ̀ròyìn kan sọ wí pé àwọn ọlọ́tẹ̀ náà ń bọ̀ wá "dí àlàáfíà lọ́wọ́ ".
mt0: <pad> In response to the accusation via WhatsApp, a report said that the protesters were returning to "hold peace."</s>

en: RFI quoted their defense lawyer, Clément Retirakiza, saying there was an absence of evidence against them, and they wanted to show it was a purely professional trip.
yor: RFI tún ọ̀rọ̀ agbẹ́jọ́rò wọn, Clément Retirakiza wí, wípé kkò sí ẹ̀rí tí dájú nípa ẹ̀sùn tí a fi kan àwọn akọ̀ròyìn náà, wọ́n kàn fẹ́ fi ọwọ́ ọlá gba aláìṣẹ̀ lójú ni.
mt0: <pad> RFI spokesman Clément Retirakiza said that there was no credible evidence against the journalists, and that the allegations were just a way to get a job.</s>

en: Iwacu has long been an independent voice that criticizes politicized violence — it is one of the last independent media outlets following the 2015 crackdown.
yor: Ọjọ́ ti pẹ́ tí Iwacu ti wà gedegbe gẹ́gẹ́ bí ohùn tí ó fajúro sí jágídíjàgan ìṣèlú — òun ni iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìn tí ó kẹ́yìn lẹ́yìn ìgbẹ́sẹ̀lé ọdún-un 2015.
mt0: <pad> Iwacu has been a strong voice for the political debate for a long time — it is the first news outlet to be launched after the 2015 elections.</s>

en: A history of violence against journalists
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá nípa ìjìyà akọ̀ròyìn
mt0: <pad> The incident followed the murder of a journalist.</s>

en: After controversial 2015 elections — in which Nkurunziza returned for a third term that many argued as unconstitutional — there was a failed putsch. The media environment quickly deteriorated.
yor: Lẹ́yìn ètò ìdìbò tí ó dá wàhálà sílẹ̀ ti ọdún-un After 2015 — èyí tí ó gbé Nkurunziza padà sípò fún ìgbà kẹta tí àwọn ènìyàn sọ wí pé ó tasẹ̀ àgbẹ̀rẹ̀ sófin — ìfipágbàjọba tí kò yọrí sí rẹ. Iṣẹ́ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn de polúkúmuṣu.
mt0: <pad> After the controversial 2015 election, which re-elected Nkurunziza for a third term, the government has been unable to restore order. The press is under pressure to report on the situation.</s>

en: Several radios stations — the most relied upon for information in Burundi — were closed and some were attacked. Dozens of journalists fled and some suffered torture, such as Esdras Ndikumana.
yor: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iléeṣẹ́ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ — tí àwọn ènìyàn fẹ́ràn fún ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ ìròyìn tí kò figbákanbọ̀kan ní Burundi — ni a ṣán pa. Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ akọ̀ròyìn lló júbà ehoro tí àwọn mìíràn bíi Esdras Ndikumana jẹ mo-yó-ìyà
mt0: <pad> Many radio stations — popular for their unbiased news in Burundi — were shut down. Several journalists have been killed and others like Esdras Ndikumana are prisoners of war.</s>

en: Numerous journalists have also experienced violence from security forces, particularly when reporting on topics deemed “sensitive” by the state.
yor: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ àwọn akọ̀ròyìn ni ó ti ní ìrírí ìyà lọ́wọ́ àwọn ẹ̀sọ́ agbófinró ìlú, pàápàá jù lọ bí wọ́n ń bá kó ìròyìn tí ó “pọn dandan” jọ.
mt0: <pad> The newspaper has said it has had experiences of abuse from the city's police, especially when it comes to reporting "sensitive" news.</s>

en: In late 2015, cameraman Christophe Nkezabahizi was killed by police along with three family members, in an operation against protests after the contentious election.
yor: Ní ìparí ọdún 2015, ọlọ́pàá pa òǹyàwòrán Christophe Nkezabahizi pẹ̀lú àwọn ọmọ-lẹ́bí mẹ́ta, ní àsìkò ìbò tí ìfẹ̀hónú wá sáyé.
mt0: <pad> In the end of 2015, police killed filmmaker Christophe Nkezabahizi with his three children, during a protest during the election.</s>

en: In July 2016, Jean Bigirimana was forcibly disappeared, reportedly arrested by intelligence services (SNR), with a limited police investigation.
yor: Nínú oṣù Keje ọdún 2016, Jean Bigirimana di àwátì, ó ṣe é ṣe kí ó jẹ́ wí pé iléeṣẹ́ ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́ (SNR) ló gbé e, láì jẹ́ kí àwọn ọlọ́pàá ó ṣe ìwádìí ìfínìdíikókò bó ṣe yẹ.
mt0: <pad> In July 2016, Jean Bigirimana became a fugitive, possibly being held by the National Radio (SNR), without allowing police to conduct a full time video investigation.</s>

en: This year, on January 16, reporter Blaise-Pascal Kararumiye with Radio Isanganiro (Meeting Point Radio) was arrested following a report on local government finances. On April 28, journalist Jackson Bahati was hit by a police officer while reporting.
yor: Lọ́dún yìí, ní ọjọ́ 16 oṣù Kìn-ín-ní, akọ̀ròyìn Blaise-Pascal Kararumiye pẹ̀lú Radio Isanganiro (Meeting Point Radio) di èrò akánrán ọlọ́pàá lẹ́yìn ìròyìn kan nípa owó ìjọba ìbílẹ̀ kan. Lọ́jọ́ 28, oṣù kẹrin, ọlọ́pàá kan na akọ̀ròyìn Jackson Bahati níbi tí ó ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ ìkóròyìn jọ.
mt0: <pad> This year, on June 16, a journalist B.-Pascal Kararumiye with Meeting Point Radio became the target of police after a report about a local government fund. On April 28, a policeman arrested Jackson Bahati while he was working on the same story.</s>

en: International media have not been spared, with BBC and VOA banned in 2019. RSF ranked Burundi 160 of 180 countries for press freedom — down 15 from 2015.
yor: Àwọn iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìn àgbáyé náà ò gbẹ́yìn, a gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé iṣẹ́ BBC ati VOA ní 2019. RSF to Burundi sí ipò 160 nínú orílẹ̀èdè 180 fún òmìnira oníròyìn — ó fi 15 láti 2015.
mt0: <pad> International news agencies did not follow, BBC and VOA were suspended in 2019. RSF ranks Burundi 160th out of 180 countries for press freedom — up 15 since 2015.</s>

en: Women in Nigeria face a caustic landmine of political advocacy online
yor: Àwọn obìnrin ní Nàìjíríà kojú àdó-olóró àgbẹ́sẹ̀léró àgbàwí ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára
mt0: <pad> Women in Nigeria have taken to social media to protest against the political censorship.</s>

en: #BringBackOurGirls and #ArewaMeToo reshaped political activism in Nigeria
yor: #BringBackOurGirls àti #ArewaMeToo ṣe àtúntò sí ìgbàwí ètò ìṣèlú ní orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà
mt0: <pad> #BringBackOurGirls and #ArewaMeToo have been a response to the failure of the Nigerian political system.</s>

en: Members of the Mother's Savings Club, Nigeria. Image by Karen Kasmauski / USAID in Africa via United States government work, public domain.
yor: Àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ Mother's Savings Club, Nàìjíríà. I'm Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ Karen Kasmauski / USAID ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ ní orí United States government work, public domain.
mt0: <pad> Members of Mother's Savings Club, Nigeria. I'm Image by Karen Kasmauski / USAID in Africa on United States government work, public domain.</s>

en: In Nigeria, the political advocacy sphere is a caustic landmine.
yor: Ní Nàìjíríà, àdó-olóró àgbẹ́sẹ̀léró ni gbàgede àgbàwí ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú.
mt0: <pad> In Nigeria, political violence is a huge problem.</s>

en: Politics and advocacy usually get filtered through a religious and ethnocentric prism.
yor: Àgbàwí àti ọ̀rọ̀ ìṣèlú sábà máa ń fi ti ọ̀rọ̀ ẹ̀sìn àti ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà ṣe.
mt0: <pad> Politics and politics are often linked to religion and ethnicity.</s>

en: Advocates with a strong social media presence — especially on Twitter — have to develop a tough skin to deal with the avalanche of gbas gbos (Nigerian Pidgin for “throwing punches”) in digital spaces.
yor: Àwọn alágbàwí tí ó gbajúmọ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà — pàápàá jù lọ lórí Twitter — ní láti lè fi ara gba ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ gbas gbos (èdè àdàlù-mọ́-Gẹ̀ẹ́sì Nàìjíríà fún "ìkànṣẹ́") ní orí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá.
mt0: <pad> Fans of popular social media — especially on Twitter — have to be able to handle a lot of tweets (Nigerian slang for "tweet") on their mobile phone.</s>

en: Nigerian female advocates — in addition to weathering this identity-driven harmful content — also face the added reality of gender-driven attacks.
yor: Àwọn alágbàwí tí ó jẹ́ obìnrin — ní àfikún sí títẹ àwọn ohun ìdánimọ̀ tí ó ń mú ìpalára wá mọ́lẹ̀ — bákan náà ni wọ́n ń kojú ìkọlù tí ó ti ara ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin ẹ̀yà jẹ yọ.
mt0: <pad> Women activists — in addition to taking down the signs of oppression — also took on the violence that comes from the racial profiling.</s>

en: How do female advocates in Nigeria cope with the bitter online terrain such as trolling, hate speech and targeted misalignment of their messages?
yor: Báwo ni àwọn alágbàwí l'óbìnrin ní Nàìjíríà ṣe ń farada ìkorò orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára bíi ìsọ̀rọ àlùfànṣá síni, ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin àti ìmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ yí-ọ̀rọ̀ wọn dà?
mt0: <pad> How do young Nigerian girls avoid online harassment such as sexism, vulgarity and abuse?</s>

en: How do they forge ahead to make sure that these attacks do not simmer their resolve or eclipse the message of their movement?
yor: Báwo ni wọ́n ṣe ń tẹ̀síwájú nínú iṣẹ́ wọn tàbí fọnrere iṣẹ́ wọn?
mt0: <pad> How do they continue their work or expand their work?</s>

en: Two online social media movements in Nigeria lend powerful insights into the experiences of advocacy and gender: The #BringBackOurGirls movement, led by Dr. Oby Ezekwesili; and #ArewaMeToo, led by Fakhriyyah Hashim, both experienced gendered political hatred that greatly affected the integrity of their messages.
yor: Àwọn ajìjàgbara orí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà méjì ní Nàìjíríà fi ìrírí àwọn àgbàwí àti ìkórìíra ìwà abo hàn: #BringBackOurGirls, tí Dókítà Oby Ezekwesili jẹ́ aṣíwájú; àti #ArewaMeToo, tí Fakhriyyah Hashim jẹ́ agbátẹrù, gbogbo wọn ni wọ́n ní ìrírí ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin abo nínú agbo òṣèlú tí ó ń fa ìlọsíwájú wọn sẹ́yìn.
mt0: <pad> Two social media campaigns in Nigeria have shared the experiences of elderly and women's empowerment: #BringBackOurGirls, led by Dr. Oby Ezekwesili; and #ArewaMeToo, led by Fakhriyyah Hashim, all of whom had experiences of gender bias in politics that hindered their progress.</s>

en: #BringBackOurGirls (#BBOG) movement
yor: Ìjàgbara #BringBackOurGirls (#BBOG)
mt0: <pad> #BringBackOurGirls</s>

en: Six years ago, on April 15, 2014, about 200 school girls between the ages of 15 and 18, were forcefully abducted by Boko Haram, an Islamist terrorist group, from Government Girls Secondary School in Chibok near Maiduguri, in northeast Nigeria.
yor: Ọdún mẹ́fà sẹ́yìn, ní ọjọ́ 15, Oṣù Igbe ọdún 2014, ó tó 200 àwọn ọmọdébìnrin tí ọjọ́ orí wọn ò ju ọdún 15 àti 18 lọ, láti iléèwé Gíga Ìjọba Obìnrin ní Chibok ẹ̀bà Maidiguri, ní àríwá-ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà ni ẹgbẹ́ afẹ̀míṣòfò èlẹ́sìn Mùsùlùmí Boko Haram sọ di ẹni tí a fi túláàsì mú sí ìgbẹ̀sìn.
mt0: <pad> Four years ago, on April 15, 2014, over 200 girls aged between 15 and 18 from Chibok State Girls High School in Maiduguri, north-eastern Nigeria were kidnapped by the Islamist group Boko Haram.</s>

en: The kidnapping of the Chibok girls ignited an international outcry.
yor: Ìjínigbé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok náà ṣe okùnfà ìlọ́wọ́sí àwọn orílẹ̀ èdè kárí àgbá ńlá ayé.
mt0: <pad> The kidnapping of the Chibok girls has become a symbol of international solidarity.</s>

en: The BBC reported that in April 2014,  the #BringBackOurGirls trended on Twitter with over 3.3 million tweets, 27 percent of the tweets came from Nigeria, 26 percent from the United States and 11 percent from the United Kingdom.
yor: Iléeṣẹ́ oníròyìn BBC jábọ̀ wí pé nínú oṣù Igbe ọdún 2014, #BringBackOurGirls náà gbajúmọ̀ ní orí Twitter pẹ̀lú nǹkan bíi àwọn ènìyàn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún 3.3 tí ó tún túwíìtì náà túwíìtì, ìdá 27 àwọn túwíìtì wọ̀nyí ni ó wá láti Nàìjíríà, ìdá 26 láti orílẹ̀ èdè Amẹ́ríkà àti ìdá 11 láti Ilẹ̀ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.
mt0: <pad> The BBC reported that in June 2014, #BringBackOurGirls became popular on Twitter with 3.3 million retweets, 27 percent of these retweets came from Nigeria, 26 percent from the United States and 11 percent from the UK.</s>

en: Dr. Oby Ezekwesili answering a question during a UN Women event with #BringBackOurGirls Campaign Coordinators.
yor: Dókítà Oby Ezekwesili ń dáhùn ìbéèrè níbi ètò àwọn obìnrin àjọ UN pẹ̀lú àwọn alákòóso ìpolongo #BringBackOurGirls.
mt0: <pad> Dr. Oby Ezekwesili addresses the UN Women's Programme with the campaigners of #BringBackOurGirls</s>

en: Image by UN Women/Ryan Brown, September 14, 2014. (CC BY-NC-ND 2.0)
yor: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ UN Women/Ryan Brown, ọjọ́ 14, oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀ ọdún 2014. (CC BY-NC-ND 2.0)
mt0: <pad> Image by UN Women/ Ryan Brown, 14 October 2014. (CC BY-NC-ND 2.0)</s>

en: Dr. Obiageli (Oby) Ezekwesili, a former vice president of the World Bank, and one-time minister of education in Nigeria, started tweeting about the Chibok girls the day they were kidnapped.
yor: Dókítà Obiageli (Oby) Ezekwesili, igbá-kejì ààrẹ Ilé ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé ìgbà kan, àti mínísítà ètò ẹ̀kọ́ orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà nígbà kan rí, bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí túwíìtì nípa àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok ní ọjọ́ tí wọ́n jí wọn gbé gan-an gan-an.
mt0: <pad> Dr. Obiageli Ezekwesili, former deputy president of the UN Security Council and former minister of education in Nigeria, began tweeting about the Chibok girls on the day of their abduction.</s>

en: She was motivated to take action due to a previous attack on schoolboys at the Federal Government College of Buni Yadi in Yobe State, northeastern Nigeria on February 25, 2014.
yor: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kan tí ó ti ṣẹlẹ̀ tí àwọn àjínigbé jí àwọn ọmọdékùnrin gbé ní iléèwé Kọ́lẹ̀jì ìjọba Àpapọ̀ ti Buni Yadi ní Ìpínlẹ̀ Yobe, àríwá-ìlà-oòrùn Nàìjíríà lọ́jọ́ 25, oṣù Èrèlé ọdún 2014 ló ṣí i lójú sí ìpolongo yìí.
mt0: <pad> A recent incident of rape in Buni Yadi State College, Yobe state, north-eastern Nigeria on 25th April 2014 has inspired this campaign.</s>

en: Fifty-nine boys died from gunshots or knife wounds, while the others were burnt to death.
yor: Àwọn ọmọdékùnrin kankàndínlọ́gọ́ta ni ó ti ara ọta ìbọn àti ọgbẹ́ ọbẹ̀ kú, nígbà tí iná sì jó àwọn mìíràn pa.
mt0: <pad> Fourteen men were killed by gun and knife wounds, while others were burned by fire.</s>

en: However, it was not until April 23, when, as a guest at a UNESCO event in Port Harcourt, in the oil-rich Niger Delta region, did her cry for the release of the schoolgirls grab national and international attention:
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, àfi ìgbà tí ó di ọjọ́ 23, oṣù Igbe, nígbà tí àjọ UNESCO gbà á lálejò ní Port Harcourt, ibi tí ó kún fún epo-rọ̀bì ní agbègbè Niger Delta, ni ó ti ké gbàjarè fún ìdásílẹ̀ àwọn ọmọdébìnrin tí ó fi di ohun tí gbogbo orílẹ̀ èdè àgbáyé gbà bí igbá ọtí:
mt0: <pad> But since the 23rd of July, when UNESCO honoured him in Port Harcourt, a rich oil-rich town in the Niger Delta region, he has been involved in the establishment of girls' organizations that have become what the world accepts as a global winery.</s>

en: And on May 7, 2014, former American first lady Michelle Obama posted an image of herself on Twitter holding a sign with the hashtag #BringBackOurGirls.
yor: Ní ọjọ́ 7 oṣù Èbìbí ọdún 2014, aya ààrẹ orílẹ̀-èdè Amẹ́ríkà ọ̀gábìnrin Michelle Obama ṣe àtẹ̀jáde àwòrán kan tí ó ti mú àmì “Ẹ dá àwọn ọmọdébìnrin wa padà” #BringBackOurGirls lọ́wọ́.
mt0: <pad> On July 7, 2014, the first lady of the United States Michelle Obama posted a photo on Twitter that she held a sign with the slogan "Bring Back Our Girls" #BringBackOurGirls.</s>

en: She also released a video a few days later from the White House — making it a global sensation.
yor: Bákan náà ni ó tari àwòrán-olóhùn kan láti inú Ilé Funfun síta — tí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí sì sọ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìjínigbé náà di ọ̀ràn tí gbogbo àgbáyé fẹ́ rí àbálọ-bábọ̀ rẹ̀.
mt0: <pad> He also posted a video of himself from the White House — which made the earthquake a public event that the world wanted to see his reaction.</s>

en: It would take two years before the Nigerian army rescued one girl, in May 2016.
yor: Ọdún méjì ni ó gba àwọn ọmọ ogun orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà láti gba ọmọdébìnrin kan sílẹ̀, nínú oṣù Òkúdù ọdún-un 2016.
mt0: <pad> Two years ago, a Nigerian soldier was kidnapped by a female prisoner in October 2016.</s>

en: By October 2016, 21 girls were reunited with their families. And by May 2017, Boko Haram militants released 82 girls from captivity.
yor: Nígbà tí ó máa fi di oṣù Ọ̀wàrà ọdún-un 2016, àwọn ọmọdébìnrin 21 darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn mọ̀lẹ́bí wọn. Ní oṣù Èbìbí 2017, ikọ̀ Boko Haram dá àwọn ọmọdébìnrin 82 sílẹ̀ nínú ìgbẹ̀sìn.
mt0: <pad> Around August 2016, 21 girls returned to their families. In February 2017, Boko Haram freed 82 girls from the cult.</s>

en: However, about 112 girls remain missing and 13 are presumed dead, according to a 2018 report.
yor: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, ó tó ọmọdébìnrin 112 tí ó di àwátì bí abẹ́rẹ́ tí ó sì jọ pé àwọn 13 tí ṣègbé, ìyẹn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìwádìí ọdún 2018 kan ṣe tọ pinpin.
mt0: <pad> However, there are at least 112 girls who have been diagnosed with HIV as a childbirth and 13 of them have died, according to a 2018 study.</s>

en: Ezekwesili co-founded the #BBOG movement that mobilized a global protest for the release of the Chibok girls.
yor: Ezekwesili àti àjọṣepọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn kan ni ó dá ìgbésẹ̀ ìjà fún ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn ọmọdébìnrin #BBOG tí ó kó àwọn ènìyàn jọ lágbàáyé fún ìdásílẹ̀ àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok.

yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Hashim ṣe sọ, àwọn ayọnilẹ́nu gbèrò láti sọ ArewaMeToo di ohun tí ó tasẹ̀ àgẹ̀rẹ̀ sí òfin nípa síso ArewaMeToo pọ̀ mọ́ LGBTQ [obìnrin-tó-ń-fẹ́-obìnrin, ọkùnrin-tí-ó-ń-fẹ́-ọkùnrin, àwọn abo àti akọ tí ó yíra padà di akọ tàbí abo àti àwọn ènìyàn tí ó ṣe àjèjì tí kò sí ní ìbámu] àti ète wọ́n ṣiṣẹ́ bí ìyọlẹ́nu orí ayélujára ṣe ń lékún sí i.
mt0: <pad> As Hashim said, journalists tried to make ArewaMeToo a legal issue by linking it to LGBTQ [lesbians, gays, bisexuals and other non-binary people] and their mouths worked as the internet criticism supported it.</s>

en: In Nigeria, gay marriage is illegal and under Sharia and penal legal codes, sodomy and lesbianism are punishable in some states.
yor: Ní orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà, ìgbéyàwó láàárín ọkùnrin àti ọkùnrin lòdì sófin bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ní abẹ́ òfin Sẹ́ríà àti òfin ìfìyàjẹ ẹlẹ́sẹ̀, ìbálòpọ̀ ihò ìdí àti ìbálòpọ̀ láàárín obìnrin àti obìnrin ní ìjìyà ní àwọn ìpínlẹ̀ kan.
mt0: <pad> In Nigeria, same-sex marriage is legal under the Sharia law and the Penal Code, while cohabitation and same-sex marriage are legal in some states.</s>

en: By associating Haashim's movement with LGBTQ rights, online trolls distorted their message and framed #ArewaToo and NorthNormal as illegitimate.
yor: Nípasẹ̀ dída ìgbésẹ̀ ìpolongo Hashim papọ̀ mọ́ ẹ̀tọ́ LGBTQ, àwọn ènìyàn ní orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára lọ́ ìpolongo wọn po wọ́n sì pe #ArewaToo àti NorthNormal ní ohun tí kò tọ́.
mt0: <pad> Since Hashim's campaign for LGBTQ rights, people on social media have criticized the campaign and labeled #ArewaToo and NorthNormal as unacceptable.</s>

en: However, Global Voices was not able to independently verify tweets that pinned Hashim's movement to LGBTQ rights.
yor: Bí-ó-ti-wù-kí-ó-rí, Ohùn Àgbáyé kò rí àyè sí àwọn túwíìtì tí ó sọ ìgbésẹ̀ ìpolongo Hashim ní ìjà fún ẹ̀tọ́ LGBTQ.
mt0: <pad> However, the World Voice did not publish tweets that praised Hashim's campaign in the fight for LGBTQ rights.</s>

en: Still, Hashim posts messages of hope on Twitter:

en: She said all these experiences helped her grow a "really thick skin":

mt0: <pad> He said that all of this experience helped him to "have a lot of happiness."</s>

en: In my experience of being loud on political Twitter for good governance, I’ve grown a really thick skin, but even that didn't prepare me for the amount of backlash we got through ArewaMeToo and NorthNormal.
yor: Ìrírí mi nípa ìgbóhùnsókè lórí ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú ní orí Twitter fún ìṣèjọba tí ó dára, ti kọ́ mi ní ìfaradà, àmọ́ ìyẹn kò mú mi gbaradì fún ọ̀kan-ò-jọ̀kan ìtakò tí a fojú rí látàrí ìpolongo ArewaMeToo àti NorthNormal.
mt0: <pad> My experience of being a Twitter commentator for good governance has taught me patience, but it didn't make me stronger for the individual harassment that we saw through the ArewaMeToo and NorthNormal campaigns.</s>

en: Though I mustered all of that and did not retreat to any cave, I did begin feeling demoralised about Northern Nigeria’s governanace and response to sexual violence...
yor: Àmọ́pé mo fi gbogbo rẹ̀ ṣe osùn mo fi para n ò sì jẹ́ kí ó fà mí sẹ́yìn, mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní í ní ìrẹ̀wẹ̀síọkàn nípa ìṣèjọba Àríwá orílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà àti bí wọ́n ṣe fi ọwọ́ mú ìwà ìfipábánilò...
mt0: <pad> Although I didn't take it personally and didn't let it affect me, I began to feel more concerned about the political system in north-eastern Nigeria and how they have taken up terrorism.</s>

en: After every episode of attacks, we did gather more strength and energy to push back because the backlash made us see how society enforced the culture of silence and if we allowed our lips to be sealed then that would be the real tragedy.
yor: Lẹ́yìn ìkọlù kọ̀ọ̀kan, a máa ń ní okun àti agbára láti tẹ̀síwájú nítorí ìtakò mú wa rí bí àṣà ìdákẹ́ rọrọ ti ṣe rinlẹ̀ tó ní àwùjọ àti pé bí a bá fi àyè gba ìpanumọ́, a jẹ́ wí pé oko ìparun ni à ń fi orí lé.
mt0: <pad> After every shock, we are stronger and more powerful because the shock showed us how deep the culture of violence has reached in our community and that if we allow it, we are entering a flood of destruction.</s>

en: Sadly, Hashim and Ezekwesili still struggle with the excruciating "lack of empathy" that characterises discourse about gender-based violence on- and offline.
yor: Ó ṣeni láàánú, Hashim àti Ezekwesili ṣì ń janpata pẹ̀lú ìyà “àìsí àánú ọmọlàkejì” tí ó dìrọ̀ mọ́ ọ̀ràn ìwà ìjìyà àwọn obìnrin lórí ayélujára àti lójú ayé tòótọ́.
mt0: <pad> However, Hashim and Ezekwesili are still being bullied by the "second-generation bully" who has been encouraging sexual harassment of women online and in real life.</s>

en: According to Hashim, this "deliberate maligning of a cause that only seeks better for victims of sexual violence" is incredibly difficult to grasp.
yor: Ní ti Hashim, "ìmọ̀ọ́mọ̀ ṣààta ìgbésẹ̀ tí ó ń gbèrò láti fi ohùn fún àwọn tí ó ń jìyà ìfarapa" nira láti gbá mú.
mt0: <pad> For Hashim, "the awareness of the movement that seeks to give voice to the sufferers" is difficult to grasp.</s>

en: This article is part of the project, "the identity matrix: platform regulation of online threats to expression in Africa".
yor: Àròkọ yìí jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àkànṣe iṣẹ́, "Orísun ìdánimọ̀: òfin gbàgede orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára bí ajere tí ń gbégi dínà ìdàgbàsókè ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ ní Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀".
mt0: <pad> This article is part of the project, "Source of knowledge: internet censorship as a barrier to the development of free speech in Africa."</s>

en: These posts interrogate identity-driven online hate speech or discrimination based on language or geographic origin, misinformation and harassment (particularly against female activists and journalists) prevalent in the digital spaces of seven African countries: Algeria, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Sudan, Tunisia and Uganda.
yor: Àtẹ̀jáde yìí ṣe ìbéèrè ipa ìdánimọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ ìkórìíra tẹ̀gbintẹ̀gbin tàbí ìyàsọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ tí ó dá fìrìgbagbòó lórí èdè tàbí agbègbè ilẹ̀ ayé, àṣìwífún àti ìyọlẹ́nu (pàápàá jù lọ ìyọlẹ́nu àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọnìyàn àti akọ̀ròyìn l'óbìnrin) lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára bí ajere tí ó wọ́pọ̀ ní orílẹ̀ èdè Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ méje: Algeria, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Sudan, Tunisia àti Uganda.
mt0: <pad> The article explores the impact of a persistently segregated or segregating language, culture and media (specially women's media) on internet as a popular activity in seven African languages: Algeria, Cameroon, Ethiopia, Nigeria, Sudan, Tunisia and Uganda.</s>

en: The project is funded by the Africa Digital Rights Fund of The Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA).
yor: Africa Digital Rights Fund ti Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) ni ó kówó fún à kànṣe iṣẹ́ yìí.
mt0: <pad> Africa Digital Rights Fund is the fund that was set up by the Collaboration on International ICT Policy for East and Southern Africa (CIPESA) to support this project.</s>

en: Walid Abdullah, 23, says the state has even gone so far as to suggest terminating the lives of suspected COVID-19 patients.

en: Speaking to Global Voices by phone, Abdullah explained that on May 13, he called Daraa National Hospital, in southern Syria, to inform them about a suspected case of coronavirus.

mt0: <pad> In an interview with the World Voice on the phone, Abdullah said he called the National Hospital of Daraa in Syria's northern province on November 15 to inform them of a coronavirus case they had identified.</s>

en: When he asked what steps should be taken, the government hospital employee who answered the phone said: "Shoot him — we have no cure for him", according to Abdullah.
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí Abdullah ṣe sọ, nígbà tí ó bèèrè ìgbésè tí ó yẹ ní gbígbé, òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba tí ó gbé ìpè náà sọ pé " Yìnbọn pà á, a kò ní ìwòsàn fún"
mt0: <pad> According to Abdullah, when he asked what action should be taken, the government official who answered the phone said "You're just a gun, we don't have any medicine for you."</s>

en: He quickly ended the call.

mt0: <pad> Abdullah told the World News "Deaths from COVID-19 are worse than walking to the government hospital."</s>

en: In a March 10 report published in The Voice of the Capital, an independent Syrian newspaper, medical personnel from the Syrian Ministry of Health claimed that "deliberate termination operations are taking place at the al-Mujtahid government hospital in the capital, Damascus, for those who are believed to be carrying the virus, through giving them additional doses of the drug [anesthetic]".

mt0: <pad> The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights said on October 10th that "a clinical trial is underway at the state hospital Al-Mujtahid in Damascus, for patients who are believed to be actually ill with AIDS, by giving them a large dose of anti-inflammatory drugs."</s>

en: This claim also appeared on social media:

en: The Assad regime's desperate approach to dealing with COVID-19 parallels callous strategies used in Assad’s war, which left 586,100 people dead, nearly 100,000 detained and forcibly disappeared, and 5.6 million refugees around the world.

en: The Assad regime owes its survival to its key allies, including Iran. With few allies in the region, Iran has leaned on Syria as well.

en: Workers’ Day Celebration: House Speaker tasks Nigerian workers on productivity
yor: ---Àjọ̀dún òṣìṣẹ́: Abẹnugan ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ as̩ojú rọ òṣìṣẹ́ láti tẹramọ́ iṣẹ́ fún àbájáde rere.
mt0: <pad> Employees: The chair of the board urged employees to stay on to work for a positive result.</s>

en: The Speaker of the Nigerian House of Representatives Mr Femi Gbajabiamila has congratulated the Nigerian workers for marking this year’s International Workers’ Day.
yor: Abẹnugan ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣ̣ojú ti Nàìjíríà, Fẹ́mi Gbàjàbíàmílà, ti kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè yìí kú orííre fún ti àjọ̀dún àyájọ́ àwọn òsìsẹ́ lágbàáyé.
mt0: <pad> The Speaker of the Nigerian House of Representatives, Femi Gbajabiamilla, has urged the country's workers to die in protest for the International Labour Organization's (ILO) anniversary.</s>

en: Mr Gbajabiamila said although the day is being marked quietly across the globe as a result of the lockdown necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, there is much to remember about the sacrifices made by Nigerian workers.
yor: Ọ̀gbẹ́ni Gbàjàbíàmílà ní bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ pé ayẹyẹ yìí wáyé láìsí ariwo ní gbogbo àgbáyé nítorí àṣe̩ kónílé–gbélé látàrí ìtànkálẹ̀ aàrun COVID-19, ohun tí a lè rántí pọ̀ nípa àwọn ìrúbọ ti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà̀ ṣe.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Gbajabmila said that although the celebrations were without much fanfare around the world because of the confinement imposed by the COVID-19 pandemic, there was something to be remembered about the sacrifices made by Nigerian workers.</s>

en: In a statement marking the Workers’ Day signed by his Special Adviser on Media and Publicity, Lanre Lasisi, the Speaker commended the Nigerian workers for their commitment and dedication to work over the years, which he said has shaped the country tremendously.
yor: Nínú àtẹ̀jáde tó ń sàmì ọjọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ èyí tí Olùdámọ́ràn rẹ̀ Pàtàkì lórí ìròyìn àti ìkéde fo̩wó̩sí, Láńre Làsísì, Abẹnugan gbóṣùbà fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà nítorí ìfarajìn àti ipa ribiribi tí wọ́n kó fún ọ̀pọ̀ ọdún sẹ́yìn, èyí tó mú ìyípadà rere bá Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> In a statement issued by the Chief of Staff, Lanre Lasisi, the President thanked Nigerian workers for their hard work and great influence over the past years, which has brought positive change to Nigeria.</s>

en: He, however, called on Nigerian workers to be more productive now and always, saying no matter what was achieved before now must be sustained and improved upon for the country to achieve more.
yor: Síbè̩, ó ro̩ àwọn òṣìṣé Nàìjíríà kí wọ́n túnbọ̀ máa so èso rere nísisìnyí àti gbogbo ìgbà, nítorí àṣeyorí àná nílò ìtẹ̀síwájú kí a ṣiṣẹ́ síi kí ọrílẹ̀-èdè yìí leè ní àṣeyọrí síi.
mt0: <pad> However, he urged Nigerian officials to continue to produce good fruit now and always, because success needs to be continued and worked on to make this country even more successful.</s>

en: “I want to salute the courage of Nigerian workers, who have over the years given their best to their work.
yor: ‘Mo fẹ́ kí àwọn òṣìṣé Nàìjíríà fún ọkàn-akin, àwọn tí wọ́n ti fi gbogbo ipá wọn ṣiṣé.
mt0: <pad> I want to thank the Nigerian workers for their hard work, those who have done all they can.</s>

en: Indeed Nigeria and Nigerians are proud of you.
yor: Nítòótọ́, Nàìjíríà àti àwọn ọmọ Nàìjíríà fi yín yangàn.
mt0: <pad> Although Nigeria and the Nigerians have attacked you, Nigeria and the Nigerians will fight you.</s>

en: I urge the Nigerian workers to redouble their efforts at this time of our national development.
yor: Mo rọ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà láti fikún okun wọn ní irú àkókò ìdàgbàsókè orílẹ̀ èdè wa yìí.
mt0: <pad> I urged Nigerian workers to play their part in this time of development of our country.</s>

en: They must continue to put in their best in the work that they do for the betterment of the country.”
yor: Wọ́n gbọ́dọ̀ tẹ̀síwájú láti fi gbogbo agbára wọn ṣe iṣé tí wọ́n ń ṣe fún àǹfààní orílẹ̀ èdè’
mt0: <pad> They must continue to do all they can to fulfill their mission for the benefit of the country.</s>

en: --- May Day: Senate President felicitates with Nigerian workers
yor: --- Àyájọ́ àwọn Òṣìṣẹ́: Olóri ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ Nàìjíríà
mt0: <pad> Employment: Speaker of the House urges Nigerian workers to take up arms</s>

en: President of the Nigerian Senate, Ahmad Lawan, has felicitated with Nigerian workers as they join their counterparts the world over to mark the Workers’ Day.
yor: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà ti Nàìjíríà, Ahmad Lawan, kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè yìí bí wọ́n ṣe sowó̩pò̩ pè̩lú àwọn akẹgbẹ́ wọn lágbàáyé láti s̩e àjọ̀dún o̩jó̩ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.
mt0: <pad> The chairman of the Nigerian House of Representatives, Ahmad Lawan, has urged the country's workers to join their international colleagues to mark the International Workers' Day.</s>

en: Senator Lawan also congratulated Nigerian workers for sustaining their heroic struggle for the liberation of the country from poverty and underdevelopment even in the face of the daunting challenges at various workplaces.
yor: Aṣòfin Lawan tún gbóṣùbà fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ fún gudugudu méje, yàyà mẹfà tí wọ́n ń ṣe láti mú orílẹ̀-èdè kúrò nínú òṣì àti àìní idàgbàsókè àti kíkojú àwo̩n ìpèníjà amúnibè̩rù lẹ́nu iṣẹ́ onírúurú.
mt0: <pad> The Lawan Act also approved the seven, eight and ten-year efforts of the government to get the country out of poverty and unemployment and tackle globalization through multi-billion dollar projects.</s>

en: He acknowledged the role of workers as the creator of wealth in society and stressed that it is for this reason that they should be appreciated at all times.
yor: Ó mọ rírì ipa àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bíi ẹni tó ń mú ọrọ̀ wá sí àwùjọ, ó tẹnumọ wípé èyí ni a ṣe gbọ́dọ̀ mo rírì wọn ní gbogbo ìgbà.
mt0: <pad> He recognizes the role of employees as communicators, and insists that this is why we should always see them.</s>

en: The best way to appreciate the enormous contributions of the Nigerian workers is to always consider their welfare as of utmost importance.
yor: Ó tẹ̣̀síwájú pé "ọ̀nà tó dára jùlọ̣ láti mọ̣ rírì ipa ribiribi tí àwọ̣̣n òṣìṣẹ́ kó ní láti mójútó ètò ìgbáyé-gbádùn wọ̣̣n.
mt0: <pad> He continued that "the best way to understand this is to see the role that employees have played in changing their work-life balance."</s>

en: "As a legislature, we are ever ready to work in collaboration with the organised labour Unions to rid our statute books of any anti-labour laws," Lawan said.
yor: Lawan sọ wípé, "Gẹ̣́gẹ́ bí ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣ̣òfin, a ti ṣ̣etán láti fọwọ̣́sowọ̣́pọ̀ pẹ̣̀lú ẹ̣̣gbẹ̣́ àwọ̣̣n òṣ̣ìṣ̣ẹ́ láti ṣòfin tó lòdì sí ìwà ìbàjẹ́ sí òṣìṣẹ lẹ́nu iṣẹ́".
mt0: <pad> Lawan said, "As a house of assembly, we have been working with hundreds of lawyers to draft a bill that will ban abuse at work."</s>

en: The Senate President said as part of the effort of the 9th National Assembly to strengthen the economy and improve the standard of living of the people, it is determined to make the country’s financial year predictable through the timely passage of the 2020 budget.
yor: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà sọ wípé, gégẹ́ bíi ara akitiyan ilé-ìgbìmọ aṣòfin kẹsàn-án láti fi okun fún ètò ọrọ̀ ajé àti láti mú ìgbé-ayé àwọn ènìyàn dára síi, ti pinu láti mú kí ètò ìsúúná ọdún yìí ṣee dáadáa nípa títètè bu ọwọ́ lu ìwé ètò ìsúná ọdún 2020.
mt0: <pad> The Speaker of the House said that, as part of the efforts of the fifth legislature to strengthen the economic system and improve the lives of the people, it has decided to make this year's budget more efficient by signing the bill early.</s>

en: According to Senator Lawan, the National Assembly has in the same respect made critical amendments to some laws to ensure smooth implementation of the budget.
yor: Nínu ọ̀rọ̀ Aṣòfin Lawan, ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin àgbà bakan náà ti ṣe àtúnṣe sí àwọn òfin kò̩ò̩kan láti ri wípé ìmúlò ètò ìsúná náà lo̩o̩ bí ó ti yẹ.
mt0: <pad> According to Mr. Lawan, the House of Representatives has also made amendments to several laws to ensure that the implementation of the heating system works as it should.</s>

en: He said the Legislature would continue to move relentlessly in that direction, despite the unforeseen challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic.
yor: Ó sọ wípé àwọn Aṣòfin yóò máa lọ ní ìlànà yìí láìwo àwọn ìpèníjà àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn COVID-19.
mt0: <pad> He said the laws will continue to be implemented despite the COVID-19 pandemic.</s>

en: The Senate President noted that this year’s celebration of Workers’ Day comes at a time the entire world is facing the health emergency brought about by the Coronavirus pandemic.
yor: Ààrẹ ilé-ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin ṣe àkíyèsí wípé ayẹyẹ ọjọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ti ọdún yìí wáyé lásìkò tí gbogbo orílẹ̀ èdè àgbáyé ń kojú àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn òjiijì COVID-19.
mt0: <pad> The Speaker of the House announced that this year's Labor Day will be celebrated during a time when the world is dealing with the coronavirus pandemic.</s>

en: "It is the resilience and never-die spirit of the Nigerian people that will boost the efforts of the government to overcome the pandemic," he stated.
yor: Ó wípé "Ọkàn akínkanjú àti ẹ̀mí tí kìí kú tí àwọn ènìyàn Nàìjíríà níí ni yóò ran iṣẹ́ ìjọba lọ́wọ́ láti leè borí àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn náà"
mt0: <pad> He said, "The determination and willingness of the Nigerian people to fight the disease will help the government's efforts to overcome the outbreak."</s>

en: The Senate President urged the Nigerian workers, as they mark their day, to adhere strictly to all the prescribed public health protocols of social distancing, wearing of face mask, use of hand sanitizer, observance of personal hygiene, and to endeavour to stay at home and stay safe.
yor: ”Ààrẹ ilé ìgbìmọ̀ aṣòfin wá rọ àwọn òṣìsẹ́ lórílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà bí wọ́n ṣe ń sàmì ọjọ́ wọn, láti máa tẹ́lé ìlànà ètò ìlera láwùjọ, fífi ààyè sáàrín ara wa, kí a máa wọ ìbòjú, kí a máa lo oun èlò ìfọwọ́ apakòkòrò, kí a máa ṣe ìmọ́tótó ara wa àti láti máa dúrọ sílé kí a sì dáàbò bo ara wa.
mt0: <pad> The Speaker of the House urged Nigerians to adhere to social distancing, wear masks, use hand sanitizers, take a self-examination and stay at home and protect ourselves.</s>

en: --- COVID 19: another twenty four (24) people were tested positive in Nigeria.
yor: --- COVID-19: Àwọn ènìyàn mẹ́rìnlélógún (24) mìíràn tún jẹyọ lórílẹ̀ èdè Nàìjíríà
mt0: <pad> COVID-19: 24 new cases confirmed in Nigeria</s>

en: Another twenty-four (24) people were tested positive for corona virus (COVID 19) in Nigeria this made the total of infected people to be one thousand, nine hundred and thirty-two (1932) when three hundred and nineteen (319) have been discharged, and fifty-eight (58) are dead. The Nigeria centre for disease control (NCDC) announced this on their twitter handle @NCDC.gov.
yor: Àwọn ènìyàn mẹ́rìlélógún (24) mìíràn tún ti jẹyọ tí wọ́n ní ààrùn Corona (COVID 19) lórílé̩èdè Nàìjíríà, èyí tó jẹ́ kí iye àwọn tó ní ààrùn Corona jẹ́ o̩gbò̩nlélé̩è̩dé̩gbàá lé méjì (1932), nígbà tí àwọn ènìyàn bí mọ́kàndínlógúnlélọ́ọ̀dúnrún (319) ti gba ìwòsàn, tí àwọn ènìyàn méjìdínlọ́gọ́ta (58) sì ti jẹ́ Ọlọ́run nípè. Àjọ tó ń gbógun ti àjàkálẹ̀ aàrùn ti Nàìjíríà (NCDC) ló kéde yìí lórí ẹ̀rọ Twitter wọn, @NCDC. gov.
mt0: <pad> 24 more people have been confirmed to have coronavirus in Nigeria, bringing the total number of cases to 1832, while 319 people have been treated and 58 people have died. The National Center for Disease Control (NCDC) announced this on their Twitter account @NCDC.gov.</s>

en: --- COVID 19 : We have received some news about the happening in Kano – Dr. Osagie
yor: --- COVID-19: A ti gba ìròyìn díẹ̀ lórí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ní Kánò- Dókítà Osagie
mt0: <pad> COVID-19: We have received few information about the situation in Kano- Dr. Osagie</s>

en: The Minister for health in Nigeria Dr. Osagie Ehanire has said they have received some news on the happening in Kano state.
yor: Mínísítà fún ètò ìlera ti Nàìjíríà, Dókítà Osagie Ehanire ti ní àwọn ri ìròyìn díẹ̀ gbà nípa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ onírúurú ní ìpínlẹ̀ Kánò.
mt0: <pad> The Minister for Health of Nigeria, Dr. Osagie Ehanire has said that they have received few information about the ongoing violence in Kano state.</s>

en: The minister said this in a daily interview of the federal Government in charge of fighting against COVID 19 with journalist in Abuja.
yor: Mínísítà sọ̀rọ̀ yìí lásìkò ètò ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò ojoojúmó tí ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba àpapọ̀ tó ń mójútó gbígbógun ti aàrùn COVID-19 ń ṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn akọ̣̣̣̣̣̀ròyìn nílùú Àbújá.
mt0: <pad> The minister said this during the daily press conference of the government's inter-ministerial committee on the management of the COVID-19 outbreak in Abuja.</s>

en: He continued that they are expecting the news about the sudden death in Kano state, and this help them to take step of providing the instrument, the professionals and the training to help stop COVID- 19 in Kano state.
yor: Ó tún tẹ̀síwájú pé àwọ̣n ṣí ń retí gbogbo ìròyìn nípa ìṣẹ̣̀lẹ̀ ikú òjijì tó wáyé ní ìpínlẹ̣̀ Kánò, eléyìí yóò ràn ìgbéṣẹ̀ pípèsè ètò ìrànwọ́  ìrìnsẹ̀ , àwọn  onímọ̀ àti ètò ẹ̣̀kọ́ tí wọn yóò  fún ìpínlẹ̀ Kánò láti dẹ́kun aàrùn  COVID-19.
mt0: <pad> He added that they were still awaiting all information about the deaths in Kano state, which will help the agency to provide travel support, specialists and education to Kano state to fight COVID-19.</s>

en: Dr Ehanire, now appealed health workers to follow the line of programmes to protect themselves always so that they will not be infected by COVID -19 or endanger themselves.
yor: Dókítà Ehanire , wá rọ̣ àwọ̣n òṣìṣẹ̣́ ètò ìlera làti maa tẹ̀ḷé ètò ìlànà láti dáàbò bò ara wọn nígbà gbogbo  kí wọ̣n máa bàa lùgbàdì aàrùn COVID-19 tàbí fi ara wọ̣n sínú ewu.
mt0: <pad> Dr. Ehanire urged health workers to follow the protocols to protect themselves from COVID-19 or put themselves at risk.</s>

en: --- Nigeria confirms 204 cases of COVID-19
yor: --- Nàìjíríà ṣàwárí àwọn alárùn COVID-19 mé̩rìnlélúgba
mt0: <pad> Nigeria has confirmed a total of 714 cases of COVID-19</s>

en: Nigeria has recorded 204 cases of the novel Coronavirus known as COVID-19, bringing the total number of the confirmed cases to 1932.
yor: Nàìjíríà ti ní àkosílẹ̀ ènìyàn mẹ́rìnlélúgba tí wọ́n ní ààrun kòrónà tí a mọ̀ sí COVID – 19, èyí tó mú gbogbo akárùn náà jé̩ o̩gbò̩nlélé̩è̩dé̩gbàá lé méjì (1932).
mt0: <pad> Nigeria has recorded a total of twenty-five cases of coronavirus disease, COVID-19, since the outbreak began in March 1932.</s>

en: There are 319 Discharged and 58 Deaths.
yor: Okòóléló̩ò̩dúnrún dín ò̩kan (319) gba ìwòsàn, méjìdínlọ́gọ́ta sì kú.
mt0: <pad> Around 300 people have been diagnosed with the disease, and 24 have died.</s>

en: On its official Twitter handle @NCDCgov, the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control, NCDC, showed the breakdown of the new cases;
yor: Àjo̩ a-gbógun-ti-àjàkálẹ̀-ààrun ti Nàìjíríà (NCDC) ló so̩ èyí lórí ẹ̀rọ abẹ́yẹfò @NCCDCgov;
mt0: <pad> The Nigerian Center for Disease Control (NCDC) tweeted this on its Twitter account @NCCDCgov.</s>

en: 204 new cases of #COVID19 reported;
yor: Alárùn COVID-19 mé̩rìnlélúgba ti farahàn;
mt0: <pad> Around 200,000 people have been diagnosed with COVID-19</s>

en: 80-Kano 45-Lagos 12-Gombe 9-Bauchi 9-Sokoto 7-Borno 7-Edo 6-Rivers 6-Ogun 4-FCT 4-Akwa Ibom 4-Bayelsa 3-Kaduna 2-Oyo 2-Delta 2-Nasarawa 1-Ondo 1-Kebbi 11:50pm 30th April- 1932 confirmed cases of #COVID19 in Nigeria  Discharged.
yor: Ọgọ́rin-Kano, márùndínláàdọ́ta-Èkó, méjìlá-Gombe, mẹ̩́sàn-án-Bauchi, mé̩sàn-án-Sokoto, méje-Borno, méje-Edo, méfà-Rivers, méfà-Ògùn, mẹ́rin-Àbújá, mẹ́rin-Akwa Ibom, mẹ́rin-Bayelsa, mẹ́ta-Kaduna, méjì-Òyó, méjì-Delta, méjì-Nasarawa, Ò̩kan-Òǹdó, Ò̩kan-Kebbi.  Ní agogo méjìlá ku ìṣéjú mẹ́wàá, ọgbọ̀n ọjo oṣú igbe – 1932 alárùn Covid-19 farahàn ní Nàìjíríà.
mt0: <pad> twenty-one Kano, eighteen Eko, twelve Gombe, six Bauchi, six Sokoto, seven Borno, seven Edo, five Rivers, five Ogun, four Abuja, four Bayelsa, four Kaduna, three Oyo, three Delta, three Nasarawa, two Kebbi. As of 12:00pm on 30 June – 1932 Covid-19 cases in Nigeria.</s>

en: --- COVID-19: Ministerial Task Team on Kano submits interim report
yor: --- COVID-19: Ikò̩ òṣìṣé mínísítà ti Kano s̩àgbékalè̩ ìròyìn gbà-á-gbè̩
mt0: <pad> COVID-19: Òṣìṣẹ́ àjọ Kano s̩àgbékalè̩ ìròyìn gbà-á-gbè̩</s>

en: The Ministerial Task Team on fact-finding mission to Kano has submitted an interim report to the Federal Ministry of Health, on the needs, strengths and weaknesses of the Kano response system.
yor: Ikò̩ ọ̀ṣìṣẹ́ mínísítà lóri is̩é̩ ìwádìí sí Kano, ti s̩e àgbékalè̩ ìròyìn gbà-á-gbè̩  fun ilé-iṣẹ́ ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti ìlera, lórí ìdí, okun àti àìlera ọ̀nà tí ìpínlẹ̀ Kano ṣe ń dáhùn.
mt0: <pad> The Ministry of Energy, the National Power Corporation, has published a report on the water, sea and road infrastructures that Kano state is responding to.</s>

en: The Minister of Health, Dr Osagie Ehanire said this at the daily joint press briefing by the Presidential Task Force on Covid-19, in Abuja, Nigeria.
yor: Mínísítà fún ìlera, Dókítà Osagie Ehanire sò̩yí nínú ìpàdé àpapọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn oníròyìn èyí tí ìgbìmọ̀ ìjọba àpapọ tó ń mójútó COVID-19 ní Àbújá ṣe.
mt0: <pad> The Health Minister, Dr. Osagie Ehanire, said this in a press conference held by the Abuja-based intergovernmental task force on COVID-19.</s>

en: He said while the Ministry awaits a full report, the interim report will be a guide in supporting Kano State COVID-19 Task force with necessary material, training and human resources.
yor: Ó ní bí ilé-iṣé ìjọba àpapọ s̩e ń retí ìròyìn kíkún, ìròyìn gbà-á-bè̩ yìí yóò jẹ́ ató̩nà nínú ìrànwọ́ fún ikò̩ agbógunti Covid-19 ti Kano pèlú èròja to ye̩, ìdánilé̩kò̩ó̩ àti àwo̩n ènìyàn araniló̩wó̩.
mt0: <pad> As the Ministry of Health hopes for more information, this report will be a major step in helping Kano fight Covid-19 with enthusiasm, commitment and unity.</s>

en: “They will include assembling and dispatching a technical team from FMOH and virus Infectious disease specialists from Irrua Specialist hospital to join a technical team from Lagos Ministry of Health that is already on ground in Kano at the request of the Governor of Kano State” he said.
yor: “ Lára àwọn ohun ìrànwọ́ ni  kíkó àti rírán àwọn ẹgbẹ́ onímọ̀  láti FMOH àti àwọn onímọ̀ nípa kòkòrò ààrùn láti ilé-ìwòsàn Irrua Specialist Hospital láti darapọ̀ mọ́ ẹgbẹ́ onímọ̀ ilé-iṣẹ́ ètò ìlera ní ìpínlẹ̀ Èkó  tí ó ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìpínlẹ̀ Kano nítorí Gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ Kano”
mt0: <pad> “Among the assistances is to train and recruit specialist teams from FMOH and infectious disease specialists from Irrua Specialist Hospital to join the expert team of the Ekiti state health service which has been working in Kano for the Kano Governor.</s>

en: He said there will also be a good pool of experienced hands-on experts to support the leading role of Kano State in the response.
yor: Gé̩gé̩ bi ìdáhùn, ó tún so̩ pé àwọn onímọ̀ onírìírí yóò pò̩ jaburata ní ìkàlè̩ láti kin àwo̩n òs̩ìs̩é̩ ìs̩áájú lé̩yìn ní ìpínlẹ̀ Kano.
mt0: <pad> As a response, he also said that some experts will be involved in the preparation of the next general elections in Kano state.</s>

en: “An emergency medical team from FHOH has left Abuja with ambulances, five of which were kindly donated by FRSC, on their way to Kano to provide emergency response in view of movement restrictions arising from the lockdown.”
yor: “E̩gbẹ́ oníṣègùn tó ń dáhùn ìpè pàjáwìrì lati FMOH ti kúrò ní Àbújá pẹ̀lú àwo̩n áḿbúlàǹsì, márùn-ún ni àjọ ẹ̀ṣọ́ ojú pópó (FRSC) fi to̩re̩, lọ́nà láti lọ sí ìpínlẹ̀ Kano fún ìdáhùn pàjáwìrì látàríi àṣẹ kónílégbélé.
mt0: <pad> “The medical response team from FMOH left Abuja with ambulances on March, the February Society for the Protection of the Face (FRSC) took over, on the way to Kano state for response to the outbreak under the emergency orders issued by the Federal Republic of Nigeria.</s>

en: Dr Ehanire restated the need for health workers to stringently follow laid down standard infection prevention and control measures at all times and not to take risks.
yor: Dókítà Ehanire tún sọ̀dí tí àwọn òṣìṣé ìlera ṣe gbọ́dọ̀ tẹ̀lé àwọn ìlànà ìpara-ẹni-mọ́ fún ààrùn ní gbogbo ìgbà, kí wọ́n máa sì fi ẹ̀mí wọn wéwu.
mt0: <pad> Dr. Ehanire also stressed the need for health workers to follow the infection control measures at all times and put their lives at risk.</s>

en: “We cannot afford to lose the service of essential manpower at this time; every client should be treated with a high index of suspicion for COVID-19, but treat every client with fairness so that persons suffering from other ailments do not suffer neglect or treatment refusal.”
yor: “A kò leè gbà láti pàdánù àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ pàtàkì nírú àkókò báyìí; gbogbo ènìyàn ni wọ́n gbọ́dọ̀ tó̩jú pẹ̀lú ìfura tó ga fún COVID-19 sùgbọ́n kí wọ́n tójú gbogbo ènìyàn láì s̩ojús̩àájú kí àwọn elòmíràn pẹ̀lú àìsàn má baà jìyà àìdásí tàbí kí wọ́n má tó̩jú wọn.”
mt0: <pad> "We can't afford to lose key staff at this time; everyone should be tested with high levels of care for COVID-19 but everyone should be tested without a referral so that others with the disease don't get neglected or treated."</s>

en: “It is not ethical to turn clients away without, at least a medical advice, neither should a person in distress be refused care in emergency situation” he said.
yor: Ó wípé, “Ó jẹ́ ohun àìdára láti lé àwọn ènìyàn lọ láìsí ìmọ̀ràn nípa ètò ìlera tàbí kí á fi ìtọ́jú du ẹni tí ó nílò ìtọ́jú ní pàjáwìrì.”
mt0: <pad> He said, "It is not good to leave people without advice about health plans or to take care of someone who needs it in an emergency."</s>

en: --- Re-opening of schools not yet in view – Minister
yor: --- S̩ís̩í àwo̩n ilé-è̩kó̩ kò tíì farahàn - Mínísítà
mt0: <pad> - The Ministry of Education has not yet announced the numbers of the schools.</s>

en: The Minister of State for Education, Emeka Nwajiuba says he cannot for-see or immediately tell when schools will be reopened.
yor: Mínísítà ìpínlẹ̣̀ fún ètò ẹ̣̀kọ̣́, Emeka Nwajiuba ní òun kò leè sọjọ́ tàbí ìgbà tí wọn yóò padà ṣí ilé-è̩kó̩.
mt0: <pad> The minister of education, Emeka Nwajiuba said he can't say when they will return to school.</s>

en: The Minister also said re-opening of schools will be in tandem with President Muhammadu Buhari’s gradual ease of the lockdown put in place to curb the spread of COVID-19.
yor: Mínísítà tẹ̣̀síwájú pé ṣíṣí àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ yóò jẹ́ ní sísẹ̀-n-tẹ̀lé pẹ̀lú bí Ààrẹ Muhammadu Buhari ṣe ń gbẹ́sẹ̀ kúrò lórí àṣẹ kónílé–gbélé tí ó wà láti kápá ààrùn kòrónà.
mt0: <pad> The minister announced that the reopening of schools will be a follow-up to the President Muhammadu Buhari's decision to lift the lockdown order to curb coronavirus.</s>

en: Nwajiuba who had earlier during the daily briefing said that the government is not ready to put the lives of children at risk, warned that no school should engage students except when a formal date of resumption is announced by the government.
yor: Nwajiuba, nínú ọ̀rọ̀ rẹ̀ lójojúmọ́ ti sọ s̩áájú wípé ìjọ̣̣ba kò ṣetán láti fi ẹ̣̀mí àwọ̣̣̣̣n o̩mo̩ wéwu, ó wá kìlọ̀ wípé ilé-è̩kó̩ kọkan kò gbọdọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ ètò ẹ̀kọ́ nílé-è̩kó̩ wọ̣̣n àyàfi ọjọ́ tí ìjọ̣̣ba bá kéde rẹ̀ pé kí ilé-è̩kó̩ wọlé.
mt0: <pad> Nwajiuba, in his speech yesterday, has said that the church is not prepared to give up on the lives of our children, and he warned that no school should start its educational program until the day the church has announced that the school can enter.</s>

en: ” In anyway none of these schools can function outside the society”.
yor: “Ní kúkurú, kò sí èyíkèyí nínú àwo̩n ilé-è̩kó̩ yìí tó le s̩í lé̩yìn odi.
mt0: <pad> "Unfortunately, no one in these schools can go behind the door.</s>

en: The Minister also said that all entrance examinations that had been postponed will hold when the government is satisfied that the students have understood the syllabus as planned.
yor: Mínísítà tún so̩ pé gbogbo àwọ̣̣n ìdánwò ìgbaniwọlé tí wọ́n ti sún síwájú ni yóò di ṣíṣe nígbà tí ìjọba bá ri dájú pé gbogbo ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ tí wó̩n gbékalè̩ ló yé àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ó̩.
mt0: <pad> The minister also said that all admission tests will be held when the government is sure that all the educational programs are suitable for students.</s>

en: The Minister clarified that both the West African Examination Council for Senior School Students and other National Examinations including NABTEB are not cancelled but only postponed.
yor: Mínísítà ṣe àlàyé pé ìdánwò àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ oníwèémẹwàá (WAEC) àti àwọn ìdánwò àpapọ̀ (NECO) pẹ̀lu NABTEB ni kò ì di fífagilé sùgbọ́n tí wó̩n sún síwájú.
mt0: <pad> The ministry said the examinations of the WAEC and NECO, as well as NABTEB, were not cancelled but in progress.</s>

en: He acknowledged challenges in the deployment of the e-learning policy hence the engagement of the State Universal Basic Education Boards.
yor: Ó sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìpèníjà tí ẹ̀kọ́ orí ayélujára tí a ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ mú wọlé àti bí a ṣe mú ètò ẹ̀kọ́ gbogboogbò ní ìpínlẹ̀ lò.
mt0: <pad> He spoke about the impact of online education and how the statewide educational system was used.</s>

en: According to him,” we know some are limited by access and the access is limited by device, some can only get on the continuation of their academic program via radio, some at the television level, some are using computer online system, so we are doing this in partnership with states meaning that every gap we intend to bridge as regards the education of these children nationwide, we had to pass through every state Governor through their SUBEBS”
yor: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ó ṣe sọ, “A mọ̀ wípé àwọn kan kò ni àǹfààní àti àìkò ní àǹfààní yìí nítorí àìkò ní ẹ̀rọ tó kún ojú òsùwọ̀n, àwọn kan le tẹsíwájú nínú ẹ̀kọ́ wọn lórí rédíò, àwọn kan lórí te̩lifís̩àn, àwọn kan sì ń lo ẹ̀rọ ayára-bí-àsá pẹ̀lú ayélujára, nítorí náà à ń ṣe èyí pẹ̀lú àjọṣiṣẹ́pọ̀ ìjọba ìpínlẹ, èyí túmọ̀ sí pé gbogbo àlàfo tí a fe̩ dí tó nííṣe pẹ̀lú ẹ̀kọ́ àwọn ọmọ jákèjádò orílẹ̀-èdè yìí, a nílò láti gba ọ̀dọ̀ Gómìnà ìpínlẹ̀ kọ̀ọ̀kan nípaṣè àjọ ẹ̀kọ́ alákọ̀ọ́bẹ̀rẹ̀ káríayé SUBEBS”
mt0: <pad> According to him, "We know that some don't have the opportunity and time to continue their education through this technology, some can continue their education on radio, some on television, some on the internet, so we are doing this with the cooperation of the state governments, that means that all our proposals regarding the education of the young people of this country will need to be approved by the governors of each state through SUBEBS.</s>

en: “Presently we have time table for 31 states out of 36 states, which means via Radio or T.v, teaching and learning are ongoing, these are time tables that suit each state but the federal government has only provided guideline via online content”
yor: "Ní báyìí a ti ní ètò ìlànà ẹ̣̀kọ̣́ fún àwọ̣̣n ìpínlẹ̀ mọ̣́kànlélọ̣́gbọ̀n nínú ìpínlẹ̀ mẹ̣̣́rìndínlógóji, èyí túmọ̀ sí wípé láti orí rédíò tàbí te̩lifís̩àn, ìkọ́ni àti ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ n lọ, èyí jẹ́ àwo̩n ìlànà ìkẹ́kò̩ọ́ tó dára fún ìpínlẹ kọ̀ọ̀kan sùgbọ́n ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti ṣe ìlànà láti orí ayélujára.”
mt0: <pad> Now we have a system of education for the 34 states, that is, from radio or television, instruction and education is going on, this is a good system of education for each state but the central government has made a system of education on the internet."</s>

en: “Using these SUBEBs ,the same way we share their interventions with them is the same way this teaching and learning online content is been shared and the FG informed that they could use state media that is appropriate in their areas”. Nwajiuba said.
yor: Nwajiuba sọ wípé “Lílo àwo̩n SUBEB, ọ̀nà tí à ń gbà momi o̩gbó̩n wo̩n ni a ṣe fi pín kíkọ́ àti mímọ̀ yìí lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára. Ìjọba àpapọ̀ sì sọ wípé wọ́n leè lo àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìgbóhùn sáfẹ́fẹ́ ti ìpínlẹ̀ wo̩n tó dára fún un”.
mt0: <pad> Nwajiuba said, "We used SUBEB, the traditional method of recording their parents, to share this knowledge and information on the internet. The Federal Government also said that they can use their local radio stations that are best for them."</s>

en: The Minister added that the COVID 19 pandemic has helped all stakeholders to retool and has also helped everybody to get on board.
yor: Mínísítà s̩àfikún pé àjàkálẹ̀ ààrùn COVID-19 ti ran àwọn olókoòwò gbogbo lọ́wọ́ láti túnramú, ó sì ti ran ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan láti bọ́ sójú iṣẹ́.
mt0: <pad> The minister said that the COVID-19 pandemic has helped all managers rethink, and enabled everyone to return to their work.</s>

en: Speaking on the Sustainability of the e-learning policy, the Minister said the government will further engage master teachers that will perfect the system that will transcend its use after the Coronavirus health challenge facing the world.
yor: Nígbà tó ń sọ̀rọ̀ lórí ìmúdúró ẹ̀kọ́ lórí ayélujára, mínísítà sọ wípé ìjọba yóò túnbọ̀ ṣàmúlò àwọn olùkọ́ akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ tí yóò ṣàṣepé ètò náà tí yóò leè mú u wúlò lẹ́yìn ìpèníjà ààrun kòrónà tó kojú àgbááyé.
mt0: <pad> When speaking about the suspension of online education, the minister said the government will rehire qualified teachers to support the program and resume it after the global outbreak of coronavirus.</s>

en: Meanwhile the Education Secretariat of the Federal Capital Territory Administration FCTA, has issued a warning to some private Schools disseminating information to parents and students indicating the resumption of the 2019/2020 3rd term calendar online.
yor: Bákan náà, ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀kọ́ tó ń ṣàmójútó àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ ní olú-ìlú FCTA, ṣe ìkìlọ̀ fún àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ aládàáni tí wọ́n ń dájọ́ ìwọlé táàmù kẹta fún 2019/2020 lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára fún àwọn òbí àti akẹ́kọ̀ọ́.
mt0: <pad> Furthermore, the Federal Council for Teachers' Accreditation (FCTA) has warned poor schools that they are taking in the third term for 2019/2020 online for parents and students.</s>

en: The FCTA Education Secretary, Umaru Marafa said in a statement released on Tuesday that no academic activities in all Schools in any form should commence until a notice to reopen is approved and conveyed by the Secretariat”
yor: Akọ̀wé ilé-iṣẹ́ àjọ tó ń mójútó ilé-è̩kó̩, Umaru Marafa sọ nínú àtẹ̀jáde ọjọ́ ìṣẹ́gun wípé kò sí iṣẹ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kọ̀kan ní ilé-è̩kó̩ kọ̀ọ̀kan lọ́nàkọnà tó gbọ́dọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ títí di ìgbà tí àṣẹ s̩ís̩í ilé ìwé bá jáde.
mt0: <pad> The spokesman for the National Council of Education, Umaru Marafa, said in a statement on Wednesday that no school work will start until the schools are reopened.</s>

en: “The Implication of this is that when the Schools will be reopened, adequate notice of the fact that 2nd term was inconclusive will be factored into the academic calendar which will dovetail into the 3rd term accordingly. Any action taken otherwise is likely to negatively distort the academic calendar of the schools involved” Marafa said.
yor: Marafa so̩ pé, “Ìtumò̩ èyí ni pé nígbà tí àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ yóò bá di s̩ís̩í padà, ìfilọ̀ tí ó yé̩ ni yóò ti wà lórí táàmù kejì tí kò parí, àti ò̩nà àti runmó̩ táàmù kẹta bí ó ti yẹ. Ìgbésè̩ tó bá lòdì sí èyí ṣeéṣe kó kóbá ètò ẹ̀kọ́ àwọn ilé-è̩kó̩ tó kàn.
mt0: <pad> Marafa said, "This means that when the schools reopen, the offer will be on the second stage of the first phase, and the path and framework for the third stage as it should be. Any action against this could affect the education schedule of the schools affected."</s>

en: School proprietors are therefore, advised to maintain the status quo and keep their schools closed and not re-open in any form while they await further directives from the FCTA.
yor: Wó̩n ro̩ àwọn ọ̀gá ilé-è̩kó̩ aláàdáni láti sowé-agbéjé̩-mó̩wó̩ kí ilé-è̩kó̩ wò̩n sì wà látìpa, kí wọ́n má s̩e si ní ọ̀nàkọnà títí ìjò̩ba yóò fi sohun mìíràn.
mt0: <pad> They urged the head of the schools to prepare for the coming storm and ensure that their schools are safe, so that they don't have any traffic until the government decides to relocate.</s>

en: Violators of this directive will face the full wrath of the law.
yor: Àwọn tí wọ́n bá ṣe lòdì sí àṣẹ yìí yóò dojúkọ ìdájọ́ òfin pó̩nńbélé;
mt0: <pad> those who violate this order will face the full legal process</s>

en: Marafa further disclosed that the FCTA Education Secretariat has concluded plans to introduce e-learning platforms to include lessons on radio and television channels to keep the students constructively engaged while the lockdown lasts.
yor: Marafa tún sọ wípé ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀kọ́ ìjọba àpapọ̀ ti parí gbogbo ètò láti leè mú ètò ẹ̀kọ́ lórí ayélujára w̩onú èto ẹ̀kọ́ yálà lóri rédíò tàbí te̩lifís̩àn kí àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ leè máa ṣiṣẹ́ nígbogbo ìgbà tí kónílé gbélé bá fiwà.
mt0: <pad> Marafa also said that the National Education Corporation had completed all plans to provide online and radio education programs so that students can work whenever they want while the coronavirus is out.</s>

en: --- No private school must start work –  Minister FCT
yor: --- Kò gbọ̣̣̣̣̣dọ̣̀ ṣí ilé-ìwé aládàáni kankan tó gbọ̣́dọ̣̀ bẹ̣̀rẹ̣̀ isẹ̣́ – Mínísítà FCT
mt0: <pad> No schools should start operating - FCT Minister</s>

en: The Minister for the Federal capital territory (FCT), Alhaji Muhammad Musa Bello has warned the proprietors of private schools in Abuja that have started informing parents and students that very soon they will start work for the third term for the present 2019/2020 academic session, to be careful so that they will not face the wrath of government law.
yor: Mínísítà fún olú-ìlú Nàìjíríà, Alhaji Muhammad Músá Bello ti ṣ̣èkìlọ̀ fún gbogbo àwọ̣̣n olùdarí ilé-ìwé aládàáni tó wà nílùú Àbújá tí wọ́n ti ń sọ̣̣ fún gbogbo àwọ̣̣n òbí àti akẹ̣̣́kọ̣̀ọ́ pé wọ̣̣n kò ní pẹ́ bẹ̣̀rẹ̣̀ iṣ̣ẹ́ láìpẹ̣́ fún sáà kẹ̣̣ta fún ti ọ̣dún 2019/2020 tí a wàyìí láti ṣ̣ọ̣̣́ra, kí wọ̣̣́n máa ba fojụ winá òfin ìjọ̣̣ba.
mt0: <pad> The Minister for Education, Alhaji Muhammad Musa Bello has warned all primary school principals in the state of Abija that they should not start their third semester without approval from the state government to avoid violating the state constitution.</s>

en: Senior secretary for education in the federal capital territory, Umaru Marafa said this in a statement released on Tuesday that no academic activities in all Schools in any form should commence until a notice to reopen is approved and conveyed by the Secretariat”
yor: Akọ̣̣̀wé àgbà fún ètò ẹ̣̣̀kọ́ nílùú Àbújá, Umaru Máráfá  ló sọ̣̣̀rọ̣̣̀ yíì nínú àtẹ̀jáde kan tí ó gbé jáde lọ̣̣́jọ́ ìṣ̣ẹ̣̣́gun pé ètò ẹ̣̣̀kọ́  kò ní tíì bẹ̣̣̀rẹ̀ nílé ìwé kankan tó wà nílùú Àbújá báyìí àyàfi ọjọ́ tí ilé-iṣ̣ẹ́  akọ̀wé àgbà fún ètò ẹ̣̣̀kọ́ bá fọ̣̣wọ̣̣́si.
mt0: <pad> The chief of education in Abuja, Umaru Marafa, said on Thursday that no school will start in any school in the state until the office of the chief of education is approved.</s>

en: “We are appealing to private school proprietors to allow all their schools to remain closed, they must not try to open the school except there is a  notice or guideline from ministry of FCTA”
yor: "À ń rọ̣̣ gbogbo àwọ̣̣n olùdarí ilé-è̩kó̩ aládàáni láti jẹ́ kí ilé-è̩kó̩ wà ní títìpa, wọn kò gbọ̣̣̣dọ̣̣̀ gbìyànjú láti ṣí ilé-è̩kó̩ náà àfi tí àṣ̣ẹ̣̣ tàbí ìlànà bá wá láti ọ̀dọ̀ ilé-iṣ̣ẹ́ FCTA."
mt0: <pad> We urge all disabled school administrators to keep the school clean, and not attempt to shut down the school unless a directive or order is received from the FCTA Board of Directors."</s>

en: All those that go against this rule shall face the wrath of law.
yor: Gbogbo àwọ̣̣n tó bá tàpá ṣófin yìí ni yóò fojú winá òfin ìjọ̣̣ba.
mt0: <pad> Everyone who opposes this bill will be violating the church's law.</s>

en: Marafa continued that Ministry of FCTA in charge of education has planned to start teaching by using the knowledge of internet, the use of television to teach the students in the period of lockdown.
yor: Máràfá tẹ̀síwájú pé ilé-iṣ̣ẹ́ FCTA tí ó ń mójútó ètò ẹ̣̀kọ́ ti s̩e ètò láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ ètò ẹ̀kọ́ nípa lílo ìmọ̀ ayélujára, àti s̩ís̩e àmúlò te̩lifís̩àn láti fi kọ̣́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní àkókò kónílé-gbélé.
mt0: <pad> FCTA, the agency that manages the education programme, has decided to start an online education and use television to teach students in the evening hours.</s>

en: --- FULL TEXT OF PRESIDENT MUHAMMADU BUHARI’S NATIONWIDE BROADCAST
yor: --- Ọ̀RỌ̀ ÀÀRẸ MUHAMMADU BUHARI LÓRI TE̩LIFÍS̩ÀN SỌ́MỌ NÀÌJÍRÍÀ
mt0: <pad> Muhammadu Buhari during his televised address to the nation on Sunday.</s>

en: ADDRESS BY H.E. MUHAMMADU BUHARI, PRESIDENT OF THE FEDERAL REPUBLIC OF NIGERIA ON THE CUMULATIVE LOCKDOWN ORDER OF LAGOS AND OGUN STATES AS WELL AS THE FEDERAL CAPITAL TERRITORY ON COVID- 19 PANDEMIC AT THE STATE HOUSE, ABUJA, MONDAY, 27th APRIL, 2020
yor: Ọ̀RỌ̀ ÀÀRẸ ORÍLẸ̀-ÈDÈ NÀ̀ÌJÍRÍÀ, MUHAMMADU BUHARI, NÍPA ÒFIN KÓNÍLÉ-GBÉLÉ NÍ ÌPÍNLẸ̀ ÈKÓ, ÒGÙN ÀTI ÌLÚ ÀBÚJÁ, FCT, LÓRI  ÌTÀNKÁLẸ̀ ÀÀRÙN COVID- 19, NÍ ÈYÍ TÍ Ó WÁYÉ NÍ ÌLÚ ÀBÚJÁ LỌ́JỌ́ AJÉ, ỌJÓ̩ KẸTÀDÍNLỌ́GBỌ́N, OSÙ KẸRIN ,ỌDÚN 2020 (MONDAY, 27th APRIL, 2020).
mt0: <pad> President Muhammadu Buhari, as chairman of the Committee on Economic and Social Development, FCT, on the management of COVID-19, in his address to the nation on Monday, 27th April, 2020 (Monday, 27th April, 2020).</s>

en: 1. Fellow Nigerians
yor: 1.O̩mọ Nàìjíríà
mt0: <pad> 1.O̩mọ Nàìjíríà</s>

en: 2. I will start by commending you all for the resilience and patriotism that you have shown in our collective fight against the biggest health challenge of our generation.
yor: 2.Màá bẹ̀rẹ̀ pè̩lú gbígbós̩ùbà fun yín nítorí ìwà akínkanjú àti ìjólóòótọ́ yín èyí tẹ s̩àfihàn nínú ìjà àjùmò̩jà sí ìpèníjà ìlera tó gajù, tó ń kojú ìran wa.
mt0: <pad> 2.Let me start by thanking you for your courage and sincerity in the fight against the evil disease that is threatening our nation.</s>

en: 3. As at yesterday, 26th April 2020, some 3 million confirmed cases of COVID-19 have been recorded globally with about 900,000 recoveries. Unfortunately, some 200,000 people have passed away as a result of this pandemic.
yor: 3.Níwòyí àná, 26th April 2020, àgbáyé s̩àwárí àwo̩n alárùn Covid-19 míĺiọ̣́nù mẹ́ta, tí ẹ̀ẹ́dẹ́gbààrún ló̩nà e̩gbè̩rún ènìyàn sì ti gbàwòsàn. Ó ṣeni láàánú pé igba ló̩nà e̩gbè̩rún ènìyàn ló tipasè̩ ààrùn náà papò̩dà.
mt0: <pad> 3 As of 26th April 2020, the world has confirmed more than three million cases of Covid-19, and over one million people have been cured. Unfortunately, only about half of the cases have been transmitted by humans.</s>

en: 4. The health systems and economies of many nations continue to struggle as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.
yor: 4.Ètò ìlera àti ọrọ̀ ajé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ orílẹ̀ èdè ni ó sì ń tiraka látàrí àjàkálẹ́ ààrùn kòkòrò kòrónà.
mt0: <pad> 4.The economy and energy systems of many countries are still under pressure from the coronavirus outbreak.</s>

en: 5. Nigeria continues to adapt to these new global realities on a daily basis. Today, I will present the facts as they are and explain our plans for the coming months fully aware that some key variables and assumptions may change in the coming days or weeks.
yor: 5.Nàìjíríà ń tẹ̀síwájú láti máa mọ àwọn òótọ́ titun tó ń súyo̩ lágbàáyé lójoojúmó̩. Lónìí, n ó sọ àwọn òtítọ́ bó ṣe jẹ́, n ó sì ṣàl̀àyé àwọn ètò wa fún àwọn oṣu tó ń bọ̀ nígb̀atí a tí mọ̀ wípé àwọn ohun kan lè yípadà láwọn ọjọ́ àtọ̀sẹ̀ tó ń bọ̀.
mt0: <pad> 5 Nigeria continues to be aware of the new reality that is taking place around the world every day. Today, I will tell the truth and outline our plans for the coming months while we know that things may change in the coming days.</s>

en: 6. Exactly two weeks ago, there were 323 confirmed cases in 20 States and the Federal Capital Territory.
yor: 6.Ní déédé ọ̀sẹ̀ méjì sẹ́yìn, oníkòrónà okòóléló̩ò̩dúnrún lé mé̩ta ni wó̩n s̩àwárí nípìnínlè̩ ogún àti olú-ìlú.
